It's more likely that because we always try to make a big impact in our work, we lose the natural flow needed for letter writing. Real creative artists, who don't focus on the impact of their words (even if they rewrite a passage many times), don't have this issue. I think the true test of a real artist is their natural understanding of the effect of their words. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably didn't consciously think about how the mix of long words made them powerful, but it showed his greatness as a writer.

**Supermarket Opening**

In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a special event. You could expect a soap opera star, a radio DJ, or a minor royal to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets seem to open every day, so celebrities are no longer needed. Why pay a famous person when anyone can do it for free? Last week, waiting pensioners didn't care who opened the new Superbuy store, as long as they were first in line. One customer, who knew someone working there, said the first five men would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women, a bunch of flowers. This information quickly spread through the crowd, making those at the front feel pleased and the latecomers envious.

**Citizen Kane**

When the film *Citizen Kane* was finally released in 1941, it faced a lot of controversy. The release was delayed because distributors were afraid of what William Randolph Hearst, who was thought to be the film's subject, might do to them. Despite receiving mostly enthusiastic reviews, the film was not a commercial hit. It was television that later brought it back to public attention. *Citizen Kane* is perhaps the most influential film, inspiring many to become filmmakers. This is especially surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles always said that its success came from not knowing what he was or wasn't allowed to do; he just did what he wanted. He had an amazing team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to create a story about a newspaper tycoon who was both like and unlike Hearst, Welles knew he had found the perfect project for himself as both director and actor. He took the opportunity with great enthusiasm.

**Dermot and Carmel**

Dermot noticed that Carmel seemed a bit strange that morning. He mentioned twice that he might be late and not to worry if he stopped by the golf club on his way home. He needed to chat with someone, and it was the best place to do so. Twice, Carmel nodded her head in a friendly but distant way, as if she hadn't really heard or understood. "Will you be all right? What are you going to do today?" he asked. She smiled and said, "Funny you should ask that. I was just thinking that I had nothing to do all day, so I was going to walk downtown and look at the shops. I thought it was almost a sinful thing, just wasting the day." Dermot smiled back. "You're allowed to enjoy yourself. And as I said, if I'm late, I won't need anything to eat. So don't go to any trouble." "No, that's fine," she replied.

**Title Race**

Tea boy? No, I'm a mobile lukewarm beverage resource facilitator.

Human nature provides the most amusing of comedies. A recent study showed that job titles are a major cause of envy and unrest at work. A survey by a top recruitment firm found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees admit that titles create divisions among colleagues. Surprisingly, the survey found that 70% of office workers would be willing to give up a pay raise for a more 'motivational' or 'professional' job title. If our vanity is so strong that it even overcomes basic greed, we are indeed in trouble. The truth is that in these early days of the twenty-first century, nobody wants to be seen as subordinate. The titles being discussed focus on ability (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just euphemisms.

The Vienna Assignment

I was in Vienna to take photographs. That was usually why I traveled anywhere. Photography was more than just my job; it was a big part of my life. The way light touched a surface always sparked my imagination. A single photo could capture the essence of a time, place, city, or person. I always hoped to take the perfect photograph, as long as I had film in my camera. Finish one roll, load another, and keep looking with open eyes. That was my approach for a long time.

I almost succeeded once when a photo I took of a smoke plume from a burning oil well became popular worldwide. It was a brief moment of fame, mostly due to luck. But they say you make your own luck, both good and bad. I went freelance after that, which seemed like a smart move, but life outside photography took some wrong turns. The mid-nineties weren't as successful as I had hoped after my photo made it to the cover of Time magazine. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more newsworthy. But I was still taking photos and getting paid for it, which wasn't bad.

The assignment came by chance. I had taken photos in London for a picture book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons" featuring London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. It was a European project that paid me well to capture my home city in different seasons. I added my own style to scenes like daffodils in Hyde Park and traffic in Piccadilly. I accepted that the best of my work might be overlooked since it was just a picture book, not meant to challenge anyone's views.

After finishing my London-in-winter photos, I learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left the Vienna job for unknown reasons. Instead of hiring someone new, they offered me the role. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, unlike the French and Italian photographers. I was happy to go because things at home weren't great. A week in snowy Vienna was appealing, and I didn't need it to be a compliment to my artistry.

They put me up at the Europa Hotel, in the heart of the old city. I had last visited Vienna with my wife for a busy summer weekend, but it wasn't memorable, and I didn't take many photos. This time, in a cold January, it would be different. I felt it as soon as I arrived and saw the pinky-grey light over the snow-covered roofs. I was going to enjoy myself and take great pictures.

The first day, I didn't even try to take photos. I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, getting on and off to feel the city's atmosphere. The weather was set, frozen like the grand baroque buildings of the old empire. I hadn't seen Schussner's work from other seasons and didn't want to. This was going to be my Vienna. I just had to wait for the right moment. A photograph captures a moment, but you have to wait for it to come. So I waited and looked until I could see clearly.

The next morning, I was out at dawn. Snow had fallen overnight, making Stephansplatz white and almost empty. I hadn't figured out how to capture the cathedral in one shot. Its spire reached into the sky like a giraffe's neck, but at ground level, it was massive like an elephant. I might have to settle for a partial shot. In that weather, it could still be magical. Photography has always had a magical quality. In the 19th century, before the chemistry was understood, it seemed mysterious. Even when you know how it works, the mystery remains. Perhaps that's why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn't surprise me.

**Kinetic Art Rejoice**

Something amazing has happened: London's serious Hayward Gallery has become a place of wonder. This change wasn't due to a big-budget, flashy show, but rather a unique exploration of a nearly forgotten art form from the last 60 years. A new exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art, which is art focused on movement, in the twentieth century. It shows that creating artworks that move by themselves or explore movement has been an ongoing, though often unnoticed, theme in fascinating creative work of this century. The exhibition, curated by Guy Brett, who has dedicated his life to studying kinetic art, includes a wide range of paintings, drawings, documents, and films. These are presented with minimal text, allowing visitors to enjoy making their own connections and discoveries.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney's art attracts many people who might not usually be interested in art. This could be because his work is figurative and easy to understand, or because it offers an escape from everyday life. Some people might be drawn to Hockney's charming personality and witty comments, which make him popular in the media. Some critics think Hockney is overrated, but others argue that his popularity doesn't mean his work lacks depth. Hockney himself knows his limits and believes it's not fair to dismiss his work because it doesn't fit an abstract idea of greatness. He doesn't claim to be a great artist and understands that only time will tell his true place in art history.

**Window-shopping - an art exhibition**

In recent years, I've seen many contemporary art exhibitions, some brilliant and some mediocre. What bothers me are shows that push a hidden agenda, suggesting a common attitude among artists. Sometimes this works, revealing new trends, but often it feels forced. As a curator, I wanted to create a show that was the opposite of this. With seven artists, I took over a space in an empty warehouse. "Window-shopping" was a collection of individual artworks connected only by their claim to be art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats chased each other on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley's video camera experiment flickered on a monitor. These works didn't fit into a themed exhibition but complemented each other through contrast. I didn't make any grand statements about contemporary art, but perhaps there aren't any to make about an activity where artists set their own rules.

**Art History**

People who enjoy paintings sometimes hesitate to analyze them, fearing it will spoil their experience. Some say that art historians, who focus on theory, ignore the pleasure of looking and the creativity of art. This idea is like thinking that knowing a recipe's ingredients and cooking method takes away from enjoying the dish. Understanding something doesn't stop us from enjoying it; it might even enhance our pleasure. Pleasure is complex, and how we experience it can be examined. Our preferences are influenced by societal values, not just personal taste. While the sensory response to art is important, the idea that thinking undermines feeling is an outdated belief from a time when art was seen as separate from thought.

**Metals**

Stone Age people might have become interested in metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. Imagine sitting by a river, waiting to catch a fish, when one of our early ancestors found a shiny yellow pebble. It didn't feel like a stone, but it was attractive. This is how gold might have become part of their lives. Gold is easy to shape, so it quickly became a valuable material. Copper might have been discovered by accident too. Once people realized how useful copper tools were, they eagerly searched for copper ores and ways to extract the metal. This is how metalworking became one of the skills that improved their lives.

**St Ives**

We walked silently, carrying our bags down the winding, cobbled lane into the town center. We were bent over against the strong wind and trying to avoid the icy waves crashing over the promenade. The streets were empty, and the shutters on every waterfront cottage were tightly closed against the storm. We had watched the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on the small single-track train. As the dark grey skies closed in, visiting Cornwall in the off-season without a car no longer seemed like a good idea. I had convinced my friend to join me with promises of walks along the beautiful Cornish coast and cozy evenings by open fires.

**Computer Modelling**

The challenge with studying the past is that it is gone. The people who lived through peaceful times and hard times are long dead. The reasons they settled in certain places or moved elsewhere, forming families, villages, and cities, are forgotten. Archaeology gives us hints, but we can't test our ideas with experiments on past cultures. We can't watch the past like a movie. Or can we? Computer modelling lets us recreate ancient landscapes and fill them with virtual communities. These digital creations have some of the needs and abilities of real humans. We can set rules for behavior and create social groups. Then we can change conditions, like reducing rainfall or increasing population, and see how this digital society reacts.

**Vervet Monkeys**  
Cheney and Seyfarth describe an incident with vervet monkeys. One day, the dominant male in their group noticed a strange male in a nearby grove of trees. The stranger wanted to join the group, which could mean the dominant male might lose his position. To prevent this, the dominant male used a clever trick. Whenever the stranger tried to approach, he gave an alarm call that vervets use to warn of a leopard. This scared the stranger back into the trees. This tactic worked until the dominant male made a mistake: he gave the alarm call while casually walking across open ground himself.

**What Cats Catch**  
In a survey in the English village of Felmersham, residents collected prey caught by their cats. Over a year, seventy cats caught over 1,000 prey items. An American professor estimated that, based on these figures, cats in Britain might be killing 100 million birds and small mammals each year. However, this calculation is not accurate because most cats live in towns and catch less prey than rural cats. The important question is whether these numbers are sustainable. The answer seems to be yes. Many people feed birds in winter, and gardens provide nesting sites, keeping bird populations above natural levels. The survey showed that cats are significant predators but not devastating to Britain's bird population.

**Buffalo's Day**  
Buffaloes are very important to marshmen and are well cared for. Each morning, the buffaloes leave their sleeping area slowly and with groans, heading to distant reed beds. They stand on the platform's edge, complaining about the day's fatigue, until the leader finally moves into the water. Once in the water, they seem to forget their purpose and wallow for a while. Their movements are so slow that they are barely noticeable, but eventually, they swim away, appearing exhausted. They spend the day among reeds and bulrushes, grazing on green shoots at eye level.

**PICASSO, Pablo**  
In early 1940, Picasso painted several fish still lifes while staying in the fishing port of Royan. One painting shows a fishmonger's slab with a crab and a pair of scales holding two or three soles. Despite their situation, the sea creatures appear alive. The painting is complex because Picasso used overlapping and interlocking transparent planes. The thin, delicately brushed paint and cool colors create a calm, underwater world. However, this calm is disturbed by an impending battle between the fish and the crab. The sharp forms of the fish and crab, along with the scales, suggest a sense of menace and hidden violence, giving the painting a symbolic edge.

Photography Over the past 150 years, photography has been used to capture all aspects of human life and activity. In this relatively short time, photography has grown in its ability to capture moments in time and space, allowing us to see fleeting moments and visualize both large and small details. It has shown us images from remote parts of the world, distant areas of the solar system, and the social complexities and crises of modern life. Photography has become one of the most important ways to express the human condition. However, using images to record events has a much longer history. The earliest pictorial recordings date back to the Upper Palaeolithic period, about 35,000 years ago. Although we cannot be sure of the exact purposes of early cave paintingsâ€”whether they recorded actual hunting events, served as magic to increase animals for hunting, acted as religious icons, or simply brightened domestic lifeâ€”pictorial images seem deeply connected to human culture. Throughout history, questions have been raised about the accuracy of visual images and their role in society. The idea that 'seeing is believing' has always given special importance to visual images. So when photography was invented, its social and cultural impact was huge. In the mid-19th century, photography promised to provide a truthful visual record automatically. The camera, working like the human eye, was seen as a machine that could capture a fixed image, very close to what we actually see. The chemical process of fixing the image allowed the capture of what might be considered a natural phenomenon: the camera image. At the same time, the photographic image was seen as a cultural achievement, producing images that artists had long struggled to create. Ironically, because of the camera's perceived realism, it was assumed that everyone would naturally understand photographs. This led to the question of whether photography was a 'universal language'. For example, in 1933, photographer August Sander expressed this view, saying even the most isolated person could understand a photograph of the sky. However, with the rapid increase in global communications in the late 20th century, we need to ask how well photographic images can cross cultural differences. Is photography as bound by cultural conventions as language? Is it possible that our familiarity with photographs has made us overlook the medium's ability to convey vivid impressions of 'reality'? Photography is often seen as providing convincing pictorial evidence, making the medium seem transparent and blurring the line between our perception of the environment and its photographic representations. It is common for someone to show a photograph and say, 'this is my grandson'. Since its invention in 1839, photography technology and attitudes towards it have changed significantly. This may be because photography has moved into 'mythic time'â€”its role as a 19th-century record-keeper has evolved, and photographic images, once immediate and close, have now become historical documents. These documents often reveal as much about the people and society that produced them as they do about their subjects. I aim to show that the camera is not just a passive recorder of events and that photography does not merely reflect culture but can inspire social and political change. For example, it is hard to imagine the cultural changes of the Italian Renaissance without recognizing the role of perspective in new visual representation. Similarly, photography has greatly contributed to the media culture of our era, while also bringing the harsh realities of the world to our coffee tables.

**How to Write Poetry**

Teaching someone how to write poetry is like walking through a minefield: you need to be spontaneous, but one wrong move and your certainties can explode. Claiming to know everything is risky, so I suggest that for beginners, no advice can replace reading a lot, writing often, and freeing your imagination and spirit in any productive way, except total chaos. Some people need a stable life to write a poem; others write to escape misery. Some follow a schedule; others wait for inspiration or a sudden idea. All methods are valid, as long as they aren't just following a set formula. It's important to find your own voice, listen to it, nurture it, and let it grow until it can stand on its own.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, there isn't space for too many characters, long narratives, or extended flashbacks. Flashbacks should be brief and only used if necessary to clarify an issue. A good way to do this is through a quick memory in the main character's mind, recalling an event that affects the current conflict. This can move the story forward but should never slow down the action. Dialogue is more useful than many new writers realize. Two characters talking can show two sides of a question faster than explaining it from one viewpoint. It also keeps the reader interested. Overwriting can ruin a short story, but brevity shouldn't make it just a summary. Conflict and action must be as strong as in a novel, but in a short story, every word must count.

**Screenplays**

If you know how to play chess, you can understand how to write a screenplay. Most chess players move from start to finish without knowing much, but enough to play. We make moves without knowing what will happen later. Maybe we see one or two moves ahead, and if we do, we're pleased with our ability. Over time, we realize chess is more about long-term strategy than short-term tactics. We start to see the game as a whole, not just individual moves. Patterns, called gambits, emerge, like openings, middle games, and end games. In chess and screenplay writing, the more you practice, the more you understand its complexities.

**Looking at Writing**

"Humans naturally speak, as seen in children's babble, but no child naturally bakes, brews, or writes." Charles Darwin was right: language is instinctive, but writing is not. Language exists in all societies, past and present. Languages change but don't improve: English is no more complex than Stone Age languages; modern English isn't better than Old English. All healthy children learn their language without lessons. When children lack a language, they create one. Writing, however, has been invented rarely in history, only in a few complex societies, and it developed slowly. Until recently, most children didn't learn to read or write; even today, many struggle. A group of children is as unlikely to invent an alphabet as they are to invent an engine. Children are naturally good with sounds, but reading and writing are skills that must be carefully taught. We need to understand how writing works, how children's minds work, and how to connect the two.

I have never started a novel with more doubt. I call it a novel only because I don't know what else to call it. I have little story to tell, and I don't end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader uncertain. This book is about my memories of a man I met only occasionally, and I know little about what happened to him in between. I could invent details to make the story more complete, but I don't want to do that. I only want to share what I know. To avoid embarrassing people who are still alive, I have given the characters made-up names and taken care to ensure no one recognizes them. The man I write about is not famous. He might never be. When his life ends, he might leave no more trace than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water's surface. Then, if my book is read, it will be for its own interest. But perhaps his chosen way of life and his unique character might influence others, so that, long after his death, people might realize he was a remarkable person. Then it will be clear who I write about, and those interested in his early life might find something useful in my book. I think my book, despite its limits, will be a helpful source for my friend's biographers. I don't claim the conversations I recorded are exact. I never took notes, but I have a good memory for what matters to me, and though I put these conversations in my own words, I believe they represent what was said. I mentioned earlier that I invented nothing, but I have taken the liberty, like historians, to put words in the mouths of people in my story that I didn't hear myself. I did this to make scenes lively and realistic, which would have been dull if just recounted. I want to be read, and I think I'm justified in making my book readable. The intelligent reader will see where I used this technique and can choose to ignore it. Another reason I started this work with worry is that the people I write about are from another culture. It's hard to know people, and I don't think you can truly know anyone but your own countrymen. People are not just themselves; they are also shaped by where they were born, the homes they grew up in, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they attended, the sports they followed, and the poets they read. These things make them who they are, and you can't know them by hearsay; you can only know them if you've lived them. You can only know if you are them. Because you can't fully know people from another nation except by observation, it's hard to make them believable in a book. I have never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I have done otherwise in short stories, it's because you can treat characters more briefly. You give the reader broad hints and let them fill in the details. In this book, I don't claim my characters are as they see themselves; they are seen, like my main character, through my own eyes.

**POETRY RECITALS**

Throughout history, the world of literature often seems confusing to those experiencing it. It is only later that we can see clear patterns and recognize important figures. Today, poetry is especially complex, with many different styles and opinions about how poetry should be presented, criticized, and taught. There is a general debate between two groups: 'literary' poets, who write poems to be read on the page, and 'popular' poets, who prefer performing their poems to an audience. This division is not strict, and public poetry readings have become more common over the past twenty years. These events happen in various places, like small towns, schools, colleges, and arts festivals.

For 'pop' poets, who write their work to be performed, public readings are beneficial. Their poems are often simple and easy to understand when heard. However, on the page, their lack of depth might be more noticeable. On the other hand, poets who focus on the craft of poetry, aiming to pack deep emotion, thought, and rhythm into their work, may not be fully appreciated by an audience hearing their poems for the first time. The risk is that these poets might choose to read only their simpler works to connect quickly with the audience, which might not represent their best work.

Listening to poetry readings cannot replace reading poetry on the page, but it can be a fun and educational experience. Hearing poets read their work can help listeners understand the emphasis and rhythm intended by the poet. It is helpful if the audience can follow along with the text or is already familiar with the poems. The main reason for popular poetry recitals, sometimes mixed with music, is to make poetry enjoyable and accessible, so people see it as something for everyone, not just a select few.

**Oral History**

Historians are increasingly using oral evidence, but this method has challenges. It is unrealistic to think that someone's spoken account is a perfect reflection of past events. During an interview, both the historian and the informant influence each other. The historian chooses the person to interview and the topics to discuss. Even if the historian only listens, their presence can change how the informant remembers and talks about the past. The final account is shaped by the historian's social position and their way of understanding history, which can affect the informant. Historians must acknowledge their role in creating new evidence. However, challenges remain even when the historian is not present. The informant's memories might be influenced by other sources, like the media, or altered by nostalgia or later life experiences. Emotions and attitudes in the testimony can seem convincing but may not truly reflect the past.

**Animal Science**

Animal science has two main approaches: physiological and whole animal. Physiologists focus on how the body functions, such as how nerves and muscles work together to create behavior. The whole animal approach looks at the behavior of the entire animal and what influences it. Within this approach, psychologists and ethologists are distinguished. Psychologists usually study learning in a few species, like rats and pigeons, in labs. Ethologists study natural, unlearned behavior in animals, often in the wild. Although these fields are merging, physiologists claim their methods are more fundamental. However, understanding nerve cell functions doesn't eliminate the need to study behavior as a whole. Behavior has its own structure and must be studied at its own level. Describing a bird's nest-building by nerve cell actions is like trying to read a book with a microscope.

**The Social Sciences**

New social science students face a dual challenge: learning the content and the methods of their subject. They must understand both the knowledge in textbooks and the ways this knowledge is gathered and organized. These elements are closely linked. Since we all experience social life, social sciences might seem like common sense. However, each social science discipline goes beyond common sense, focusing on specific aspects of social life, using particular study methods, and employing its own concepts. These concepts form the 'logical basis' of the subject, allowing social scientists to surpass everyday understanding and distinguishing each discipline.

**Classical Architecture**

In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. According to the Roman architect Vitruvius, architecture involves order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. These ideas likely come from an earlier Greek source. Utility and function are not part of this definition, though Vitruvius later discusses the best forms for different structures. Initially, the focus is on architecture as an art. Classical architecture has complex origins, with a long history of simple constructions in Greece and Italy that did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. Despite their simplicity, these early forms contributed to later architectural ideas. The classical temple, though elaborate outside, is essentially a simple, single-roomed structure.

The two sisters kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the allotments, the railway line, and the gasworks, even jumping a small bridge with all four wheels off the ground, which was her only mistake. She finished her drives by the gasworks, surrounded by the smell of sulphur. Surprisingly, Chen was amused by his wife's secret driving. "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" he said. Mui thought men were strange; Chen should have been upset. Instead, he eagerly planned a trip with Lily, excited about her new skill. They chose a Monday at the start of next month, the quietest day of the week, planning to leave early and return by midday to avoid losing customers. Meanwhile, Lily practiced driving around the allotments. Despite her doubts, Mui bought a road map, getting a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen. Lily, however, felt a bit insulted by Mui's lack of trust in her navigation skills.

Within an hour of leaving home, they were looking at the English Channel. Lily drove perfectly. Even Mui, sitting in the back ready to give directions, had to admit this. On the road, Lily overtook a few slow vehicles with great skill, making Mui hold back her protests. Chen even applauded. After passing through the gasworks of a seaside town, past the lagoon with its small motorboats, they drove smoothly along the empty promenade. Lily parked in a street full of empty parking spaces. She wasn't sure about the road markings and preferred to pay a fee rather than risk being towed or fined. Maybe this caution would ease Mui's worries. On the way, Lily noticed her sister's tense face in the mirror, which she used often. It might be best not to mention worries that hadn't occurred to Mui.

Lily locked all the van doors and checked each one. "Don't worry," Chen joked. "No one will want that heap of tin." The sisters were annoyed. Lily accused Chen of being ungrateful, and Mui scolded him for being too easily fooled by appearances. Surprised, Chen took Man Kee ahead to look at the grey sea. He sat his son on the railing and held him. Man Kee was a soft, warm, and increasingly responsive child. He put his small hand, similar to Chen's, on his father's sleeve. In that moment, Chen decided to raise Man Kee his way. He would ensure his son got a good education in numbers and grew up to own many restaurants, learning all aspects of the business. The somber sea made Chen feel pleasantly thoughtful as he planned Man Kee's future. He saw a trail of smoke near the horizon and then a ship appeared, shimmering in the sunlight. There was a telescope nearby. The sparkle of the water changed Chen's mood. He put a coin in the slot and looked through the telescope. At first, he couldn't find the ship, but then he saw it: a large, rusty tramp steamer. Chen lifted Man Kee to the eyepiece. "Do you see the ship, Son?" he asked gently. "It's a special little ship for people like us. It's small and old, but we know better. It's the ship that will take us home when we're done here. It will take you to your homeland, which you've never seen." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. Lily and Mui were behind him now. Lily put her arm around Chen's shoulders. "The little old ship," Chen said. "Let your mother see, Son." Man Kee didn't want to let go of the telescope, and when he finally did, the view was gone. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship had disappeared over the horizon, and Lily only saw seagulls scavenging in the ship's wake.

**THE WELL**

I had read somewhere that if you looked up from a deep hole, you could see the stars during the day. I convinced you to help me test this idea. You watched nervously as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it on the wall, and climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn't consider how much heavier the bucket would be with me in it, or that you might not be strong enough or willing to hold on. You tried to hold the handle as I pushed the bucket off the well's edge, but I fell immediately. You screamed and tried to stop the handle, but then let go. I fell into the well and hit my head. At that moment, I didn't realize I had, in a way, achieved my goal. I saw strange, blurry lights. Later, I connected these lights to the cartoon stars and planets that appear when a character gets hit on the head. At first, I was dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall and worried about what Mother would say. You called down, asking if I was okay. I was about to shout back when you called again, sounding more panicked, which stopped me. I lay still, watching you through my eyelashes. You ran off, calling for help. I quickly climbed out of the well and hid in the shadows near the moat bridge. I heard alarmed voices from the castle. Mother and Father appeared with you and old Arthur. Mother was frantic, and Father told Arthur to use the winch. You looked pale and shocked. I felt a mix of excitement and fear. Then I noticed the trail of water drops I had left from the well to where I was hiding. I was horrified that no one had seen them. Father was shining a flashlight into the well. The drops glistened in the sunlight. I couldn't believe no one noticed. Mother was screaming, a sound I had never heard before. It shook me deeply. What should I do? I had gotten back at you, but now things were more serious than I expected. It had gone from a clever prank to something that would lead to serious punishment, likely for me. I regretted not thinking it through. From a plan to a disaster in minutes. Then an idea came to me. I gathered my courage and left my hiding place, pretending to be weak and disoriented. I cried out softly, then louder when no one heard me. I stumbled and collapsed on the cobbles. Sitting up, comforted by my weeping mother, I claimed I had found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and crawled through it. I thought I was convincing until Father asked me to repeat my story. I hesitated, and his eyes narrowed. Trying to cover my lie, I said the tunnel had collapsed after me, so there was no point in checking. I looked into my father's eyes and saw disappointment. It was like seeing the world from an adult's perspective, realizing how my story sounded. My words stopped. "Don't be ridiculous, boy," he said with contempt. He walked away. Arthur looked at me, regretful and troubled, shaking his head. He saw through my lie and worried about my character and future. His pity was as painful as my father's words, confirming their judgment of my actions. It affected me deeply.

**REMOVAL DAY**

Susan, a widow, is leaving her family home now that her children are grown. The removal van had "Removers of Distinction" written on it, and indeed, everything special about the house was being packed away. Fred, the removal man, with his large fingers, carefully handled the fragile items, while his team was less gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-storey house overlooking a small harbour. The memories of her children growing up there lingered like dust in the air. 

When they first bought the house, her son Robert, then five, had asked, "Mum, when you buy a house, how do you get it home?" Now, Robert was there helping, especially making sure Susan didn't mention the piano. Francesca, her daughter, was also helping, insisting that only she could handle the Steinway piano properly.

Fred, the removal man, noted that Susan didn't seem like she was going to cry. Susan asked if people often cried, and Fred explained that many do once everything is packed up, though they feel better at the new place. Susan could understand this feeling. She would have warned the movers about the piano, but Robert insisted it was their job to notice any issues. The piano was in the best room of the house and would be moved last.

Sitting on the bottom stair, as all the chairs were gone, Susan remembered when they first moved in. The piano had been brought in first and got stuck on the stairs. The removal men struggled for hours, and young Francesca had cried, "We can't live in a house without a piano!" Her husband Peter had solved the problem by hiring a builder to remove a window and using a crane to bring the piano in. It was an expensive process, and they couldn't afford to tune the piano for months. Peter had said, "That's there forever," but forever is a long time.

The children were now too busy to visit often, and Susan found it hard to move around the house. She thought about the stairs and the slightly crooked banister rails, a reminder of the piano's difficult arrival. She should have warned the movers, but it was too late. Fred reassured her that only the piano was left to move. Susan felt anxious as Robert and Francesca watched from the hallway.

As the piano was carefully moved down the stairs and out the door, Susan felt on the verge of tears. But when the piano was safely outside, Robert started laughing, and soon all three of them were laughing uncontrollably, relieved it was over. They walked arm in arm down the path for the last time, with Susan shedding tears of laughter.

**Online Literary Criticism for Everyone**

Is do-it-yourself literary criticism just harmless fun? From the beginning, the idea of open access to the Internet was a key principle. In theory, anyone could publish a manifesto or start a music channel online. In practice, though, some technical skills were needed, especially in the early days. However, one area that was truly opened to everyone was literary criticism. By visiting Amazon.com, the first popular online bookshop, anyone could try their hand at reviewing books. Amazon's approach to book reviews was simple: anyone could say what they liked about a book and give it up to five stars. This seemed like a brilliant idea. Each book had its own page on Amazon's site, and whenever a reader submitted a new review, it appeared automatically. This allowed Amazon to fill its pages with free reviews, and potential buyers could see what other readers thought of a book, rather than just reading the publisher's blurb or professional critics' opinions. Other online bookstores, which also had physical stores, offered similar features. But as the largest player, with over 80% of the online market, Amazon initially had the most customers, attracted the most reviews, and encountered the most issues. This open review system led to various kinds of misuse. Thousands of reviews were submitted each day, so it was impractical to check them all. Instead, a team of editors checked that reviews followed the company's guidelines. Single-word reviews, personal attacks on the author, obscenities, spoilers, or references to other reviews were not allowed. However, reviewers were anonymous and offending reviews were removed only if Amazon's editors noticed them. This allowed for some mischief. For example, writers could give their own books glowing reviews. One writer, Lev Grossman, was so upset by the bad reviews of his first novel ('infantile trash', 'puerile pap') that he submitted several positive ones himself ('hilarious', 'fabulous') to balance things out. His trick worked until he wrote an article about his deception, and the fake reviews were removed. Authors could also comment on their books by clicking a link marked 'I am the Author, and I wish to comment on my book.' Most authors used this feature to post friendly messages hoping readers would buy and enjoy their book. Some even shared their email addresses, inviting readers to contact them directly. However, Amazon did not verify that these comments really came from the authors, except for well-known writers. A little-known writer submitted a comment pretending to be from John Updike, calling himself a 'talented but ultimately over-hyped middlebrow author'. It was deemed fake and removed. The real drama came from readers, not writers. When James McElroy's "We've Got Spirit," about a small-town cheerleading team, was published, it was well-received by the mainstream press. But many people mentioned in it felt betrayed and used Amazon's page to express their anger. Dozens of critical reviews were submitted, only to disappear a few days later. Despite this, Amazon saw the fact that so many people were willing to spend time reading and writing reviews as good for business. Since readers' reviews were meant to be a 'forum to talk about a book' rather than a chat room, Amazon closely monitored bestselling books to ensure reviews followed the rules. This meant that the best place to post a silly review was on a page for a less well-known book. "The Story about Ping," a classic children's book about a duck named Ping, inspired much geek humor because 'ping' is also a term for a software tool used to measure Internet congestion. One long review made an elaborate analogy between the book's plot and Internet architecture, concluding that the book provided a 'good high-level overview' of basic networking concepts. Such silliness was rare. Most reader reviews on Amazon.com were taken seriously by their contributors. Overall, the reviews provided a remarkably accurate indication of whether or not a particular book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once complained that reviewing too many books involved inventing reactions to books about which one has no spontaneous feelings. This makes the democratization of the process seem like a good thing.

**Art in Modern Times**

In the last two hundred years, we often talk as if every artist must rebel against the art of their time. Art is admired for being unique, revolutionary, and even shocking. We like to praise artists whose work was not appreciated a hundred years ago. But when it comes to contemporary art, we hesitate and say an artist has gone too far, that what they do is no longer art. Or, more often, the media says it for us, and we agree because we expect art to be puzzling and new. We overlook the old themes, methods, and virtues present in today's art. We want artists to be different from us, with special talents and energy that break conventions. In the past, people went to artists with specific requests because art was part of everyday life. Today, we leave artists to their own ideas and get annoyed if they try to be more relatable.

**Picture This**

I will describe a situation and then ask an important question about it. I hope it doesn't seem too mysterious. But if it does, that's modern art for you. Here's the situation: An artist picks a piece of text from an art book. The text talks about the variety of pictures, asking, "What are they all about?" and then concludes, "There is no end to the number of different kinds of pictures." This sounds simple, but stay with me. The situation gets more complex. The artist asks someone to make a canvas, stretch it, and prepare it. Then, he asks a sign painter to write the chosen text on the canvas, instructing them not to make the lettering flashy or charming. The sign painter does this, writing the text in simple black letters on a white canvas. So, my important question is: Is the finished product a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery, London until 26th June

It is an unspoken rule for successful painters that once they find a profitable style, they stick to it. Collectors expect artists to continue in the same direction, and trying something new often leads to disappointment. I'm not sure why this is. Gallery owners prefer safe choices, and perhaps art buyers need the comfort of consistency. Some artists break the mold and succeed, like Picasso and Hockney. Eric Rimmington is another artist trying something new, and we will see if he succeeds. His new show moves away from the still lifes he is known for to paintings of the London Underground. Railways fascinate Rimmington. From drawings of Kings Cross Station in the 1980s, he logically moved to explore the underground world. These sketches inspired "Underground Encounters," an exhibition of 40 paintings and drawings capturing the unique charm of this underground world for people on the move.

**Extract from a Novel**

I have come to this island with a few books. I don't know why I say "escape." The villagers joke that only a sick person would choose such a remote place to rebuild. So, I am here to heal myself, if you want to put it that way. Apart from the old peasant woman who comes from the village on her mule each day to clean the house, I am alone. I am neither happy nor unhappy; I feel like a hair or a feather in the cloudy mix of memory. I spoke of the uselessness of art but didn't mention its comforts. The comfort of my work with brain and heart is that only there, in the silence of the painter or writer, can reality be reordered and show its true meaning. Our everyday actions are like a rough cloth hiding the golden pattern underneath. For us artists, art offers a joyful compromise with everything that hurt or defeated us in life; it helps us fulfill our true potential through imagination. Otherwise, why should we hurt one another?

**Family Business**

"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were driving back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from the fancy girls' school I attended. He had also just sat through Parent's Day, where I received the Latin prize and the prize for doing best in my exams. He had a long talk with my headteacher, and now we were heading home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, though I had guessed what he was thinking from his unusual silence. He was usually a talkative man. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I was told you will get a scholarship to Oxford."

"So?" I said, trying to be bold. "Mightn't that be useful?"

"I also hear," he continued, and I knew a confrontation was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.

"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"

"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can quickly understand a lot of information, you can talk well, and you enjoy performing."

"I don't know about that," I said. "All I know is what I see in TV dramas."

"Be that as it may," he continued, "I feel your heart's never going to be in the business now. Obviously, you'll go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting it."

The problem was that, like many children of family businesses, I felt trapped by family expectations. I saw other career options and wanted to explore them. At the same time, I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I found him intimidating.

"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.

"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," said my father, who was often right about such things, "and it's a pity because you've got the gifts - the brains, the nerves, the vision."

"There's still Maurice," I said, sulking. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.

"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a sort of consultant."

My mother wasn't around to help - she had died early in my childhood, and my father had raised Maurice and me. Maurice was two years younger, and because he was motherless, I got into the habit of taking care of him. It wasn't a hardship. I loved Maurice. Because the business was successful, we lived in luxury - a big house in London, posh schools, nice clothes, parties, theatres, operas. My father knew all kinds of people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was full of interesting conversations.

"I tell you what," my father continued. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you decide to leave us, you can. It will give you some pocket money and be a real help to me."

"OK," I said, relieved to avoid immediate decisions and especially the depression and sulks my father would fall into if I opposed him. This was how he controlled us.

So it happened. In my last term at school, and then during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on the safer tasks. I became one of the smarter undergraduates, with a little house of my own, a small but powerful white car, designer clothes, and a black dress with a Paris label that I planned to wear for my final exams.

In my last term, my father visited me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor predicted I would get a First Class degree (in Law), and I knew that if I stayed focused and used these last days wisely, he might be right. I felt poised, confident, concentrated.

This was not to be. My father told me that, in about a week, he needed me for one last assignment, the most important piece of business the family firm had ever attempted, and that it would be worth my while.

"But Dad," I protested, "I've got my final exams coming up, and I need to concentrate on that. It's really important that I do well, and I don't want to think about anything else right now."

I could tell that such pressures were beyond my father's imagination (or was he somehow jealous of my life away from him?) and that he would see a refusal as a betrayal in his hour of need. That was not all. As he described the procedures, I saw more clearly than ever before the single-mindedness of my father -- the clarity and resourcefulness with which he approached his work, the dynamic energy, the perfect self-control. In his way, he was a sort of genius, and I respected that in him. It made my own plans and hopes seem less important.

"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being very careful with money, which made it a bad decision. At first, it seemed like a good idea because Simon had many successful cases, and Lois had returned to her job at the advertising agency shortly after their twins were born. She even got a raise, bringing her salary to thirty-five thousand. Lois was the one who pushed for the move, arguing that their flat wasn't suitable for a family, and they needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. These needs could have been met in a less expensive area, but Lois wanted more than just space. She felt their old address wasn't suitable for a rising barrister and a successful businesswoman. 

To save money, Lois decided one of them should use public transport. Since her job was far away, Simon had to be the one to do it. The crowded tube ride made him resentful, and he often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he had stayed as a boy. His grandmother believed in giving the breadwinner peace and comfort after a long day. But times had changed. Lois made it clear before they married that her career was as important as his. Their lifestyle depended on both their salaries.

Now, their situation was threatened by Venetia, who had come to their office in a bad mood. She accused Simon of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, had bribed jurors in a case four years ago and that Cartwright had given shares to Simon's fiancÃ©e before the trial. Simon denied it, but his denial was weak, and he felt guilty. He wished he had been prepared and could have given a better response. Venetia's anger and disgust puzzled him. He wondered why she felt the need to confront him and if her own actions were always perfect. He feared that if the accusation spread, even as a rumor, his career would be over.

I chose this place to live, thinking I would be anonymous among people who didn't mind if the rented houses were falling apart or if the gardens were overgrown. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon start to recognize you. The roses next door remind me that the gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside trying to forget that it's summer, but tonight, I'm watching the swifts flying between the treetops and roofs. I've cleared some space in the garden for a chair, and my arms are scratched from the work. It's a small London garden where plants must grow tall to survive. 

My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of the window. She's written several unpublished manuscripts, and as an English teacher, I sometimes have to pretend to be interested. I have her latest one now. 'How's the work going, Jaz?' I ask. 'In no other job do you have to explain yourself so often,' she replies. Then she offers to bring a drink down. I don't want Jaz in the garden, and I realize it looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. 'You're on holiday now,' she says, sitting in the chair. 'I should've been a teacher - writers don't get holidays. They say, those who can, do, those who can't, teach.' And some can't do either. 'What plans for the holidays?' she asks. 

I feel anxious about the school year ending. Empty days. Hot pavements. The walk to the shops. The park with its fountain, and loneliness beside me on the bench. 'I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?' I ask, my heart racing. 'Of course,' Jaz says, knowing she will be around. 'Where will you stay? A nice B and B?' 'No, with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We've known each other since we were eight.' It's not true, but I often deal with fiction. 'Going back to your roots. What do you think of my manuscript?' Jaz asks about her work, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which is half-read on my desk. I like the title and tell her so. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing gifts to other houses and rejection letters to hers. I decide to be honest. 'Try writing about nice people for a change, people who try to be good,' I suggest. 'Teachers!' Jaz responds like a rebellious student. 'I keep a journal where I write something good about each day,' I say. 'Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.' 

Oh, I've got a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes, reading on the tube. When we go inside, my calm kitchen reassures me. Then I remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age, winking as she said, 'I've had my moments.' We nearly died laughing.

**Heritage**

Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to the past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage, knowing about our grandparents and their lives. Beyond personal stories, there is a broader need to learn about our past to understand our future, both individually and nationally. Heritage gives us a sense of continuity, helping us find our place in history. Just as we inherit genes, we inherit culture passed down through generations. Even if there are parts of our national heritage we don't like, it is still ours, and it is comforting to belong to something. Heritage teaches us a lot and is essential for our well-being, influencing everything from customs to material culture. Traditionally, we connected with the past through stories from our ancestors. However, Western industrial society disrupted communities, causing much of this oral tradition to be lost. Now, places and buildings provide clues to our past. It is crucial to preserve these links as a testament to our ancestors' identity.

**The Fens**

I started a novel, "Waterland," where the landscape of the Fens in England became important. People often ask why I, a Londoner with no personal connection, chose to write about the Fens. The short answer is that I chose them for their apparent simplicityâ€”a flat and empty stage for my story. However, I learned that the Fens are neither flat nor empty. They are as richly English as any other part of England but also strangely unique. It's remarkable that in the middle of England, the Fens feel foreign to many English people, even when other distinct areas of Britain have become part of the nation's cultural heritage. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated yet wild, open yet mysterious. My research for the novel wasn't extensive; I haven't visited places like Wisbech or Prickwillow. As a fiction writer, I prefer imagining worlds and making inspired guesses rather than seeking documentary proof. Imagining the Fens has its logic because, as Edward Storey's book shows, the Fens are not just a landscape but a state of mind.

**Museums**

Museums must make their collections accessible. In the past, this meant putting items in display cases with long labels that were hard to understand. Today, accessibility means more. Displays should be lively and interesting, using theatrical or architectural techniques to capture visitors' attention and evoke emotions. Museums should do more than just display items. They should make collections accessible to the widest community. For example, they can provide loan boxes of objects for teachers or use similar materials to help elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on real artefacts and specimens, not replicas. They offer encounters with authentic items that existed and had meaning in history. This is their strength, setting them apart from heritage centres, theme parks, books, and digital media. Museums that embrace this challenge and offer exciting displays, catalogues, and outreach programs will find that virtual history can be an ally, creating a desire for the real experiences that only museums can provide.

**Architecture and Environment**

The desire to preserve things is not new, but changes in our towns happen so quickly and on such a large scale that most of us are affected. This turns some people into strong preservationists and makes others think more about the nature and future of towns. It can be argued that generations who lived through events like world wars are more inclined to preserve things than those before themâ€”anything that expresses stability becomes important. If there is a psychological need for preservation, planners should consider it. Change is not an enemy if we learn to manage it. Physical changes in our towns reflect social changes, such as changes in population, welfare, and demands.

**Einstein**

If you ask someone to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His face is often used to sell products that are linked to intelligence, like computers and encyclopedias. Most people don't know much about what Einstein did, except that he created theories called 'relativity'. These theories are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that seem to go against everyday experiences. Einstein was part of a big change in scientific thinking, which started modern science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to describe the universe in a new way by studying how matter and natural forces interact. Einstein made important contributions by rethinking the basics: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, scientists followed Isaac Newton's idea that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, saying that time and space are not fixed but relative.

**Young Readers**

When we were children, Lydia and I didn't trust books that won prizes because we thought they would be 'worthy', which to us meant 'boring'. Our mother didn't like our attitude and would hint at her disapproval, but our father would happily give us small amounts of money to encourage us to read these books. He would also sneak in a few better-quality books among our Christmas and birthday gifts, marking them with 'This Book is NOT Literature'. Although we ignored most of his choices as 'boys' books', he did manage to introduce us to some good short stories and, once, a famous collection of poems.

**Language**

In 1851, Jacob Grimm wrote that 'The origin of human language is truly secret and marvellous'. This mysterious origin has led to many strange ideas. In 1928, Charles Caller claimed that early humans might have made sounds like "meuh" when they felt danger. "Meuh" sounds sad. Humans in dangerous lands with scary animals made desperate noises, and languages have kept some of these sounds, like 'malaria' meaning "fever" or the Latin 'mors' meaning "death". Because of such odd ideas, many people avoided the topic, thinking it was for eccentric thinkers. However, recently, the origin and evolution of language have become important research areas. Language likely developed in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly communication and was important in power struggles. Sharing information was probably not its original purpose, contrary to philosopher John Locke's idea of language as a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

Text: 'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode explores the art of writing reviews from a writer's perspective. Most reviews are created and shared under conditions that make them have a very short lifespan. There are deadlines and strict limits on their length. Once published, they last only as long as the newspaper or magazine they appear inâ€”maybe a day, a week, or at most a month. The temporary nature of reviews often defines their literary value. Many people, including the writers themselves, often think that reviewing is a task done out of necessity, like needing extra money, or because they can't spend all day working on a novel or a serious book. However, reviewing is a skilled and complex job. It's one thing to be concise and fair in a short newspaper review, and quite another to maintain a strong argument in a longer piece for international journals. The fifteen hundred words of a leading article in weekly magazines present challenges of both short and long reviews. Length isn't the only factor. Reviewers must consider their audience, from casual weekend readers to those deeply interested in the subject. A reviewer needs to know a lot about many topics and must write in a way that intelligent readers can understand and enjoy. This often means the reviewer also writes other things besides reviews. The American novelist John Updike, who views criticism as 'hugging the shore,' still enjoys writing reviews between his major novels. He collects all his reviews, even the short ones, into books with modest titles. While some might think lesser-known writers should accept the temporary nature of their work, it's understandable if they want some permanence, especially if they believe their best writing is in reviews. I feel this way about my own work. My main job has been academic, and most of my serious books are academic, the kind professors are expected to write. In the English-speaking world, unlike other cultures, there isn't a strict separation between reviewing and literary study, so it's common for the same people to do both. The days are gone when academics criticized professors for writing reviews, or for wasting time, or for not respecting their institutions. Complaints from non-professors that professors are taking their opportunities are also less common, partly because there is more reviewing work available now, and partly because the rewards are often small. I believe these arrangements benefit both readers, who can trust the reviewer knows the subject, and professors, as it helps them stay grounded. It also reminds them to communicate clearly with non-professors. When talking among themselves, they might use complex language, but when addressing intelligent non-professors, they need to be clear. Ultimately, reviewing is a secondary occupation. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and, as he entered the dark, still hallway, felt a brief unease about owning it. Even after three years, this feeling sometimes came over him when he returned alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he would come home eagerly, often as early as possible, wondering what the flat had been like while he was away. It felt like a welcoming place to him, where he was in control. He thought he should worry about intruders or leaks, but the flat always seemed to be waiting for him, either tidy or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he began to see it as just another part of himself, a space filled with his thoughts and feelings. He became frustrated with its inability to change. Sometimes, there would be a small pile of letters by the door or the answering machine would be blinking with messages. He was thankful that the windows hadn't been broken or the contents disturbed, though he wondered what it would look like if that happened. From his dull third-floor office on Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to his three or four quiet evenings at home each week. Once he left the artificial world of the office and felt himself returning on the bus ride home, he no longer needed to be alone, a fact he often forgot when planning his social life. At his desk, he would long for solitude, time alone with his belongings, but once home, he felt empty, waiting for a sense of self to return. Instead, he felt a deep emptiness, making him suspect that doing work he didn't enjoy had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was. He would often read or listen to music as the night went on, but now he questioned why he did these things. His sense of direction was unclear, and ideas would come and go, unable to connect. There was a time, he thought, when he didn't feel this powerless, when he might have escaped if he had realized his own worth. But he had been eager to settle for something and followed the first path that seemed right. After university, he tried to make a plan for his future, but he wasn't surprised to find he only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs he heard about from friends, following their paths without imagining he could find happiness in his work. He attended his only job interview gratefully and didn't think to question the positionâ€”a vague editorial role at a free local newspaper. He was relieved to have a pleasant conversation with Neil, his boss, and didn't consider the long meetings he now faced daily. Neil offered him the job immediately, saying Ralph was the only graduate who applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**

I was about to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I pushed through ice-cream vans, crowds of people, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was moving towards the racecourse, and I tried to find a good spot. A section was marked off for the race. It wasn't like big racecourses, but people stood on both sides of the track where the goats would run. They were trying to keep a few special goats in order, which is hard because goats are known to eat almost anything.

**Canoe Trip**

As the day ended, I started to worry about the night. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and there was nowhere to stop. We hadn't seen any villages or huts since morning. In the dim moonlight, with our torch, we could barely see the cliffs. The torch batteries were dying, so we put in new ones, but they didn't work. We realized we wouldn't find a camping spot. A few miles later, Lesley shouted that she saw a flickering light, and we got hopeful. But it was just moonlight on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud noise of fast water, but we couldn't see what was happening. Time seemed to stop as we continued.

**How to be Presentation Perfect - we answer your questions**

I am not naturally good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I often have to present to my colleagues and major shareholders. How can I improve my presentation skills and confidence? 

You are not alone. Presenting requires different skills than running a company, but many senior executives need to be good at it. To convince your audience, you must believe in what you are saying. Show your belief with passion and enthusiasm. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas in advance. Ask colleagues to think of the tough questions your audience might ask. Also, create a positive atmosphere from the start. Begin with something everyone agrees on and slowly build to your main point.

Some activities cannot be rushed; they need their own time. If you're late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you rush making mayonnaise by adding oil too quickly, it will curdle. If you pull too hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will tighten. The mind also works at different speeds. Some tasks are done very quickly, while others take longerâ€”seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. Some mental tasks can be sped up, like solving puzzles or doing math in your head. But others cannot be rushed, or they will fail, like the mayonnaise, or become more complicated, like the fishing line. Saying 'Think fast; we need the results' can be as unwise as trying to sleep in half the time. We learn, think, and understand in different ways, and these mental processes work at different speeds, suitable for different tasks. 'He who hesitates is lost,' says one proverb. 'Look before you leap,' says another. Both are true. Generally, the mind has three processing speeds. The first is faster than thought. Some situations need an immediate, instinctive reaction. When my motorbike skidded on a wet road in London, my brain and body quickly reacted to keep me safe, and only afterward did my conscious mind catch up. A concert pianist or an Olympic fencer doesn't have time to think about their next move. This fast physical intelligence can be called our 'wits'. Then there is thought itself: the kind of intelligence that involves reasoning, weighing options, building arguments, and solving problems. A mechanic figuring out why an engine won't start, a scientist interpreting an experiment, or a student working on an assignment all use this type of intelligence, which relies on reason and logic. We often call this 'intellect'. Someone good at these tasks is called 'bright' or 'clever'. But there is another, slower mental process. It is often less focused, more playful, or dreamy. In this mode, we are thinking deeply or being contemplative. Sitting by the sea, lost in the sound of the waves, or just before sleep, we are in a different mental state than when planning a meal or writing a letter. This slow, seemingly aimless way of thinking is just as intelligent as the faster ones. Allowing the mind to wander is not a luxury to cut back on when life gets busy. On the contrary, slow thinking is an important part of our mental abilities. We need the slow mind as much as the fast one. Some problems are better solved with a slow mind. Some mysteries can only be understood with a relaxed, open mental attitude. Recent studies show that slower, less deliberate thinking is good for understanding complex or unclear situations. Deliberate thinking works well when the problem is clear. When deciding where to go on holiday, the options may be obvious. But when we don't know what to consider or which questions to ask, or when the issue is too subtle for conscious thought, we need the slow mind. If the problem is how to manage a difficult team at work, or whether to change careers, it might be better to sit and think than to search frantically for answers. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity or even 'wisdom'. Poets have long known the limits of conscious thinking and have tried to develop these slower ways of knowing. Philosophers have written about the parts of the mind beyond conscious thought. Only recently have scientists begun to study these slower ways of knowing. The field of 'cognitive science' is showing that the unconscious mind can do many interesting and important tasks if given time. It can learn patterns too subtle for normal consciousness, understand complex situations, and solve difficult problems better than the conscious mind.

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**

I have been warmly welcomed. It's a friendly and well-equipped base camp in a very isolated place. At any time, there are about forty people - scientists, students, weathermen, satellite trackers - in a close community where everyone helps out. My basic French is just enough to communicate, but not to have casual conversations. I miss the subtle meanings, and my phrasebook is useless at breakfast. This isn't a practical problem for me, but at first, it affected my self-confidence. I found myself slightly dreading mealtimes. I would hesitate, worried about which table to choose, scared of the silence when I spoke, anxious like I hadn't been since my first weeks of school. I still smile awkwardly or panic when people talk to me. I think the reason for this occasional sadness isn't about losing company or communication; it's because I've lost the social advantage that my ability to talk has always given me.

**Elliot**

When I first met Elliot, I was just a young author like any other, and he didn't pay much attention to me. He never forgot a face though, and when I saw him here or there, he shook hands with me politely but didn't try to get to know me better. If I saw him at the opera, for example, and he was with someone important, he tended not to notice me. But then I had a surprising success as a playwright, and soon I noticed that Elliot was more interested in me. One day, I got a note from him inviting me to lunch, and I thought he was testing me. But after that, since my success brought me many new friends, I started to see him more often.

**Alfred Hitchcock**

The film director Alfred Hitchcock always said he didn't care about the subject of his films or the acting, but he did care about the photography, the soundtrack, and all the technical parts. For Hitchcock, it wasn't a message or a great performance that moved the audience; he believed people are excited by pure film, no matter their cultural background. So, if a film is made correctly, in terms of its emotional impact, the Japanese audience should scream at the same moment as the Indian audience. Hitchcock's view of himself was always clear, logical, and hard to argue with. He was a man of reason and a genius craftsman who liked to hear an audience scream. He didn't deal with speculation, abstract ideas, or intellectual hints, and his view of his own screen characters was not deep. He focused on film, pure film, and the most precise, calculated beauty of what a strip of film can do to an audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**

Astronomy has changed a lot in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts or catalogues. Telescopes were basic, and there were few books on how to do astronomy. Today, you can buy many types of telescopes and equipment. Electronic calculators and computers have changed how we make charts and analyze observations. This might be the best time for amateur astronomy. However, some things have been lost. Now, you might need to travel 80 km to find a sky as clear as it was in cities 50 years ago. During the day, airplane trails can last for hours and turn into clouds, making it hard to observe the sun and stars.

**Too Much Choice**

Society now has too many choices. There are too many things to do and too many options. In today's economy, people always want the newest product or service, and technology makes changes happen faster. New products come out quickly, making it hard to keep up. This can cause stress and make life feel disconnected. More choices mean more stress and less time. People are now looking for 'simplexity'â€”simple things that bring meaning in a complex world. But simplifying life is hard when there are so many products and services. There are more types of detergent and breakfast cereals than we need, and more software updates and phone plans than we can manage.

**McAndrews Hotel**

Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. This is a family tradition started by my grandmother, and it has become very important to us. We do not let anything disturb this ritual. The guests at McAndrews are similar: old-fashioned and maybe a bit snobbish. I do not like the rude behavior of shop assistants today, which is seen as being equal. I dislike overly friendly waiters who seem like they might pat you on the back. I know most of the other guests' names because they have been coming here since they were children, like me. But I can be sure that when I see them in the hotel, we will only exchange polite greetings. Such respect for privacy is rare in hotels today.

**Othello**

The move of an outstanding production of Shakespeare's play "Othello" from Stratford to London gives me a chance to correct a harsh review I wrote when the show first opened last spring. At that time, I said Ray Fearon was too young for the main role and criticized his acting. I still believe that changing the age difference between Othello and Desdemona alters the tragedy, but I take back my negative comments about Mr. Fearon's excellent performance. In fact, the entire cast is excellent. Memorable scenes include Cassio's competitive games with other young officers, which become dangerously intense, and the moment when Iago starts to lose control and struggles to regain it. I dare anyone not to be moved to tears during the scene where Emilia prepares Desdemona for bed. The pace and tension throughout the play are fantastic. Don't miss this production.

**Lake Vostok**

In the center of Antarctica, nothing moves. On the edges of the continent, there are many penguins, seals, and birds. But on the large white plateau inside, life cannot survive. Except, that is, in a huge hidden area of freshwater called Lake Vostok, which is under nearly 4 kilometers of ice, right below the coldest place on earth.
