I initially fed them with a syringe, wiping them with a warm cloth first to mimic their mother's licking, which helped them relieve themselves. For the first few days, they were fed every four hours. Within a week, they were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though shakily. They seemed content with each other for company and a heated pad as a substitute "mum."

Three weeks later, I noticed Willow was lethargic, though he was still eating. It was a warning sign I missed, and the next morning, I found him dead. A vet's post-mortem revealed he died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding, it's important not to let an animal drink too fast, as liquid can enter the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that was hard to treat, even with antibiotics. Disheartened, I continued caring for the others. Six days later, a local farmer brought me another male cub, abandoned by its mother. He was cold and hungry, and the farmer knew she wouldn't return. Willow II joined us. At six weeks, he was about two weeks younger than the females. I soon discovered why his mother left him. He was difficult to feed, and I had to move the bottle's teat around and squeeze it to get him to drink. After 10 minutes, he would finally latch on. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and then anything. Willow was different. He gave up the bottle but couldn't eat without walking through his food or sitting in it. Eventually, I offered him a sausage, which he slowly ate. After a week of sausages, he was ready for other foods.

At nearly five months old, they were eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat 60% earthworms, plus beetles, bugs, baby rabbits, mice, voles, and plant shoots or roots. My badgers were better off than others that year; the summer was very hot, making it hard to dig for earthworms. By August, my badgers became nocturnal, going for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where they played and chased each other's tails. As "human badgers," we joined in. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, didn't and sometimes got bruised. During these walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely extending their territories to find food, as badgers are territorial and can kill intruders. We were warned they might enter our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we covered the gate with sheet metal. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and the response led us to start an appeal to build a sett on the farm. With advice, we designed a new home for the badgers. Our son Daniel drew up the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate facing their usual walk direction. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side for viewing from a darkened enclosure. As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they forgot the walks, excited by the tunnels and bedding. The building cost more than expected, but a local bus company, Badgerline, sponsored part of the appeal, and local firms donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers with a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I returned to find them asleep in their chambers. These days, I don't walk with them as often, especially since they're awake at midnight. We see Primrose occasionally, as she's joined a neighboring sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still greet us before heading off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they've accepted.

**In search of true north - and the man behind Halley's comet**

Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, plans to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to map compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his major achievements was mapping the 'variations of the compass' during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', refer to the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without understanding declination, sailors couldn't accurately correct their compasses, making it difficult to determine longitude and navigate the seas. 

Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at the time, set out for the Cape Verde Islands to map declination in the North and South Atlantic. His first trip was cut short due to crew issues, but he tried again. This second voyage took him to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From these travels, Halley published a 'New and Correct Chart showing the Variations of the Compass in the Western and Southern Oceans' in 1701. This chart and its successors were crucial for sailors for over a century until changes in Earth's magnetic field made them outdated.

Dr. Clark, an enthusiastic sailor, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's journey by retracing the Paramore's route. He needs to raise Â£70,000 for the trip, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, known for leading the first cross-Antarctica expedition, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley during a two-year stay at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about the scientist's life. 'Halley led a remarkable life,' says Dr. Clark. 'He was a respected scientist and explorer, not just an astronomer but also a geophysicist. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped stars and also developed a diving bell and advised Sir Isaac Newton on his Principia Mathematica.'

Dr. Clark believes recreating the voyage will give Halley the recognition he deserves. The expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve taking the same measurements Halley did, but with more accurate instruments. These measurements are important because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data collected will help improve the international geomagnetic reference field, a model of Earth's magnetic field. 'It's common to measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field. You need to know true north to measure direction,' says Dr. Clark. 'We can use global positioning satellites for that on our expedition.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments, and a Danish satellite will be taking similar measurements globally. Dr. Clark hopes his measurements will fill any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean and provide useful ground-based comparisons.

Halley's Atlantic journey was significant as it was the first dedicated scientific sea expedition, and Halley was the first civilian appointed as a naval captain for this purpose. Does Dr. Clark have the qualifications to succeed in his voyage? Besides his two years in Antarctica and work with the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey, he has already sailed 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews. Does he share Halley's passion? 'I'm willing to dedicate eight months of my life to this, so some might say I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't cross the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose.'

**POWER DRESSING**

Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peahens. This display raises a question that puzzled Charles Darwin: in a world where survival is tough, how did such extravagant features evolve? Darwin believed that evolution happened through natural selection, where the fittest survive. However, the peacock's tail seemed to be a disadvantage, so he proposed another idea called 'sexual selection'. He suggested that females might choose mates based on beauty alone.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He thought that if peahens chose the most attractive males, there must be a reason beyond just beauty. He believed the tail was a sign of some other survival advantage. Today, this debate continues, as studying peafowl behavior is challenging. However, the 200 peacocks at Whipsnade, who live like wild birds but are used to humans, provide a unique chance to study this.

Marion Petrie and her team at Whipsnade are exploring two main questions. First, do peahens really prefer males with the most impressive tails? Second, do these males have other advantages, as Wallace suggested, or is it just about looks, as Darwin thought? Observations show that peahens do prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails, which are linked to tail length. These males attract more mates. However, whether these males are better in other ways is still unclear.

William Hamilton from Oxford University suggested that showy male birds might be healthier and free of parasites, and their plumage shows this. There is evidence for this in other birds, but Petrie and her team haven't been able to test this in Whipsnade peacocks. This year, they are comparing the offspring of attractive and less attractive males to see if the former grow faster or are healthier. If so, it would support Wallace's idea that female choice is practical.

Finally, R.A. Fisher, a mathematician and biologist, proposed 'Fisher's Runaway' in the 1930s. He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their sons will inherit the tail, and daughters will inherit the preference for long tails. This cycle could lead to increasingly extravagant tails. Modern computer models show this could explain the peacock's tail, supporting Darwin's idea of 'beauty for beauty's sake' once the process starts.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He applied this in his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of impressive yachts with the latest technology. Most of these yachts are based on design changes from 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly moored on a tidal creek on the south coast. Although designed last year, she looks like she could be 100 years old, which might make people think I'm a romantic dreamer. Maybe I am, but I doubt it. This boat benefits from traditional boat design, but modern technology made the job easier. However, while modern technology is essential in boat design and building today, it often shields crews from the real challenges of sea life. These challenges are often what sailors want to experience when they go to sea. I'm not saying sailors should suffer unnecessarily. I always make sure my boats have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable sleeping areas. But why go sailing if every sail operates automatically? Sometimes, dealing with sails is part of a sailor's life. And why should we move steering positions from the safe back of the boat to a risky spot halfway to the front? Sadly, this is done to create a cabin like an ocean liner, with a bed bigger than the one at home. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a floating cottage. When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, which I used to sail around Britain for a TV race series, the former owner said she had every comfort but no luxury. During my time with her, I learned how right he was. Her sails were heavy, and she had no pumped water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the kindest, easiest boat I have ever sailed. However, classic boats need a lot of care. After a back injury, I realized my 15-year relationship with her had to end. I couldn't find a suitable younger boat, so I decided to build a new one from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett are skilled with computer design, Irens first sketched this boat on a paper napkin and later used the computer. After creating a design, he carved a model, just like in the old days. We reviewed the model and then adjusted the design on the computer. The final version was perfect. The finished boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She looks timeless, moves beautifully at sea, and her interior, made from reclaimed pitch pine, feels peaceful. This is because she was designed purely as a sailing boat, without focusing on furniture. This traditional method works well. She shows that you don't need to follow trends to be satisfied and that history can teach valuable lessons. Built with wood treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. She has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a traditional one.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are seeing a rise in business. We asked five journalists to review some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**

I was excited to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I needed to relax. My room in the large 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm immediately. On the first day, I rested and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined body conditioning classes like stretch and tone, yoga, and body alignment. The instructors are very skilled, and I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, such as aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The hour-long facial made me feel renewed. The staff were friendly and professional, creating an energetic and enthusiastic atmosphere. Henlow plans to renovate this year, adding a half-size Olympic pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you prefer to relax, you can read a magazine or walk in the garden. During my stay, my mood and appetite improved. I left feeling energized, and I plan to return. This is a perfect break for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**

The calm atmosphere of this stately home was clear as soon as I entered the reception area. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a charming conservatory, and plenty of space, so you can enjoy solitude if you wish. Upon arrival, everyone receives a medical check-up, including weight and blood pressure. We were called patients, which felt strange since I am healthy. However, a shoulder issue found during the check-up was quickly addressed by the fitness instructor in group workshops and individual sessions. Each person follows a specific diet. I lost weight without fasting but had a headache on the second day from hunger. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and exotic fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for supper. If not fasting, you eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty and well-presented. You receive a massage or water therapy every other day, and extra treatments are reasonably priced. - Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**

Careys is not a health farm and doesn't claim to be. It's a lovely old manor with cozy log fires and a spacious lounge. If you're watching your calories, you might skip the gourmet food. The French chef creates rich sauces and creamy desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a gym and a soft-water pool to burn off the indulgences. You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you want to lose weight. There is a spa bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A highlight is the sports injury clinic, where I received expert advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, the surrounding countryside is beautiful. - Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**

Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. The 376-acre National Trust estate has beautiful woodland walks and gardens. Waldo's, a renowned restaurant, offers a menu that is hard to resist. The meal was excellent, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed happy! The next morning, I spent time in the gym to burn calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden offers fitness assessments, workouts, and beauty treatments if you want themâ€”before enjoying a meal at Waldo's. - Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**

The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It's the best because it's delicious, but the worst because it's 360 calories, which isn't ideal if you're trying to lose weight. You've been warned! The second best thing is the wonderful aromatherapy massage. I chose relaxing oils, fell asleep twice during the massage, and had a refreshing night's sleep. The modern, purpose-built premises are efficiently run, with up-to-date facilities and luxurious bedrooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, so scheduling appointments is easy. They offer a variety of treatments, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. Guests include football teams, mothers and daughters, best friends, and singles. Ideally, I would visit here once a month. - Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans split from chimpanzees, we haven't changed much genetically; we're still over 98% identical to chimps. On an evolutionary scale, what makes humans different from animals is a recent development. Our ability to create art and other uniquely human traits must come from a small part of our genes. This means that the differences between us and animals are mostly small. For example, both humans and animals use tools: chimpanzees use sticks, and sea otters use rocks. Monkeys have simple language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings show that there are few absolute differences between us and animals, except for art.

If human art comes from a unique genetic trait, it's interesting that our ancestors didn't create art for most of the time since they diverged from chimps. Early art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these don't last over time. Clear evidence of human art appears with the Cro-Magnons around 35,000 years ago, with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.

If we say our recent creativity sets us apart, how is our art different from animal creations? Three main differences are often suggested: human art is non-utilitarian, made for aesthetic pleasure, and learned rather than instinctive.

First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." Human art doesn't help us survive or reproduce, unlike most animal behaviors. While human art communicates ideas, it doesn't pass on genes. Birdsong, for example, helps defend territory or attract mates, directly aiding gene transmission. By this measure, human art is different.

The second claim is that only human art is motivated by aesthetic pleasure. We can't ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during breeding season, suggesting it's not just for pleasure. Again, human art seems unique here.

The third distinction is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Different human groups have distinct art styles that are learned, not genetically inherited. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. Some birds, however, inherit their species' song and would sing it even without hearing it. It's like a French baby raised in Japan spontaneously singing the French national anthem.

The role of learning in human art is also seen in how quickly styles change. Geese honked 2,000 years ago as they do today, but human art evolves rapidly. Even casual museum-goers can tell a 20th-century painting from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often identify when and who painted a work. However, they might mistake the works of two mid-20th-century artists, Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo created up to 33 pieces in a day and was upset when his pencil was taken away. Their paintings were shown in a 1957 exhibition in London, and most were sold, a success many human artists can't claim.

These ape paintings blur the lines between human art and animal activities. Like human art, they had no utilitarian purpose and were made for the artist's satisfaction. You might argue that human art is different because it's meant to communicate, while the apes didn't care about sharing their work. But even some famous human art was created for the artist's personal satisfaction.

**An Exciting Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on earth. It is also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the tale. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to be about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes narrowed from looking into the distance on their journeys into the unknown. These days, you rarely find such people in stories, let alone in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's great adventure was leading an expedition across the Taklamakan Desert in western China. Its name means 'once entered you never come out', but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey, in the calm atmosphere of his family home. The team he led included four Britons (one of them the group's medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts on the area, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It later turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have cost everyone their lives and certainly put the expedition's success at risk.

This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the world's least hospitable desert, and Charles Blackmore has written a fascinating account of their journey. At the time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, to prove something. 'I had always thought I'd spend my whole life in the Army. I had been offered a promotion, but suddenly I felt I wanted to see who Charles Blackmore really was, outside all that. It was a huge risk. Tina, my wife, was very worried that I wouldn't come back as nobody had ever done that route; we went into it blind. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very kind to us.'

Anyone reading his extraordinary account of that crossing will wonder at the use of the word 'kind'. The team suffered terrible hardships: dysentery, extreme temperatures, severe thirst and dehydration, and the loss of part of their precious water supply. 'But', Blackmore explains, 'when we were at the limits of our endurance and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we managed to find some. We didn't experience the Taklamakan's legendary sandstorms. And we never faced the raw, biting desert cold that would have totally stopped us. That's not to say that we weren't fighting against challenges the whole time. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were torture to climb, for us and for the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us.

'What drove me on more than anything else was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Neither our budget nor time allowed one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we got into the sandhills, we were completely on our own. 'I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared of my physical ability to do it. I remember day one -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We've got to do it now!" At that moment, I was a very scared man.'

If it was like that at the beginning, how did they feel towards the end? 'When you've walked for 1,000 kilometers, you're not going to give up. You've endured so much; you've got so much behind you. We were very thin, but very muscular and strong despite our physical exhaustion. My body was well-toned, and my legs were like pistons. I could walk over anything.'

Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon, thinking of his family. How aware was he of the ordeal it must have been for them? 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace with himself. When I have doubts about myself now, I go back to the image of the desert and think, well, we managed to pull that together. As a personal achievement, I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I've done. Yet in terms of a lifetime's achievement, I think of my family and the happiness we share -- against that measure, the desert does not compare.'

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I yearn for the challenge -- for the open spaces -- the resolve of it all. We were lifted by the sense of purpose. I find it difficult now to be part of the uniformity of modern life.'

Life was becoming overwhelming for Susan Harr, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and rediscover the joys of doing things by hand. Everyone loves technology because it gives us amazing gadgets that make life easier and give us more free time. However, we've been subtly convinced that technology is essential, and that's okay. But is it really? Using my hands doesn't consume energy like our gadgets do, and it doesn't harm the environment. A recent bad experience with my broken word processor, which cost me a lot to fix, made me question if gadgets are worth the trouble and expense. Are we as dependent on technology as we think?

Gradually, I've been letting household gadgets go as they break down. This makes me wonder what "time" technology really gives us. Is it just more time to buy more gadgets? If so, marketing experts have tricked us. When my gadget started making strange noises, even when unplugged, I left it in the backyard, where it now sits like a ghost. I'm no longer tied to a noisy machine, and I can take my time with my sewing. I was always a bit scared of those electric machines that rush towards your fingers. Best of all, I can take my sewing anywhere in a bag.

Of course, there are some gadgets I wouldn't want to live without. A year without a washing machine showed me how valuable it is. But losing other gadgets has been surprisingly nice. We were spending too much time in front of the TV, so I returned the rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. It's hard on the eyes but makes us focus on what's worth watching. Now, we spend more time walking the dog, reading, talking, or doing other hobbies. One of my hobbies is sewing, and I no longer use my old sewing machine, which is now a plant stand. I can't afford a new one, so I sew by hand.

We've come to believe we can't live without technology, and even if we resist the idea that our lives would be unmanageable without it, we don't want to give it up. We feel sorry for past generations who had to do hard, tiring work. Even our brains are relieved by computers that do fast calculations and provide entertainment. But the time I spend sewing by hand is not boring, and there are many benefits. I can sew and listen to the radio or talk with family and friends. If it's a simple task, I can watch TV and feel less guilty about sitting in front of it because I'm doing something useful. It's a cozy feeling to sit by the fire and sew with a pot of tea.

I used to think sewing by hand was horrible, imagining long hours and eye strain. But there's something soothing about it, and it's satisfying to see my work improve. Things get done quickly, and life slows down to the pace of my hands. I'm free from the rush of modern life, where we hurry from one task to the next. I've also regained control of my sink, where I enjoy washing dishes and daydreaming. Now, I look around the house and wonder if we really need the freezer, microwave, or lawnmower. We could save a lot of money by doing without electric lights!

Charles Hurst, a cabinet-maker, earns his living by creating beautifully crafted furniture. When I meet him at his workshop in East London, he seems to be in a hurry. He greets me with a quick handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" It's not clear if his abrupt manner is genuine or if he's just shy. His workshop is busy, filled with half-made furniture and planks of wood in various natural colors. Hurst has been in this business for ten years and has a great reputation. His order book is always full months in advance, even though he doesn't advertise. People know that if they want a well-made cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen unit, Hurst is the person to go to.

Finding a furniture-maker isn't difficult, but finding one who focuses on clean, simple lines is rare. Hurst is disappointed by some modern furniture and criticizes mass-produced, low-quality pieces. His quest for perfection and his talent are key to his success. Hurst is confident in his abilities, saying, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He is self-taught and learned his craft by asking the right questions.

Most of his work comes from private clients, and some return repeatedly. He finds it satisfying to furnish entire homes. However, he admits that not all client relationships are smooth. He prefers clients who know what they want. Hurst is also willing to praise others when deserved, acknowledging that some are better than him. He criticizes craftsmen who take too long to make a single piece and dislikes degree shows where students try to make fashion statements. For Hurst, furniture should be practical and usable.

Despite his confidence, Hurst is not pretentious. As I leave, he shows humility, saying, "After all, I am only making furniture."

Text: 'Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. It seems clear, then, that sleep has an important role. However, what that role is remains uncertain. Scientists do not fully agree on why we spend so much time sleeping. There are three main theories. The most popular theory suggests that sleep is mainly for physical health. It says we sleep to keep our bodies healthy. In other words, while we sleep, our bodies repair any damage from the day and restore us to full strength. Another theory focuses on the learning benefits of sleep. This theory suggests that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day, and without sleep, learning would not happen. A third theory is about energy, suggesting that we need sleep to recharge our energy for the next day.'

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and who does not follow the accepted norms of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most of us have our own quirks and oddities. It could be a love for entering newspaper competitions, a habit of collecting beer mats, or a tendency to write letters to the press about various topics. Eccentricity is about expressing our individuality. Inside us, there is a constant conflict between wanting to be unique and wanting to fit in. It's like having two trains on the same track, one called individualism and the other conformity. For most people, conformity is stronger. We want to be accepted, loved, and feel connected with others more than we want to stand out and be different.

People with unusual hobbies, strong opinions, or unconventional behavior often gather together. They form clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to share their interests or problems. The key word here is 'common'. They seek others who share what is usually seen as odd by family, friends, and neighbors. Being part of a group, even a small one, is comforting.

We all feel a tension between individualism and conformity. While most of us follow the crowd, we don't like to admit it. We feel the need to show our individuality, like when someone at a bar says, "I say what I think," or when a new acquaintance says, "You must take me as you find me. I don't stand on ceremony."

At any time, we can choose to emphasize our individuality. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, the American singer, said, "When you feel in your gut what you are doing and then dynamically pursue it - don't back down and don't give up - then you're going to mystify a lot of folk." But this self-conscious assertion of individuality is not eccentricity, at least not at first. When a pop singer wears strange clothes for publicity, or a society hostess makes shocking comments to get noticed, that is not eccentricity. However, if they continue these actions until they become a natural part of who they are, then they might be considered eccentric.

The key aspect of eccentricity is its naturalness. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are. A true eccentric is not concerned with public opinion; they are barely aware of it. They do what they do because of who they are. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, brilliant criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses. These people are very aware of the world around them and often act in response to it. Some want to make an impression on society, while others want to escape from it, but all are conscious of society. The eccentric, however, continues on their path regardless.

**Natural Books: Influential Wildlife Classics**

We asked four leading naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**

Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I've met many pioneers in the field, but none impressed me more than Barbara Ward. She was central to environmental issues in post-war Europe and developed a compelling philosophy from her experiences. As a young journalist, her work made everything clear to me. Picking the book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet," but "The Home of Man" stands out. Despite its old-fashioned title, it focuses on the rapid growth of cities and the themes of sustainable development. I've read hundreds of books since, but none match its impact.

**B. Linda Bennett**

When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can vividly imagine the sounds and sights of a herring gull colony. This book brilliantly explains animal communication through words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony transforms from chaos to a structured society. You can identify partners, boundaries, and families. Tinbergen, a distinguished behaviourist, wanted to share his findings with everyone. His collaboration with wildlife artist Eric Ennion resulted in a book that appeals to all wildlife lovers. Ennion's art, based on years of observing birds, captures their behaviours with minimal lines and colors. This is true field naturalist art.

**C. Lee Durrell**

"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell has had the greatest influence on my life. It led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation. This book solidified my love for the natural world. While researching animal vocalisations in Madagascar, I faced many challenges. But reading this book each night made everything brighter. It beautifully weaves together animals, people, joy, and beauty, showing a world worth saving. Some say humans are the worst species, but I remember Gerald as a boy, seeing the world as a family. This interconnectedness is a concept we all need to understand.

**D. Bruce Pearson**

I discovered "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library soon after its 1966 release. The 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion immediately caught my attention. I already had bird books and enjoyed identifying birds during holidays, which led me to sketch them. But this book offered much more. It included chapters on migration, the history of birds in Britain, and birds in music, literature, and art. This broad range of information and exciting images encouraged me to appreciate birds and nature more generally. It showed me that an emotional and creative response to nature is as valid as a scientific one. As art was my strength, this book opened a new path for me.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five top British publishers about how book reviews affect a book's success. Here is what they said:

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are crucial for publishers; they are the first part of the newspaper we look at. The Book Marketing Council found that when people were asked why they bought a book, more mentioned reviews than any other reason (like ads, word of mouth, or bookshop displays). Authors and publishers react differently to reviews. Both dislike getting no reviews, but publishers are usually calmer about bad reviews. They believe that any mention, whether good or bad, can boost sales as readers decide to see for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinion of a book since they are often the first 'reader'.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and the press both care about book review pages, but their needs differ: newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviewing is better nowâ€”more varied and less elitistâ€”than 40 years ago. However, paperbacks, which most people read, are often ignored. Weekly summaries aren't enough, and original paperbacks rarely get serious attention. Still, publishers need reviews, as they are a cost-effective way to make a book and author known. A lively review by a trusted name can boost sales, especially if there are several. Fame helps get a book into readers' hands.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are vital for literary publishing; without them, we lose an essential lifeline. Our books are usually not by famous authors, so we rely on literary editors for exposure. Good reviews are more valuable than ads because readers trust them as unbiased. Reviews help sell books, but their impact on sales is hard to measure. Good reviews can launch a book and a career, but they need support from other factors like word-of-mouth, strong book trade response, and smart marketing.

**Publisher D**  
The link between publishing and reviewing in Britain? I wish I knew! In the US, the New York Times can make or break a book with one review. Here, bookshops often don't seem to care about reviews. It can take 20 years of great reviews for people to start reading a good writer's work. Yet, some poorly reviewed or unreviewed books are bestsellers. It's unpredictable, though non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer's knowledge than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers dream of long, positive reviews. But do they sell books? I once published a biography with great reviews, but it flopped because people felt they didn't need to buy the book after reading the reviews. Does the reviewer's name matter? Thirty years ago, certain reviewers could influence the public. Now, it's more about the choice of an unexpected reviewer or the power, wit, or originality of the review that drives buyers to the bookshop.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**

Making weathervanes is an ancient craft, dating back to early Egyptian times. Today, this skill is still alive in Graham Smith's workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. "This way, I can make a special, personalized item," he says. "Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a unique present that reflects the man's job or hobbies." This is very different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common for weathervanes. Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel but a witch on a broomstick, which he made as a surprise gift for his wife. Friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them too. "I realized that there are endless possibilities for weathervane designs," he says.

Graham decided to focus on a weathervane business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to switch rolesâ€”she went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to care for their children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his new path. "My previous job didn't have an artistic side, but this is exciting and creative," he says. "I really enjoy designing."

Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval for the silhouette design before cutting it by hand. Graham also keeps many traditional designs in stock because they are as popular as the custom ones. "People are drawn to hand-crafted items," Graham says. "They like the chance to get something a bit different."

Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People love the individuality, and I get a lot of satisfaction from turning a simple shape into something almost lifelike," he says. "For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction," he explains. "Now, with more people moving to the countryside, they want to add a unique touch to their homes. This has helped crafts like mine."

Graham is now very busy, sending flat-packed weathervanes to clients around the world. Buyers from America and Denmark are especially interested. "The price," he explains, "depends on how complex the design is." His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans earned him record-breaking amounts of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success story.

The start of the year was tough for Nicholas Evans, who was a screenwriter, producer, and aspiring director. Things went wrong when *Life and Limb*, a film he had been working on for months, suddenly fell apart. He was worried because it had been two years since he last earned any money, and this film was his only hope to keep the bank happy. A sensible person might have found a job, perhaps returning to television work. Instead, Evans made a bold decision. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months.

The idea for the story had been with him for a while, inspired by a farrier he met on Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. Its owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. Such people were called 'horse whisperers'. Evans was fascinated and started researching the topic, initially thinking of writing a screenplay. But after *Life and Limb* failed, he decided to write a book instead.

In the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he recalls. "I was observing people, but I felt alone and as if my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt, worried about feeding my children, and wondering if it was all a mistake."

By August, he had returned home and written half of the book. The bank was pressuring him, so he showed the draft to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent thought it was "fine" and estimated Evans might get $30,000 as an advance. Evans needed more to pay off some debt and support his family. He had already spent seven months on the book and needed at least two more. He was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.

In October, the first 200 pages and the summary were sent to seven UK publishers just before the Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down an offer of $75,000. "I said, 'You what?' And he said, 'It's OK, I just sense something is happening.'"

What happened next was remarkable. Within a week, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record-breaking advances for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were shocked. We never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans says. It wasn't sent to Hollywood either, but soon major studios were competing for it. "My UK agent wisely involved an agent there, and when he called to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief."

The studios agreed to this amount, and they each presented their case to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four top filmmakers called, one after the other, to offer $3 million for an unfinished novel.

Evans shared this story while we drank coffee on the verandah of his home. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's been such a fairy tale so far. I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is tough, and I don't want to become an employee of people I like and who have paid me so much. I'd hate to write a draft or two and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but now we'll bring in someone else.'"

He planned to stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel also brought new offers to back *Life and Limb*, but he wasn't sure he wanted to make it anymore. "I think it would be wise to write another novel," he said.

Text: 'Young Masters Age is a challenge for Bobby Fischer as he tries to make a comeback. Chess is now more than ever a game for young people. After 20 years away from the game, Bobby Fischer has returned to chess and is playing against his old rival Boris Spassky. Fischer's win in the first game was impressive, simple yet deep. However, as the following games have shown, this older, bearded chess player is not the same as he was in 1972. He is 49 years old, out of practice, and not in top shape. Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. A new era of professionalism began with Fischer's own influence on the game. The rise of professional chess has made winning more important than the scientific and artistic aspects. The main goal of modern players is to win. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as important as their intellect and wisdom. The pressure of the game has always been high: a chess clock is used to make sure each player finishes the required number of moves in the given time - failing to do so means losing the game immediately. But now the playing sessions are longer, and many games are played without breaks. This increased pressure favors younger players. Over the past 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. It is notable that, of the world's ten highest-ranked players, eight are under 30. The way the game is played has also changed. Much of modern chess happens off the board - not just the psychological battles that Fischer is known for. Every professional must now focus on pre-match preparation, especially because computer databases have greatly impacted chess. A small portable computer can store one million chess games and provide instant access to hundreds of games of a potential opponent. In a recent match, each player had large teams of assistants working nonstop to find weaknesses in the other's strategy. The opening moves of a chess game are now analyzed in great detail. Being better prepared in the opening can decide the game. Today, the chess world has more top players than ever before. Hundreds of grandmasters compete for modest prize money worldwide. Success requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours. For the chess master, this time is a constant struggle. A moment of lost focus can lead to disaster. So the players are always in a state of nervous tension. The chess clock adds to this tension. The end of the game often involves a frantic 'time scramble'. In these moments, each player has only seconds to make several moves or lose instantly. With minds racing and hands moving quickly, the masters make their moves and press their clocks with coordination that any athlete would admire. Such moments are not for thoughtful intellectuals. The game becomes a basic struggle where nerves, determination, and a strong will to win separate the winner from the loser. At the top level of chess, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the nerves and exhaustion. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. The chess master must be ready to compete the next day. Most chess competitions last for 9-11 days, with games every day, and there is a year-round tournament circuit. World championship matches are even more demanding. The 1984 match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to be stopped after several months because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost about two stone (10kg) in weight. Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This made his departure from the chess world after 1972 even more puzzling. But in some ways, it was a fitting end to his story. It made Bobby Fischer a legend. If he has returned for the money, he stands to gain a lot. Whatever happens in his match with Spassky, both will end up several million dollars richer. But if Fischer has come back truly believing he can prove he is still the best player in the world, the final result could be disappointing.'

**Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some of the new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are on their way to success.

**A** Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, has written three plays that critics love. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over Â£30 million, but it could be as low as Â£30." The most surprising thing about Nick is that before writing "Peaches," he had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed," he says. "It's set in a car. I probably wouldn't do that now because I know the practical issues. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he says. "Suddenly, I was with people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational setting. It was very inspiring."

**B** Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has advanced a lot in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is now writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a demanding tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even at Bristol, he was practicing his comedy in clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon recalls. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor and that I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job in the world, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, it's wonderful to make people laugh." He has performed with the comic group Funny Business, but his work with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably saw me imitating him," Simon admits.

**C** Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became known to the public when he starred in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The critics loved it, and his career took off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says with a smile. "I can now choose what I do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. But looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was always destined for success. Encouraged by his mother, he went from lead roles at school to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework," laughs Ciaran. "But I decided to pursue it because I was good at it and loved it." Now he is waiting for the praise to come in, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about getting respect for doing good work."

**D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single "Chimera" is released soon. "The record company talks about a big hit, but I have no idea. For me, if two people buy it, I'll be happy," he says. Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to break into the music business ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was doing student gigs for eight years and was getting tired. I was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have happened at a better time. There were times when I was very depressed, and I've been in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E** Poet and author Stephen Richards, 27, has won more prizes, awards, and academic honors than many people twice his age. He is well-known on the poetry circuit, where he has been touring and giving readings for the past six years. Now his first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing at school but became disillusioned with education later. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with stuffing envelopes at a theater, I decided I should." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writerâ€”they thought I'd be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry receiving critical acclaim, moving into novels is brave. "There's a structure with my poetry and less chance to make big mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for bad words. My main goal is not to fall into a pattern of producing work without caring about the quality."

Text: A. Isabel, the main character in this quirky novel, is an art student who loves historical romances. At 31, she is looking for Mr. Right but worries her knobbly knees might be a problem. Despite this, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a fast-paced style similar to early silent films, with chapter titles like 'Our Hero Feels Inspired.' B. This story is about the rise and near-fall of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of Francis With, a smart but weak child. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town American setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing. He takes the reader back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of dime stores, old cars, and the radio. C. In this story, it is normal for a second husband to talk with his wife's first husband. So, when professor Richard Vaisey falls for a Russian poetess, he talks to his wife's ex. The poetess writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she wants his help for her brother, who is in prison. The author skillfully untangles these issues with humor and insight into relationships, making it a fun and clever read. D. Two pairs of best friendsâ€”two women and two menâ€”meet in 1960s London and stay connected for 25 years. At the start of this long novel, one of them, James Hudson, an American businessman, is starting a newspaper, which his friend Richard Blake is editing. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that the woman they both loved (and one married) was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, with well-written characters that draw you in. E. This touching and funny story by a top American writer is about Ian Bedloe, who, feeling guilty for a past mistake, becomes the 'father' to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, Ian is slowly becoming an eccentric bachelor, surrounded by the chaos of family life. The story explores emotions and focuses on Ian's tender relationship with the youngest child, Daphne. It's a warm book with a perfect mix of sadness and humor.

**Volunteer Tourism: A Discussion by Four Academic Writers**

**A.** The direct impact of volunteer tourism on development is often questioned. Volunteers may help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a large fee to participate. This money, if given directly to local communities, could hire more workers than a single volunteer could replace. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often lack technical skills or professional experience. Many studies question whether these volunteers are truly motivated by a desire to help others or if they are seeking to gain 'cultural capital' for their careers. However, these projects might help volunteers become more ethical and socially responsible in their future careers.

**B.** Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, and more participation in global affairs. It can also create international social networks among ordinary people. In this way, the benefits can be greater than the individual contributions, helping both volunteers and host communities. However, if volunteering is mostly done by people from wealthier countries, it may benefit these volunteers more than the communities they visit. These volunteers might use the experience to advance their careers, while the host communities gain little.

**C.** At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of imperialism or self-serving career development for wealthy Westerners. At its best, it can provide technical assistance and foster an exchange of skills and cultural experiences. Volunteering can also raise awareness and commitment to fighting inequality, poverty, and unsustainable development.

**D.** Volunteer tourism aligns with the trend of life strategies focused on helping others. These strategies, which aim to 'make a difference,' can seem positive in an anti-political climate. They avoid big government and business but also bypass the democratic process, reducing development to individual charity acts. While volunteering is a commendable act, when it is promoted as sustainable development, it can degrade the true meaning of development. The politics of volunteer tourism can shift focus away from understanding global inequalities and the poverty experienced by many in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**

Many of us listen to the radio in the morning and need something to wake us up. That's where the clock radio comes in. But how do you choose a good one? Our panel, including myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models.

The first model has a 'dual alarm function,' but it doesn't work as expected. Instead of waking you with a buzzer and then letting you snooze, it lets you set two different wake-up times, one for weekdays and one for weekends. This model is priced similarly to the second one we tested, but it includes a cassette player, which is a good deal. You can fall asleep to your own tapes and wake up without news. We all thought the radio quality was excellent, but it's quite large, about the size of a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, "Any clock radio I buy has to leave enough space on the bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. I'm paranoid and always book a wake-up call in case the alarm doesn't go off." This model was voted the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was "in love with it," although the clock on his test model "kept getting stuck at 16.00." I liked the digital display with its grey numbers on a green background. The wide snooze bar is easy to tap with your eyes closed. However, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which was a problem when I finally looked at the 50-page instruction booklet. The clock has a self-power backup, so you don't have to reset it if someone unplugs it to use a hairdryer or vacuum cleaner; we all liked this feature. However, setting it up was technically challenging, though mastering it made us feel "cool" and sophisticated.

Tom Granger described the model with an extra built-in lamp as "unbelievably tacky." "You have to pull the light out of its socket to make it work, which makes me question the quality of the rest of it." He had to read the instruction booklet twice to get it to work; the clock kept jumping from 12.00 to 02.00, so he had to start over. The light was hard to position; you couldn't read by it as it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea amusing but agreed the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer reminded me of "action stations" on a submarine and made me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market.

Aimed at young people, with its bright colors and matching strap, this model appealed to Tom Granger and me. "I would choose this one because it stands out," he said. The traditional controls made it the only one we set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm has a 20-minute margin for error; the manual says, "the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the pre-set time." Paul Bridges laughed at this and said it was "terribly fiddly" and "completely useless."

The simplest and cheapest model scored points with Tom Granger because it "seemed very standard and took up little space," and it has old-fashioned dial tuning. "It's more intuitive to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you're never sure if you've pressed all the buttons in the right order, so you can't trust it will work." He admitted that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was crude, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model certainly works; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Text: 'Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines covering its body. Hedgehogs are found in many parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. All hedgehog species can roll into a tight ball when threatened, making their spines point outwards. The success of this defense depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have evolved to be lighter, so they have fewer spines and might try to run from danger, using their ball-rolling ability only if necessary. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, either under bushes or in a hole in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all do; if conditions are right, some stay awake all year.'

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in any sport is challenging, even for men, but women often have to work twice as hard. Training and competition leave little time for a normal life, so sacrifices are necessary. Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and breaking records. Here, we talk to some brilliant British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**

"It's an amazing feeling to fly through the air and land cleanly, but it can be scary. Sometimes you don't feel well, or it's windy and you can't see, but you just keep going. It's not easy to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months a year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends. But it was my choice. There are six men and three women in the British team. We all compete on the same courses at the same competitions and get treated the sameâ€”it's a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**

"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to take part in a charity race. I won overall just because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was amazing because I'd never cycled before! I'm well paid as a professional, and cycling has lots of potential for endorsements. However, I know I'm not ugly, and it worries me that people may think I've succeeded because of my looks, not because I'm the best cyclist. So I focus on cycling at the moment, rather than earning money. I do at least four hours of training every day on the bike, plus some stretching exercises, swimming, and running. My boyfriend's a cyclist as well, so he understands the time you have to put into itâ€”it would be impossible otherwise."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**

"Rowing is hard for girls to get into because very few girls' schools offer it. So most don't start until they're 19 or 20, which makes it harder to succeed at an international level. Also, you usually have coaches who only stay a year or so. There's no continuity, so the women's squad is basically a mess. But it's great fun, and I love being fit, plus there's a good social life."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**

"At 13, I dreamed of walking around the worldâ€”I didn't know just how big it was then! But Britain was too claustrophobic, too safe. I was very headstrong; I hated anyone having control over me. Now I am more tactful. Each walk has been different. The walk across Australia was the worst experience I've ever had in terms of pain. I was doing 50 miles and 21 hours each day with three hours of sleep in high temperatures and walking with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record! I had to because my sponsorship money was going to run out after 95 days. Men think that women are more likely to fail, so sponsoring them is always seen as a higher risk."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**

"Some men have huge egos when they're drivingâ€”you see it on motorways. When I'm doing well, they don't talk to me. Being a woman has its disadvantages. When I get to a corner, the men think 'I've got to beat her,' so I've had a lot of knocks! You have to be naturally competitive and aggressive. It's very difficult to earn any money, and what I do make goes back into the sport. Women have been racing since the twenties and have always been seen as eccentrics. It's great that there are now more and more women taking up racing every year. For me, the appeal of saloon car racing is aiming for perfectionâ€”always trying to get around with a perfect lap."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**

"I get up at 5.30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on my sleep. In the evening, I just cycle or run. Yes, I do fall asleep at my desk sometimes! There is a lot of nervous build-up beforehand, and when you're racing, you really push yourselfâ€”you don't feel good if you don't. Several times I've asked myself why I do it. The answer is a) I'm happier when I keep fit, b) I'm a slob at heart, and if I didn't make myself do this, I'd really be one, c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when an event is covered in the press, 90 percent of the article will explain the men's event, and 10 percent will say, 'Oh, by the way, so-and-so won the women's event.' The prize money isn't as good either, of course. But now we've formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission, so we're working on it."

**The Day I Drew Picasso**

Richard Cork remembers the day he met one of the most famous artists of the century, Pablo Picasso. At 18 years old, Richard was traveling around Europe and Morocco before starting university. He was low on money and found a job painting boats in Cannes. One day, while at an open-air restaurant in Cannes harbor, he saw Picasso having lunch with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Picasso was known to be a private person, so Richard was surprised to see him there.

Encouraged by a friend, Richard nervously approached Picasso to ask for his autograph. To his surprise, Picasso agreed and signed Richard's sketchbook. He even added a playful drawing on the page. Richard was thrilled and started a conversation with Picasso, though they needed an American woman at the table to translate because Picasso's English was not good.

After showing his friend the autograph, Richard was encouraged to go back and draw Picasso's portrait. Without asking for permission, Richard began sketching Picasso, who made funny faces to make the task difficult. Despite this, Richard continued drawing, feeling challenged by Picasso's playful behavior. Eventually, Picasso stopped moving and allowed Richard to study him closely. Richard noticed how youthful and intense Picasso's eyes were, despite his age.

When Richard finished, Picasso wanted to see the portrait. Although Richard was embarrassed, Picasso looked at it and nodded approvingly. Then, Picasso took the crayon and quickly drew a playful version of Richard's face, moving one eye onto his nose and capturing his smile with a single line. Richard felt like a character from one of Picasso's mythological drawings.

Richard asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but Picasso declined, saying Richard already had his signature. Despite this, Richard felt incredibly lucky to have met Picasso and received his attention. This encounter meant a lot to him.

**Talking Shop: How Stores Make You Spend More**

Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Here, we explain the tricks shops use to make you spend more money.

**A. The Image of Freshness**

Supermarkets know that customers value fresh produce. They often place fruits and vegetables at the store entrance or display house plants to create a fresh image. An in-store bakery might spread the smell of fresh bread throughout the store. The store's colors, like green, can also enhance this fresh image. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, doesn't match this fresh image.

**B. Displaying to Advantage**

The placement of products in a store is crucial for sales, especially in supermarkets. With computerized stock control, supermarkets know which areas attract the most shoppers. High-profit items or fast-selling products are placed in these spots. The saying "eye-level is buy-level" means that shelves at eye height are prime spots for products. Special offers in "dump bins" attract bargain hunters. "Complementation" is also popular, like placing salad dressings near salads or desserts near ice creams.

**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**

Supermarkets often place low-cost essentials like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This forces shoppers to pass by more expensive items. Similarly, chain stores might place popular products far from the entrance, relying on customer loyalty to lead shoppers past other tempting items.

**D. Less Sells More**

Chain stores have changed how they display products. The Next chain, for example, moved away from the "pile them high, sell them cheap" method. Their stores have a "boutique" feel, displaying fewer items to seem exclusive. However, Next's clothes are as mass-produced as their competitors'. Their success is due to good store design and well-designed clothing.

**E. Tempting Totals**

Food shoppers often focus on the total bill rather than individual prices. Supermarkets use this by offering a mix of low and high mark-up items. Not everything in a supermarket is cheap. Some items, called "loss leaders," are sold at a loss to attract customers. More often, low prices come from buying in bulk or meeting sales targets, which earn discounts from manufacturers.

**F. The All-Important Price-Tag**

In chain stores, shoppers buy fewer items and notice individual prices more. Pricing a blouse at Â£14.99 instead of Â£15 is still effective. This pricing also helps reduce theft, as staff must ring up a sale to give change.

**G. Lighting to Effect**

Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully plan their lighting. Chain stores aim for lighting that resembles natural light, so clothes look the same as they would in daylight. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to make fresh produce look more appealing.

**H. Walk This Way**

Many chain stores use different carpeting to guide shoppers. One pattern marks the main paths, and another marks sales areas. These paths, called the "Yellow Brick Road," guide shoppers through the store. However, not all shoppers follow them. Marks and Spencer, for example, use wood or marble for paths, encouraging shoppers to step onto the more inviting carpet in sales areas.

**I. In-Store Promotion**

As you enter a supermarket, large photos of delicious foods greet you, tempting you if you're hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets use "video trolleys" with screens that advertise products as you shop. Sensors trigger ads relevant to the section you're in, like an ad for ready-made meals near the cook-chill section. These trolleys target impulse shoppers and reportedly increase sales by about 30%.

Chris Bonnington, a 58-year-old mountaineer, is famous for climbing Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written books like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way." Robin Knox-Johnston, aged 53, started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic, taking 10 days from New York to the Lizard. Chris and Robin teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in their book "Sea, Ice and Rock."

In 1979, while working on "Quest for Adventure," Chris contacted Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail, where Chris could teach him climbing, and Robin could teach Chris sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed, anchored, and then went ashore to practice climbing. Chris was impressed by Robin's calmness in difficult conditions. At one point, they reached a big drop, and Chris showed Robin how to climb down. Robin, used to using his arms on the boat, wanted to descend in his own way, which he did safely.

During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin formed a strong friendship. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a larger version of their Skye adventure. Chris admired Robin's leadership. Although the skipper usually makes all decisions, Robin involved everyone in the decision-making process. Chris found the sailing part boring and challenging, as he preferred land and wasn't handy with repairs. Robin, however, enjoyed sailing and fixing things. Chris sometimes felt useless, which was difficult for him. The yacht was crowded with six people in a space meant for four, unlike a mountain expedition where you can have some space.

When they reached Greenland, Chris led the climbing part of the expedition. He found it hard to be responsible for Robin's safety, as a fall could endanger both of them. Climbing Greenland's highest mountain, the Cathedral, was tougher than expected. Robin, not a natural climber, impressed Chris with his determination. On their first attempt, they climbed for 24 hours and were exhausted. Robin trusted Chris completely, even when they had to turn back. Despite worrying about the boat, Robin was eager to try climbing the mountain again.

The only tension between them occurred on the yacht home. Chris was supposed to take a watch shift at 4 am, but Robin let him sleep, thinking he could manage alone. Chris felt insecure, thinking Robin didn't trust him, but Robin reassured him it was a misunderstanding. By the end of the Greenland expedition, Chris realized that beneath Robin's tough exterior, he was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been with us since ancient times, in many colors, shapes, and sizes. However, the late 20th century risks losing this heritage.

**Prehistoric Wild Apples (8,000 BC)**

Humans have eaten apples since prehistoric times. In Neolithic Britain, they spat out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near their homes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people stored dried apple halves for winter. These were wild crab apples, small and shriveled, known in Ancient Britain as 'windings'. They were quite different from today's apples.

**Norman Knowledge (1000 AD)**

The French learned fruit-growing skills from the Romans, which were developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain. The dessert apple, Decio, was introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, most Roman apple varieties did not suit the British climate, and Norman varieties became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and develop new apples, which are the ancestors of many Western apples today.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**

Several apple types became popular in Britain during the 13th century. The Old English Pearmain, recorded in 1204, was the main dessert apple until the 18th century. Its cooking counterpart was the Costard, sold in Oxford markets from 1296 to the late 17th century, giving us the word 'costermonger' for a street fruit and vegetable seller. However, prosperity declined due to droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses. Fewer apples were produced, and more were imported. This changed in the 16th century when Henry VIII sent his chief fruiterer, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple cultivation. Harris returned with many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and created the first modern-style orchard in Kent.

**Settler Treasure (1750)**

By the 17th century, apples were so popular in Britain that settlers took them to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took the first apples to Australia; Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers carried them to America. In North America, the most famous apple-planter was John Chapman, or 'Johnny Appleseed'. Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. The Indians saw him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees, unusual clothing, and religious devotion inspired many folktales. He was said to be so kind to animals that he even slept with bears.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**

Around this time in Iowa, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a shoot growing from a dead tree's roots. It became an apple tree with a new apple, which Hiatt called 'Hawkey'. At a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed 'Delicious, delicious!'. In 1895, it was introduced to the market as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples worldwide.

**Granny Smith (1850)**

Another famous modern apple was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. The daughter of convicts, Maria was independent and rejected her parents' criminal life. She worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales, where she was known as 'Granny Smith'. She managed the family farm and orchard. In 1868, she found a small tree growing from discarded fruit.
