Even without accepting traditional Chinese principles, Western doctors recognize that acupuncture can relieve pain. Scientific explanations suggest that acupuncture may work by stimulating nerves to block pain signals or by releasing natural pain-relieving substances called endorphins.

**Types of Pain Treated**

Many people with chronic pain turn to acupuncture when other treatments fail. It is commonly used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, migraines, and post-operative pain. Acupuncturists also claim to treat menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**Modern Developments**

Although acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, its use as an alternative to anesthesia in surgery began in the 1950s. This development helped convince some Western doctors of its effectiveness. In China, acupuncture is used in various surgeries, sometimes with electrical stimulation or drugs. It is said to eliminate pain without the side effects of conventional anesthetics, allowing quicker recovery.

**Effectiveness and Trials**

Clinical trials for acupuncture are challenging to conduct, but those that exist show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists report similar success rates, acknowledging that it may not work for everyone. For chronic pain, relief usually occurs after six or seven visits, with some improvement after two or three.

**Different Approaches to Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine have different views on pain. Acupuncturists take a holistic approach, considering the whole person rather than just symptoms. They spend time diagnosing underlying weaknesses in Qi and consider external factors like weather conditions that might affect pain. This approach is different from that of a typical medical doctor.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**

Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others, including many general practitioners, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that only by using traditional Chinese medicine can deep, lasting changes be achieved. When choosing an acupuncturist, ensure they are qualified and will refer you to a medical doctor if necessary.

P.D. James, whose full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, is a famous crime writer known for her complex and imaginative stories. Despite her quiet and authoritative presence, she admits to being shy. Her famous detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, reflects her own personality, or how she imagines she might have been if she were a man. Like Dalgliesh, she prefers to work alone, especially when writing, needing complete privacy.

James is modest about her success, even though her 12 detective novels are loved by readers worldwide. She admires the works of her friend Ruth Rendell, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. Her reading preferences include women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she also appreciates male authors such as Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh.

James's success came later in life. She was 42 when her first novel, "Cover Her Face," was published. Born in Oxford and raised in Cambridge, she met her husband, Connor Bantry White, there. Her life has had its challenges; her husband returned from World War II very ill, and she had to work hard to support him and their two daughters. Her in-laws helped care for her children during these tough times.

While working full-time for the National Health Service and later at the Home Office, she used her organizational skills effectively. Her work in forensic science exposed her to the realities of crime, but it was the structure of crime novels that attracted her. She always wanted to be a writer and saw detective stories as a way to practice serious writing without drawing from her personal life.

James believes that writing detective stories is about creating order from chaos. Solving a crime in a story affirms the value of life, even if the life in question is not particularly likable. She emphasizes that nobody truly enjoys violence.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**

The study of handwriting to reveal a person's character is gaining support. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you might be asked for a sample of your handwriting. Your handwriting could help decide if you are suitable for the job. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Researchers say it can help identify certain illnesses, like heart disease and cancer, and can show psychological states and emotional issues. Handwriting analysis is being used more for career guidance and during interviews. Many big companies hire graphologists to study the handwriting of potential candidates for important jobs. However, most doctors and psychiatrists are skeptical about the value of graphology. 

Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist for over 20 years, argues that they should take it more seriously. She believes handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says, "Handwriting is a strong indicator of social class and intelligence. But more than that, it can assess mental ability and potential, whether a person should focus on arts or sciences, and whether they have a devious or open character." According to Ms. Marne, graphology can be useful in assessing possible criminal tendencies: "Criminals often have disturbed handwriting, mostly illiterate and poorly-shaped. Most criminals come from deprived backgrounds and have arrested emotional development. This often shows up in unusually childish handwriting and in going over letters several times. I can tell whether people are honest, manipulators, or reliable employees."

"Young male offenders frequently have very high ascenders, indicating that they live in a world of fantasy and dream of making it big. Graphologists can tell whether violence is about to erupt, whether the writer is under unbearable pressure, and whether there are psychopathic tendencies. Handwriting can be used to predict would-be suicides." Heart and lung problems can also show up, she says. "You can't make a diagnosis from one sample, unless the writing is obviously shaky or disturbed. But if over time it changes or becomes disjointed, if there's a break in the signature which did not exist before, that could be a sign that something quite serious has occurred." A severe emotional upset can also show up in a temporarily altered signature, she maintains.

Ms. Marne says handwriting can reveal other psychological characteristics. People with writing in which letters form "threads" instead of being individually formed are, apparently, devious and clever. Those who write mainly in capitals are trying to hide their true selves from others. Very light pressure indicates sensitivity and lack of vitality. Originality in handwritingâ€”how far the writer has deviated from copybook scriptâ€”indicates confidence and artistic ability. Disconnected writing is the main sign of a loner. Very small signatures indicate inhibition and an inferiority complex; circles over the 'i' are a bid for attention, and crossing the 't' heavily over the whole word is a sign of intolerance and a patronizing attitude.

Ms. Marne says it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting accurately, and this must be combined with empathy and intuition. She feels more research is needed to put graphology on a proper scientific footing. This will happen soon, she believes. "It's actually far more accurate than psychoanalysis, as you can tell the whole history of the person, including all their emotional crises, without asking them questions to which they may give wrong answers." 

Interesting as all this may sound, there is little hard evidence to support such claims. Some psychiatrists are highly critical of them. Handwriting, they say, is a product of education, artistic ability, and the type of writing taughtâ€”and has no other significance.

Text: 'Is your office working well? Fresh air and the right chairs are important for a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they were as work environments. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist who studies people's working conditions, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions. Office A. Advertising Agency Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple; no central heating, no mechanical ventilation, windows open directly to the street. It's hard to see why this space works, but the people, who are part of a small, dynamic team, seem to have few complaints. They adapt to the seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, much like they do at home. This might be the key: a team of seven people have created a happy, homely work environment without any outside bureaucracy. Ergonomist: The furniture here has developed over time; no two pieces match. Much of it causes bad working postures. Chairs are old, most aren't adjustable, and many are broken. Although this environment is poor in that way, the staff have a varied work schedule, which they control -- office work, meeting clients, making presentations, and so on. This variety reduces the risk of fatigue, boredom, and muscle problems. Occupational Psychologist: Staff are happy with the variety of work and the flexible office space. They said their office was 'just the right size' -- small enough to know what colleagues are doing, large enough to be alone and focus on personal work. I found the office attractive and fun, showing both efficiency and creativity. Office B. News Service Building Health Consultant: While the office may not be very exciting, it seems comfortable and is not disliked by the staff. The air quality and general maintenance standards seem good. This is helped by a No Smoking policy. Ergonomist: I was not surprised to learn that the company had already used the services of an ergonomist. Chairs are excellent, lighting and computer equipment are good. Space provision is good, although the layout could be improved. But the environment is impersonal and unstimulating, with grey, bare walls. Occupational Psychologist: Walls are bare except for year planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have been there for at least five years and relationships are satisfactory. The office could be improved if the desks were positioned to make sharing information easier. Success stories or information on upcoming projects could be displayed on the walls. Office C. Bank Building Health Consultant: An office that produces mixed reactions from those working in it. The feeling inside is like being in a glass case, viewed by, and viewing, many similar exhibits. Despite a mix of smokers and non-smokers in a relatively small space, the air did not seem stale. Even standing only 1.5 meters away from a smoker, it was not possible to smell his cigarette. Ergonomist: The office area is, unfortunately, very standard and uninspiring. The desks are adequate, but only just. Not all the chairs used for computer work meet requirements, but this is user choice. Computer screens are often on small desk units with lowered keyboard shelves; this is no longer considered appropriate for modern equipment. Occupational Psychologist: Staff are supportive of each other and well served by technology. Many communications awards are on display. The wood-colored paneling and brown carpet give a slightly serious effect. The office is a buzz of activity. Office D. Newspaper Building Health Consultant: It is hard to say anything good about this building. The air-conditioning control is very basic, causing large temperature changes. The space is cluttered and most people have inadequate desk space. The office is very dusty -- there are many places for dust to settle. The shed-type roof also collects dust, which, if disturbed, falls on those sitting below. Ergonomist: The furniture would be more suitable in a carpentry workshop than in a high-tech industry. Most of the chairs are of little use to keyboard users, especially those shorter than about 1.75 m. Many chairs are old, lack proper adjustment, and have armrests that prevent the user from getting close to the desk. Occupational Psychologist: Old brown chairs, dirty carpets, dust, and dirt everywhere. A lot of room for improvement -- the place needs a good clean-up, individual success could be more recognized, air conditioning needs to be improved immediately -- there are many smokers. Few conversations were happening when we visited; everyone seemed stressed and driven by deadlines. The company needs to adopt a policy of team-working.'

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular and classless, with Americans consuming 12 million sticks daily. Learn how this ancient habit became a major industry. Each stick of gum has fewer than ten calories, but it is considered a food and must meet the American Food and Drug Administration's standards. Modern gum is mostly synthetic, with added pine resins and softeners to maintain flavor and texture. 

In ancient times, Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, found mainly in Greece and Turkey, to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists learned from the Amero-Indians in New England to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, spruce gum was sold in the eastern United States, becoming the first commercial chewing gum there.

Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic, leading to a new industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla commercially have failed, so synthetic alternatives were developed as the market grew. Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, called chicleros, live a tough and dangerous life, traveling long distances to collect sapodilla in humid conditions. They face threats from poisonous snakes, insects, and the chicle fly, which lays eggs in their ears and nose. Despite these dangers, chicleros climb trees with just a rope and an axe to collect the sap, which is then boiled into bricks at forest camps. Life at these camps is hard, with a basic maize diet and local alcohol.

Despite the harsh conditions, chicleros worry about their jobs. The U.S. once imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle annually from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetic materials to cut costs and meet demand.

Gum producers are also finding creative ways to market their products. Gum is said to help you relax, boost energy, and reduce tension. It was even given to soldiers during both world wars. Its biggest claim is that it reduces tooth decay by increasing saliva flow, which neutralizes plaque acid and provides minerals like calcium, phosphate, and fluoride. Research continues on new textures and flavors, with glycerine and vegetable oils used to blend the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still need natural ingredients. Additionally, 137 square kilometers of America are dedicated to growing mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the calm of an English country house with Indian symbolism. The Ghanerao family has lived there for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome paying guests. The facilities are basic, with hot water provided by bucket, but this simplicity adds to its charm.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
The Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island is one of my favorite hotels. I discovered it by chance while climbing. We were flown near the top of a glacier, climbed to the peak, and then walked down. At the bottom, I was surprised to find this hotel. It is in a stunningly beautiful, wild, and high-up area. After a tiring climb, finding yourself in luxury, with someone playing Cole Porter on the piano, is extraordinary.

**C. MAURITIUS - BEACHCOMBER PARADIS HOTEL**  
On the southwest of Mauritius, the Paradis Hotel is on its own peninsula in a quiet part of the island. Driving from here, the road winds along the coast past empty beaches with only fishermen. The hotel is not small, and many enjoy the free watersports, but you can easily find solitude along nine kilometers of private beach. Swim a few yards into the Indian Ocean, and the hotel is hidden by palm trees. In the evening, sit on the beach as the light fades, and you'll feel far away from everything.

**D. ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL, ST LUCIA**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has one of the Caribbean's most dramatic settings. Quiet and remote, it stands 1,000 feet high, with open rooms looking out between the twin peaks of the Pitons to the Caribbean Seaâ€”a stunning view in the morning! The style is colonial, with mahogany and greenheart wood furniture, and four-poster beds with muslin netting.

**E. TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
This hotel, on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, is perfect for escaping Istanbul's noise. The islands are an hour by boat and are idyllic. There are no cars, only horse-drawn carriages and beautiful 1920s wooden architecture. The islands are a mix of Key West and the Old South, and the landmark building is the Splendid. Made of wood, painted white with red domes, it's a copy of a turn-of-the-century hotel on the French Riviera. It's a bit run down now but still charming.

**F. FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the heart of Champagne, is a beautiful 17th-century chateau. Surrounded by a moat with two swans, the chateau was a family home until recently and has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster bedsâ€”one even has a large billiard table. There are special weekend rates for two nights with breakfast and dinner, plus complimentary champagne (their own brand, if you want to take some home).

**G. KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview is a rare find in Africaâ€”a comfortable hotel without excessive luxury. It's a key stop for travelers resting from one safari and planning the next. Some guests arrive, see the gardens, rooms, and dining menu, and decide to stay longer. There are even apartments for those who choose to stay for months. The hotel's leafy grounds and scattered buildings are on Nairobi Hill, far from the city's busy center. It's a great place to watch the African sunset, sip beer, and look forward to a hearty dinnerâ€”like braised zebra and two vegetables, followed by jelly trifle.

**H. ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Duke of Windsor was the first to sign the guest book at Hotel Splendido. Since then, many famous people have visited, like Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart, Liz Taylor and Richard Burton. Today, you might meet a soft drinks billionaire or a rubber-tyre heiress. This former monastery-turned-villa-turned-hotel is still splendid, as its name suggests, and has enough glamour to enhance any weekend break. The restaurant offers deliciously simple food, and there are fine Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

Text: Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. Christopher Middleton watched her work. Just one minute into her inspection at the Globe Hotel, things start to go wrong. The receptionist is busy on the phone, unaware that she is ignoring an important guest. "Hasn't even acknowledged us," Sue whispers. "Very poor." This is a common mistake Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. "But this isn't an ordinary three-star place," she says. "It has three red stars, and I would expect better." Red stars mean the Globe is among the top 130 of 4,000 hotels in the guide published by Sue's organization. Even before the cold welcome, there were issues. The entrance from the car park was through an unmanned door with a buzzer, leading to a long, empty corridor. "Again, not what I had expected," says Sue. Things get worse. "We seem to have no record of your booking," the receptionist says. Only three of the hotel's 15 rooms are occupied that night. One room on the top floor is not to Sue's liking: it's stuffy, and there's a large hole in the wall behind a wardrobe panel. Early in her career, Sue was known for being tough. "The Woman in Black, I was called," she remembers, "which was funny because I never wore black. And I've never been too tough." The next morning, after paying her bill, Sue reveals her identity to the Globe's general manager, Robin Greaves. He looks terrified. Before she says more, he apologizes for the bad smell in the main lounge. "We think there's a blocked drain," he says. "The whole floor might need to come up." Sue suggests they should not take guests into that room. "Better to guide them to the other lounge," she advises. Greaves agrees and takes notes. He has been at the Globe for only five months and struggles to believe Sue when she says her feedback will help the hotel in the long run. Not everything is negative. Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, a young waitress, are praised for their work. Dinner was good enough to keep the hotel's two-rosette food rating. Greaves asks, "What do we need to do to get three rosettes?" Sue suggests, "Don't serve a pudding that collapses." The light in Greaves' eyes fades. Sue's job is to voice complaints that other guests might not express. "Sometimes it's delicate," she says. "Once, a woman complained I got her son fired. All I could say was he served me apple pie with his fingers." Sue also writes a full report for the hotelier. They pay for her advice, as there is a fee to be in the guide. Being a red-star hotel is worth it. Greaves is relieved to hear Sue won't recommend removing the Globe's red stars. The bad news is another inspector will return in two months to check improvements. "Good," Greaves says, not very convincingly. "We'll look forward to that."

**Seven Up: Conquering the Seven Summits**

Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experiences of climbing the highest peak on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. His journey began later in life, and he recounts them in the order he climbed them.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
Doug and his partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave near the summit. Dougal started talking to someone who wasn't there, likely due to lack of oxygen. Doug also found himself talking to his feet, worried about frostbite. Despite these challenges, Doug felt confident with Dougal and managed to reach the summit.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
In April 1976, Doug and Dougal faced the world's most dangerous mountain. They carried all their gear on their backs, a first for a new route. The low air pressure made it feel like they were at a higher altitude. After a tough climb, they reached the summit.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and Paul Braithwaite intended to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up on Kilimanjaro. They got lost in the jungle, struggling with scarce water. They eventually found a trail and reached the summit via the Umbwe route.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, joined a group to climb Aconcagua. Bad weather delayed them, and they chose an easier route to meet their flight schedule. They reached the summit and met climbers aiming for the Seven Summits, inspiring Doug to consider the same goal.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug realized he could climb Vinson Massif by guiding others to cover costs. In November 1992, his team reached the summit despite harsh weather. The experience was uplifting, though visibility was poor.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In summer 1994, Doug's team faced challenges on Elbrus, including a demand for a commission that was later waived. They reached what they thought was the summit, only to find another ridge. They returned safely the next day.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
Doug's team aimed to establish a new route and connect with the Dani people. Despite warnings of danger, they climbed the mountain, reaching the summit by 11 am. This marked Doug's completion of the Seven Summits, celebrated with a standing ovation. Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**

Style influences many aspects of our lives today, from clothing to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley gives an overview of this year's fashion trends.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**

Ned Ingham creates dreamy, romantic wedding dresses. He advises people to choose simpler styles instead of traditional, stiff, or overly frilly dresses. Ingham has been designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to cut and make clothes. Ingham also designs long, classic evening dresses with modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer traditional styles, he offers a classic summer navy-blue suit, a staple in English women's wardrobes throughout the 20th century, but with a fresh twist.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**

Sally Quail, who once worked for an art dealer, has no formal training in jewelry. She started designing her own engagement ring when she couldn't find one she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Her pieces are now popular with many celebrities. Her signature style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, inspired by 18th-century jewelry. Recently, she has started using diamonds. 'It must reflect my age,' says 36-year-old Quail. 'I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond, and that's when I began working with them.'

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**

Lily Grimson entered the competitive fashion industry four years ago with only a basic course in art and design. Two of her creations have already been chosen for a major design exhibition. Grimson's handbags, handmade in the UK, are always noticed. They are glamorous, whether made from fine calfskin or heavy silk. Her combination of style and craftsmanship makes a Grimson bag special.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**

For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of some of the world's most famous people. 'Most women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage at home,' he says. His approach ensures clients never look like they've just left a salon. However, this natural look is expensive, costing Â£250 for the first appointment, with a three-month waiting list. Peter has also launched his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, allowing people to create their own styles at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**

Penny Pratt runs a small shop and is a flower consultant for a large supermarket chain. She also provides floral ideas to top restaurants. Despite having no formal floristry qualifications, she left her teaching job 10 years ago to pursue something different. Her simple yet modern flower arrangements have won many design awards, helping her establish her own London Flower School. She has also given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. She says, 'Flower arrangements are simpler these days. Keep them simple but strong, and don't use too many leavesâ€”they are too large and architectural. For wedding bouquets, the golden rule is: the flowers must be of the same species.'

**Five-star luxury meets modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took nearly two years to convert four large eighteenth-century houses into this luxury hotel. This transformation allowed the installation of the latest technology for both staff and guests. General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but for specific preferences, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system, which cost Â£250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible due to the guest-history feature that records preferences.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests worldwide. At the Merrion, a high-tech system allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the standard 18Â°C. Additionally, the front desk can adjust each room's temperature between 14Â°C and 25Â°C. Business travelers, who are expected to make up 65% of the hotel's clientele, will appreciate the technology in their rooms. Each room includes three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. To keep up with rapid technological changes, extra cables have been installed for future upgrades. Televisions are rented, not bought, so they can be easily replaced with newer models. DVD recorders can also be upgraded when needed.

Despite all this advanced technology, the hotel aims to make guests feel comfortable and not overwhelmed. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, and welcoming. The hotel also features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. As with all luxury hotels, excellent food is essential. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his business to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He designed a new, modern kitchen and enjoys better parking facilities. The hotel gains a popular and successful restaurant without financial risks. With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is set to succeed.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden, full of her favorite flowers like tulips and poppies, provides many of her painting subjects. Some plants grow wildly, spreading seeds everywhere. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors and shapes, especially along the flower borders that line the path from east to west. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left plants that Susan liked. She also inherited their gardener, Danny. Susan says, 'It was really his garden.' They got along well, and he understood her vision when she explained she wanted to paint certain plants.

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they are, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. 'I don't set the whole thing up at once,' she explains. 'I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another one, building the painting over time. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.' Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. 'They all come out together, and you're so busy,' she says. She is also fascinated by how flowers change as they decay. For example, tulips change shape and open up after being in water for a day. 'When you first put them in a vase, they seem boring, but they change all the time with twists and turns.'

Susan has always been interested in plants. 'I studied botany at school and collected wildflowers from the countryside,' she says. 'I wasn't interested in gardening then; I thought garden flowers looked like fake ones sold in shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was amazed by how they grew in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs.' Now, her garden includes plants from far-off places, but they seem at home there. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like an aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of subjects to paint, she finds it hard to work in the garden. She has hired an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her work, 'you have to get your hands dirty.'

Many trees in the Brackham area were knocked down during the terrible storms in March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. The removal of these trees changed the look of the town center completely, which upset some of the more traditional residents. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have been among those upset. However, during the storm, when the wind even knocked down the mature walnut tree in his garden, Pelham was too sick to notice. A usually healthy man, he was seriously ill for the first time with bronchitis. When he first felt a headache and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, tried to convince him to see a doctor. Believing the police force needed him, he ignored her and kept working. This only made his memory worse and his temper shorter. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. By then, he was too weak to argue. Soon, she took him to the pharmacy to get his antibiotics and then home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed. On Thursday morning, when Molly told him the walnut tree had fallen during the night, Pelham couldn't understand it. On Thursday evening, he weakly asked about damage to the house, was relieved to hear there was none, and went back to sleep. It wasn't until Saturday, when the antibiotics started working, his fever went down, and he got up, that he realized the loss of the walnut tree had changed the look of the living room. The Pelhams' large house was in a big garden. It was expensive, but Pelham didn't regret buying it. The leafy garden gave a sense of privacy. Now, the storm had changed his view. Before, the view from the living room included the beautiful walnut tree. It didn't make the room dark because there was another window on the opposite wall, but it created interesting light and shadow patterns that hid the worn furniture the family brought from their old house. With the tree gone, the room seemed too bright, showing the shabby furniture. The view from the window was also unpleasant. The tall house next door, once hidden by the tree, was now visible, with its unattractive purple bricks and outside pipes. It seemed to have many upstairs windows, all watching the Pelhams' every move. 'Doesn't it look terrible?' Pelham said weakly to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded more happy than upset. 'That's what I've been telling you since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.'

**Living in the Valley**

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first realized the dangers in the surrounding hills that could threaten our survival. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall, reaching about 15 centimeters deep in a day. It almost blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. On the nearby hills, the snow was much deeper and lasted longer. Up there, the wind blew fiercely. In our valley, we only felt sudden gusts of wind; trees swayed, but the branches held firm. Yet, we knew we had reason to worry. The snow and wind were inconvenient, but they did not trouble us much. It was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, that threatened us most. It reminded us of what could have happened if the water from the hills had not been controlled by a series of dams many years ago.

Soon, the snow started to melt. Day after day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. Grey clouds spread over the valleys, warning of what was to come. We had seen enough of the sky; now we began to watch the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder every day. The snow was gradually washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but high up in the hills, the reservoir was filling and was fast approaching danger level. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. Up in the heights, it was like Niagara Falls, as water surged over the dam and poured into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the waters rushed down to its lower stretches. Just a couple of meters from our cottage, the stream seemed wild beneath the bridge. It was deeper than we'd ever seen it so close to our home, fiercely hitting its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Fortunately, our hopes were answered as the dam held and the waters began to subside.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded the nearby villages in such a rage. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, all is well; the large amount of water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind its barrier with just the occasional overflow. We can now enjoy, rather than fear, the large clouds over the valley and be amazed by the river's tremendous power. Thanks to this protection, we feel our home in the valley is still secure and safe.

Film Critic Mark Adams reflects on his past ten years working as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing about films for The Front Page was his first real job. Before that, he had done some reviewingâ€”novels for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and various tasks for the radio. This is how he met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also wrote for radio and TV. Tom hired him, but Tom wasn't mainly a journalist, or he might have been more careful in choosing his staff. Initially, Tom's idea was to have a team of critics handle art forms that didn't need specialized knowledge: books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have a weekly lunch to choose from the artistic material Tom decided they should cover, with guests to keep things sociable. It all felt like a dream then: a new newspaper, and Mark was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market. It felt just as likely that a millionaire wanted to help him personally and was pretending to employ him. Such was his lack of self-confidence. The first time he saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to a page with one of his reviews, he didn't know where to look. Tom's original plan for a team of critics never happened. It was a good idea, but they didn't meet as planned, so everything was done by phone. It turned out that the public preferred to link a reviewer with a single subject area, so Mark chose film. Without Tom's initial push, they wouldn't have the current setup, where Mark writes an extended weekly piece, usually on one film. This way of working suits him well. He wouldn't have been interested in the usual film critic's role, which involves reviewing every film that comes out. That routine would make him lose interest quickly. He would soon be sinking into his seat on a Monday morning with a sigh, 'What terrible rubbish must I sit through now?'â€”a type of sigh often heard in screening rooms worldwide. The space he is given allows him to expand his argumentâ€”or forces him, in a dull week, to create something out of nothing. But what is his role in the public arena? He assumes people choose films based on the stars, the publicity, or the director. There is also loyalty to a 'type' or its opposite. It rarely happens that someone who hates westerns buys a ticket for one after reading a review, or a love story fan avoids a romantic film because of what the papers say. So if a film review isn't really a consumer guide, what is it? He doesn't feel he has a responsibility to be 'right' about a movie. Nor does he think there should be a certain number of 'great' and 'bad' films each year. All he has to do is present an argument. He's not a judge, nor would he want to be.

Text: Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun." Teenager with a love for endurance sports WANTED: Sports-enthusiastic training partner for a triathlete, preferably female. Opportunity to train with a potential Olympic champion. Must be very interested in distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (enjoys winter training in cold rivers), and distance cycling (likes 100km rides). Ability to do all three without resting is essential. The triathlon is becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. Recently, it has attracted large crowds who are fascinated (and shocked) by athletes swimming 1500m, cycling 40km, then running 10km without stopping. It's exciting for spectators, but what makes the triathletes want to push their bodies so hard? And why would a 17-year-old girl with excellent academic results give up everything for the challenging experiences it offers? Melanie Sears hasn't yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction, mental challenge, and higher goals that most athletes use when asked similar questions. "You swim for 1500m, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you freeze. When the 40km cycle ride is over, you have to run 10km, which is a long way when you're feeling exhausted. But it's great fun, and all worth it in the end," she says. Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section - but then I was the only junior taking part. It seemed so easy that I was waving at my teammates as I went around." Full of confidence, she entered the National Championships, and although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she didn't place. "I was following this man and suddenly we came to the sea. We realized then that we had gone wrong. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried all the way through the running." But she did not give up and is determined that she never will. "Sometimes I wish I could stop because then the pain would be over, but I am afraid that if I let myself stop just once, I would be tempted to do it again." Such determination draws admiration from Steve Trew, the sport's director of coaching. "I've just been testing her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off and into a wall. She had given it everything, but whereas most people step off when they realize they can't go any further, she just kept on." Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower at cycling. That's why I'm working very hard at it." She is trying to convince her supportive parents, who will cover the Â£1,300 cost of her trip to New Zealand for this year's World Championships, to buy a Â£2,000 bike ("It's a special deal, with Â£1,000 off) so she can try national 25 km and 100 km races later this year. But there is another price to pay. Her intense training sessions have made her a bit of a recluse. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party animal anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to go to sleep. But I phone and write to the other girls in the team." What does she talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, what sort of times they are achieving." Where will all this focus end? Melanie has tried other events. She has tried the triathlon "sprint," for example, where you only have to swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big trouble is, I have no one of my age to train with," she says. Funny, that.

**The Collectors**

Amanda Roy writes about her love for collecting and why many people share this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults participating. It is a world full of passion and excitement. But remember, only collect things you truly love.

Since ancient times, people have collected items. Early humans collected pebbles for their beauty and wore them as necklaces. Today, children still collect stones and seashells for their shapes and colors.

I have been a collector all my life, gathering everything from tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. At six, I went to a school in a remote part of England. My parents took me to a local museum filled with fascinating objects from the past, sparking my interest in collecting.

Many people share this passion for collecting. Some find it gives them control over their lives. For me, it's simply enjoyable. Famous collectors include the Duc de Berry in France, who had a 'room of wonders' with items like coconut shell cups and Oriental china. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. You don't need to be wealthy to collect; I've collected tulip bulbs and china cups with great determination.

I once convinced another tulip collector to give me a tulip I wanted. Sadly, it was later stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching across the USA for different designs. Unfortunately, this collection was destroyed in a house fire, which was very upsetting.

The way collections change hands interests me. A silver spoon once owned by a king or poet gains value. As small items become popular, their prices rise. Toys from the 1950s are now valuable investments, especially if you kept the original boxes. (I, unfortunately, threw mine away.)

**My Line of Work: Four People Talk About Their Jobs**

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**

I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I need to learn about the exhibition topic first and then talk to experts to decide the main themes and goals. I plan what objects and pictures to show. I ensure the public understands the exhibition by planning interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also hire engineers and electricians to make sure the exhibition is safe. Before it opens, I help design and write brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**

I start my day at 7.30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents are needed for learning the routes for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are here, figuring out the best routes using the correct streets and turns. I help when there's a disagreement, like if a right turn is possible at a junction. When they're close to the test, I give them a simple route and then tell them they must find another way because the road is closed. The next student must find a third route, and I give a reason why they can't use it. This is to make them think.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**

I live by the coast and work from home. My job includes answering phone enquiries, creating educational materials, and setting up training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but mostly I am by the coast. I work with schools and study centers and run courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about the seas. I take them out to sea in a boat to help them understand marine life better. This often changes their views, as it is different from making decisions on a computer. I am lucky because conservation is my hobby, so I enjoy my job. The downside is that I work for a charity, so we always need more money. This means I am always looking for more resources and can't achieve everything I want.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**

My work is varied. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and keep stocks of about 300 books we publish. We have high standards for information and content. We get many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which need careful replies. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with an enthusiastic team, which makes the job enjoyable. The downside, like many jobs, is too much administration, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

Text: 'No Title We always went to Ireland in June. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who bought the house, the Malseeds, have added to the building, but everything has been done very discreetly. It was Strafe who found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. 'How about this?' he said one evening and read out the details. We had gone away together the summer before, to a hotel recommended by friends, but it wasn't a success because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time, Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and myself. They call me Milly, though my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school, Dekko Deacon sounding quite good, I suppose. He and Strafe were at school together, which is why we call Strafe by his surname as the teachers used to. We're all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds were before they moved from England to Ireland. Quite a coincidence, we always think. 'How very nice,' Mrs. Malseed said, smiling her welcome again this year. She seems to know when guests are about to arrive, as she's rarely not waiting in the large, low-ceilinged hall that always smells of flowers. 'Arthur, take the luggage up,' she told the old porter. 'Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium.' She referred to the names of the rooms reserved for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors of the hotel instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband handles redecoration and repairs. 'Well, well, well,' Mr. Malseed said, entering the hall through the door that leads to the kitchen. 'A hundred thousand welcomes,' he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling broadly with his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel like more than just another group of hotel guests. Everyone smiled, and I could feel the others thinking that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn, all was well. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. 'You look younger every year, all four of you,' she said, making everyone in the hall laugh again. Arthur led the way to the rooms, carrying as much of our luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but didn't play as long as usual because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man on his own and a French couple. There were other people at dinner, of course, because in June Glencorn Lodge is always full: from where we sat in the window, we could see some of them strolling on the lawns, others taking the cliff path down to the seashore. In the morning we'd do the same: we'd walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee in the hotel there, back in time for lunch. In the afternoon we'd drive somewhere. I knew all that because over the years this kind of pattern had developed. Since we first came here, we'd all fallen in love with every variation of its remarkable landscape.'

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'Isere, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets, that are typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Being a chalet girl isn't a career, she says, but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not live in the chalet. She gets up at 7 a.m. to walk about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests. 'They get everything - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' When the last guest has finished breakfast, by about 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes the afternoon tea, which is left for the guests to help themselves, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m. she is ready to go skiing herself. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day we can be up there until 4:30 p.m.' Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but does not sleep. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says. Dinner, a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming in to a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are happy to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.' Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives - and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night as Sunday is her busiest time of the week. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast with a terrible headache.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, since breakfast for guests who are leaving has to be on the table by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests are gone, Sarah starts cleaning quickly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't already done the week's shopping on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., the cleaning work done, Sarah then prepares tea for the new guests. 'They get here at around 4:30 p.m.' Sometimes they are confused and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a drink later, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says. '

Miss Rita Cohen, a very small, pale-skinned girl, visited Seymour's factory one day. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was six years older. Rita wore overalls and big, unattractive shoes, and her pretty face was surrounded by a bush of wiry hair. She was so small and young-looking that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. Sometimes, he would help a student by answering questions over the phone or, if they seemed very serious, by giving them a short tour. Rita Cohen seemed almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class, who had visited the factory years ago. Marie's father had shown them how he made gloves, especially Marie's favorite part, the laying-off table. At this table, the men shaped and pressed each glove by pulling it over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table, looking thin and flat. As a child, Marie was fascinated by them and called them the 'pancake hands'. Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She took notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. 'They come to the tannery. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they make it into the right kind of leather for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. So did I, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' 'Not yet.' 'Well, you need to visit a tannery if you're going to write about leather. I can arrange that for you if you'd like. They're primitive places. Technology has improved things, but what you'll see isn't much different from hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. It's said to be the oldest industry with remains found anywhere. Six-thousand-year-old tanning relics were found in Turkey, I believe. The first clothing was just skins tanned by smoking them. I told you it was an interesting subject once you get into it. My father is the leather expert; he's the one you should talk to. Start my father talking about gloves, and he'll go on for two days. That's typical: glove makers love the trade and everything about it. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' 'I can't say I have.' 'Never seen anything made?' 'I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child.' He laughed. She made him laugh. An innocent with spirit, eager to learn. His daughter was at least 30 cm taller than Rita Cohen, fair where Rita was dark, but otherwise, Rita reminded him of Marie. The good-natured intelligence that filled the house when Marie came home from school, full of what she'd learned. How she remembered everything, neatly written in her notebook and memorized overnight. 'I'll tell you what we're going to do. We're going to take you through the whole process. Come on. We're going to make you a pair of gloves, and you're going to watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

Text: 'Is it a tough job? Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as wonderful as they seem. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she has to travel around the world at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. There's just one small issue - she doesn't like flying. 'On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to calm down,' she admits. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. 'It felt so closed in with those tiny windows.' When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some routine paperwork - organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel arrangements. She didn't apply for the job. A chance meeting with a pop group's manager led to an offer to work behind the scenes, and she took a secretarial course in the evenings at the same time. Five years later, she was in the right place at the right time when her boss needed a PA. B. David Brown David Brown has been both an accountant and a golf caddy, someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he preferred being a caddy. Well, who wouldn't if golf was their passion? There were some downsides, though. A small flat fee is offered, plus a percentage of the winnings. The average earnings are between Â£25,000 and Â£35,000, and much of that goes on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for the golfer Greg Norman. 'You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge against the weather, and trying to understand the course.' His accountancy skills were recently recognized by European Tour Productions when they made him a statistical data administrator. From cards brought in by the caddies, he compiles and analyzes the statistics of each day's play. The results are wanted by TV commentators, golfing magazines, and the golfers themselves. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to try out what's available in the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants that charge very high prices? 'For those who can afford it, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend Â£120 on a meal I'll remember for the rest of my life than buy a microwave.' His talent as a cook led to the offer of a food column from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. For Martin, who was then a creative director at an advertising agency, it was a useful extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper called to offer him a full-time job. 'It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a profession.' He still does all the cooking at home and tries to keep his waistline under control by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. 'Before that, I always loved words and enjoyed using them, but my writing was mainly poetry. Then I had this idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a kind of role reversal story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them,' he says. 'That's what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not up with the dawn, I'm afraid. After lunch, I spend another couple of hours typing out the morning's scribbles - all of which I do with one finger on an old portable typewriter rather than on one of those awful laptops. I get between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that is the part about being a writer that I enjoy the most. I do try to answer them all, but nowadays I have some secretarial help.'

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust. These golden piles covered the yard all the way to the blue lake. That afternoon, with nothing else to do, all the boys followed Michael up a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed on the sawdust, laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he said, trying to get them to follow him. Laughing, he watched them from the roof, looking scared, but one by one they jumped and got up smiling with relief. In the hot afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust pile telling jokes until one of them said, "Let's go up on the roof again and jump down." They weren't very excited, but they all went up and started jumping off again until only Michael was left. The others were below, calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong with you?" Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed on the edge of the roof, licking his lips, with a nervous smile, wondering why it seemed like a longer drop this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried counting to ten and jumping, but it didn't work. He tried taking a deep breath and closing his eyes. After a while, the boys started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we're going to stay here all night?" they shouted, and when he didn't move, they started to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you all?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for nearly an hour while the sun, like a big orange ball, slowly set beyond the lake. His clothes were wet from nervous sweating. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, fell heavily on the sawdust, and lay there for a long time. There were no sounds in the yard; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump, then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to get home in time for dinner. If you won't come home, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled severity, but Michael, with his dark, gloomy face, hardly heard her; he was still thinking about the boys' grinning faces and their laughter.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job but unsure how to change? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change careers are turning to careers advisers. You will need to write a brief history of yourself and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. These tests help create a summary of your skills and suggest possible careers and any retraining needed.

I decided to try Career Analysts, a large career advice organization. Taking the careers test felt like being back in my science exams. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions quickly. I had to remember it wasn't about passing or failing. The psychometrics involved tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. Afterward, I had a long chat with an adviser who used the test results to create a report with observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of the conclusions, though I was a bit disappointed with my performance in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. However, it was reassuring to hear that I had made the right choice in journalism.

Rethinking your career doesn't always mean a big change. Last March, after working as a marketing manager for a large insurance company for five years, 25-year-old Donna Laney lost her job. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to step back and review my career,' says Donna. Some results were surprising. 'I didn't realize I had a talent for design. But I had to consider the cost of retraining against my financial commitments,' she says. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. 'I decided to use my existing skills and move into something more suitable than insurance. I'm now a Public Relations officer. I might have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped me see clearly what I wanted to do. I've recommended them to several friends who are all happy with the service.'

Some people feel they wouldn't have reached their goals without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services led 26-year-old Juliet Greene to make life-changing decisions. 'After working for a major bank for six years, I found my job dull and needed a new challenge. I had no idea what I wanted, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed I was interested in sciences,' she says. 'I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget many things you say. After the fourth meeting, I decided to study geology and plan to start a degree course later this year. The advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the fee. I'm much happier and more positive now.'

However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says: 'I reached a point in my career where I didn't know what to do next. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I got many new ideas, I rejected them because they required a big salary drop or a lot of retraining. I wasn't told anything about myself that I didn't already know,' she says. 'You have to give the adviser a lot of personal information, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given similar advice.'

**Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you'll notice bright modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit during their check-ups. Jerome explains, "Half of the people only go to the dentist when they're in pain instead of going for regular check-ups. That's because they're scared." To change this, he has created a place where people feel comfortable. That's why he decided not to wear a white coat, as it often makes people think of pain. Jerome believes dental treatment should happen in a relaxed, interesting, and even enjoyable atmosphere.

This idea is surprising for many of us who usually think of dental visits as painful or at least very formal. Jerome says, "If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past negative experiences." One of his new relaxation methods is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first practice in Britain to use them, and they're very popular. The headsets are used during the first check-up, where the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I examine their teeth. Then the headset switches to a special camera, giving the patient a visual tour of their mouth." Surprisingly, most patients enjoy this part of their dental visit.

Another important aspect is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome says, "When people walk in, I want them to realize with all their senses that it's not like going to the dentist's. Smell is very important. The typical dental smell can make your heart race if you're scared of dentists." I found the gentle smell in the office very pleasant.

Although he is known as Glasgow's most fashionable dentist, Jerome emphasizes that he takes his work very seriously. The relaxation techniques are important, but the quality of the treatment is the most crucial thing. For example, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, instead of scraping. It feels a bit strange at first, but as long as people are relaxed, it's not painful at all.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to research dental techniques. "One thing I learned there was that when you make it easier for the patient, you make it easier for yourself," he explains. He sees his patient-focused approach as the beginning of a gradual shift towards less formality in the traditional British dentistry profession.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks him what video he'd like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this five-star treatment, and it's no surprise. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which started in South America, is now a huge global business. At Easter, people in the UK spend over Â£230 million on chocolate. Eight percent of all chocolate is bought during this time. Only at Christmas do people consume more chocolate. Although large-scale chocolate production began in the 19th century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is an evergreen, tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. The fruit of this tree is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans, a misspelling from the 17th century when they were also called cacoa and cocao beans.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water' in their language, Nahuatl. In Aztec times, this chocolate drink was flavored with spices and used for ceremonies and welcoming guests. The Spanish found the drink tastier with cinnamon and sugar, but the recipe didn't spread to the rest of Europe for another century. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses were established in Europe's capital cities, where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the 19th century, the chocolate drink was made from solid blocks of chocolate that had to be melted in hot water. But in 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the crushed beans.

The age of the chocolate bar began in 1847 when a Bristol company, Fry and Sons, combined cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block you could eat. A Swiss company then added milk solids, creating milk chocolate. At the start of the 20th century, the British chocolate market was led by French companies. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville (ville is French for town) to add a touch of French elegance. But then came Cadbury's famous Dairy Milk bar, which started as Dairymaid in 1905. Smart advertising linked it to the healthy qualities of milk from the English countryside, making it a strong competitor to the more luxurious French brands.

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain has stabilized at about four bars each week. This has pushed manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. The latest marketing strategy is the 'extended line,' where a simple chocolate bar becomes an ice cream, a soft drink, or a dessert to appeal to chocoholics tired of regular snacks. Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices at the end of the 1980s. Since most cacao farmers work on a very small scale, many had to close their businesses. Perhaps you could think of them as you enjoy your next chocolate bar.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83, Peter Cooke has mastered his art. He still wants to try new things like paper-making and feather-work, but for now, he focuses on creating delicate and unique objects from shells, a skill he has perfected over the past ten years. "Tell me if I am boring you," he says as he shows me around his apartment filled with his work. There's a fine line between being a bore and an enthusiast, but Cooke is definitely the latter, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to a pair of shell-covered ornaments above a fireplace. "I won't mind if people don't buy them because I've grown fond of them, and to me, they're adorable. I never intended to sell my work commercially. Some friends visited me about five years ago and said, 'You must have an exhibition - people should see these. We'll talk to a man who owns an art gallery.'"

This led to an exhibition in London, where 70% of the objects were sold. His second exhibition opened at the gallery yesterday. Considering the high prices his pieces fetchâ€”around Â£2,000 for the ornamentsâ€”an empty space above the fireplace seems a small sacrifice for Cooke. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at Â£225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Cooke insists he has nothing to do with the pricing and is open about it: he claims no one else in the world makes work like his, and as the gallery owner told him, "Well, you're going to stop one day, and everyone will want your pieces because there won't be any more."

"I do wish, though," says Cooke, "that I'd started this much earlier, because then I could have created really wonderful thingsâ€”the potential would have been there. Although the ideas are still there and I'm doing my best now, I'm more limited physically than when I started." Still, his work is far from the common shell constructions found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he says, resulting in boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, little shaded pictures made from shells, and baskets of astonishingly realistic flowers.

Cooke has developed his own method and uses materials as he finds them. He uses the cardboard from laundered shirts for his flower bases, a nameless glue bought in bulk from a sail-maker ("If it runs out, I don't know what I will do!"), and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just does itself," he says of his working method, yet the attention to detail, color gradations, and symmetry he achieves look far from accidental.

Cooke's search for beautiful, especially tiny, shells has taken him beyond his Norfolk shore: to France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines, among other places where he has searched for treasures to bring home. He insists he only collects dead shells and defends himself against those who accuse him of stripping the world's beaches. "When I am collecting shells, I hear people's great fat feet crunching them up far faster than I can collect them; and the ones that are left, the sea breaks up. I would not dream of collecting shells with living creatures in them or diving for them, but once their occupants have left, why should I not collect them?" If one considers the amount of luggage one man can carry home, the beauty of his work often surpasses the natural parts, making his argument quite convincing.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, you will probably find her studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.

"I'm afraid Kira will be a little late," the receptionist at the agency told me. "Oh, fine," I said, "no problem." I had been trying to convince myself that all the negative things I had read about models were not true, but words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent kept coming to mind. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided a visit to the hairdresser's would be more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she would be rushing. She could be in a bad mood and refuse to answer my questions.

But when the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she was with her mother. Kira was not dressed in expensive designer clothes but in a simple black dress and trainers. There was no sign of a selfish attitude; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under the age of 16 must take an adult with them whenever they work, she explained, and apart from looking incredibly young, her mother was a normal mum - visibly proud of her successful daughter.

Kira seems slightly puzzled by her new fame, which is understandable since it was completely unplanned. It was her older sister who decided that she should enter the model competition. "She saw the competition and said I should go in for it," Kira remembers. "I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway." When the call came to tell her that she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected for the final gave Kira the confidence to go through with it, and she performed perfectly. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London immediately offered her work.

Kira now finds that one of the hardest things she has to do is manage her two separate lives. But her friends and teachers have become used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. However, a few unkind people at her school are rude about her success. "They say I have too high an opinion of myself." This kind of remark must be hard for Kira to deal with, since there can't be many people as successful as her who are less self-important. But she says, "They assume that because I've suddenly become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confident - not in a horrible way, but I'm able to stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, though, her social life is obviously affected. The Select agency can call at any time and tell her that she is wanted for a job the next day. "If my friends are going out together, I can't say I'll come, because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get broken, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"
