Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a fabulous career ahead of her. And not many people can say that before they even sit their school-leaving exams. I am about to finish the interview with the girl who has it all, and I ask what she would like to do as a career if she didn't have the outstanding beauty that seems certain to take her to the top of the profession. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

**Father and Son Search for Gold**

Terence and Chris Madden, a father and son team, have traveled from Canada's cold north to Africa's heat in search of valuable metals. Terence, an explorer, and Chris, a mineral expert, believe their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated."

Their journey began when Terence read about gold worth millions in the "Dolgellau gold belt," near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. They studied 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to choose the best area to explore. After clearing the land and finding small pieces of gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission from landowners, taking earth samples, and removing old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running out of money. They need to find someone to invest Â£50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "At the moment, this looks doubtful, although we've got quite a few people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread, the idea of finding gold excited both locals and gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "It would bring more people here if they are right, but if they find gold, I hope millions don't come and damage the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has declined since the late 1880s when many people worked in numerous mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed recently. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It's adventurous and exciting, the wonder of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University, where she teaches and researches marine geochemistry. This means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. When she isn't teaching, she goes on dives to study underwater volcanoes. She uses a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to dive three kilometers down into the ocean. Inside the vehicle, space is very tight, and she can easily touch the two pilots. They are used to these cramped conditions, where they can't stand or move much, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is an emergency, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. However, no one has tested it yet, and Rachel thinks it might not be a pleasant experience.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship's deck, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would handle being in such a small space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She says two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It flows out at one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel recalls being scared only once, during a dive with an American team. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest parts of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing something no one else has seen before. After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and somewhere beneath all that, suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body couldn't take any more stress. My mind couldn't handle any more foreign timetables, currencies, or languages. "Never again," I said, as I stepped onto home ground. I said exactly the same thing the following year. And the next. All I had to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five years old, I could spend a whole month traveling anywhere I wanted in Europe. Ordinary beds are never the same once you've learned to sleep in the corridor of a train, the rhythm rocking you into a deep sleep. Carrying all your belongings on your back in a rucksack makes you have a very basic approach to travel and encourages incredible wastefulness that can lead to burning socks that have become too unpleasant, and getting rid of books when finished. On the other hand, this way of looking at life is entirely in the spirit of Inter-Rail, for common sense and reasoning can be thrown out of the window along with the paperback book and the socks. All it takes to achieve this carefree attitude is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that enables young people to travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day must be pretty special. On that first trip, my friends and I were at first unaware of the possibilities of this type of train ticket, thinking it was just an inexpensive way of getting to and from our chosen campsite in southern France. But the idea of non-stop travel proved too tempting, for there was always just one more country over the border, always that little bit further to go. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We were not completely uninterested in culture. But this was a first holiday without parents, as it was for most other Inter-Railers, and in organizing our own timetable we left out everything except the most immediately available sights. This was the chance to escape the guided tour, an opportunity to do something different. I took great pride in the fact that, in many places, all I could be bothered to see was the view from the station. We were just there to get by, and to have a good time doing so. In this, we were no different from most of the other Inter-Railers with whom we shared corridor floors, food and water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name. It is as if the city in which you arrive never actually existed until the train pulls in at the station and you are able to see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by actually seeing Europe, by watching the changing landscapes and seeing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles, can you really have an accurate picture of the continent in your mind. Everybody knows what is there, but it is meaningless until you view it yourself. This is what makes other people's holiday photos so boring. While the train trip won't allow you to discover anything new in the world sense, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is a big place, and Inter-Rail gives people the best opportunity to recognize this ... though in our case it didn't happen immediately.

Arriving at an airport in another country and finding out your baggage is missing is very disappointing. At best, you might have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you could be in a different climate, far from home, with unsuitable clothes. Airlines don't often say how many bags they lose, but regular travelers will eventually face this issue. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and no airline can guarantee your checked luggage will be on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes.

Here's how the system works: Airlines require you to check in early to give enough time for your baggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are set to ensure there is enough time to transfer baggage between flights. Usually, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights, causing the baggage system to fail. Human error or accidents, like a torn-off destination label, can also cause issues. These problems are more common at large transfer airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport managed over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, mostly moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing baggage is higher at certain airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to Latin America.

To avoid losing your baggage, choose direct flights when possible and check in early. If you must change planes or want a cheaper flight, try to fly with the same airline. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Include your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.

Text: 'The Kingfisher Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, partly shading the shallow water. Soft greens, mud browns, and the many shades of yellow sunlight are the main colors, as gentle as the sounds of water in the breeze. The bird moves quickly through the scene, like a flash of light and motion so striking you almost feel it. It disappears in a split second, but the image stays in your mind, its impact much larger than its size. Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He cannot explain exactly what attracts him to this little bird, which shows how much he cares for it. The kingfisher is part of legends. In Greek myth, it is a moon goddess who turned into a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became the blue of the sky, while its underside was burned by the sun. There is some scientific truth in this. Despite the many blues in their feathers, kingfishers have no blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light and reflects blue strongly. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green with a slight change in light angle. It's no surprise that some wildlife photographers are so enthusiastic about them. The colors, combined with the fact that kingfishers, though shy of direct human contact, can be watched easily from a hideout, create a lifelong passion. Charlie James's first hideout was an old blanket he put over his head while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat only a meter away. But it took him another four years to get his first good picture. Meanwhile, the European kingfisher began to dominate his life. He spent as much time as he could by a stream rich with kingfishers. The problem was, school limited his time with the birds. So he skipped classes, becoming what he calls an 'academic failure'. But his interest in the world's most widespread kingfisher, the only one to breed in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He then worked as an assistant to the editor and gradually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make the ultimate kingfisher film. 'No speech, just beautiful images that say it all,' he says. 'I'm drawn to the simple approach. I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings ...' His sentence trails off. He's thinking of the bird's colors, which still excite him after so many years. His photographs communicate some of his feelings, but as Charlie knows, there's much more to his relationship with the kingfisher than his work can show.'

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors**

**A. ANNE MANSON**

Anne Manson, 30, had an unexpected start in conducting when she asked to watch Claudio Abbado's rehearsals in Vienna and ended up replacing an absent assistant. She later helped with another opera the next season. "I had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. No, I wasn't nervous. I've always been comfortable in front of an orchestra," she says. Manson, originally from the US, works with a London opera company focused on modern music. She is also gaining recognition in Europe, supported by the British Arts Council, and has assisted Abbado on several projects since then.

**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**

Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of conducting is convincing people to give you opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after failing in two others. Reflecting on this, he feels the timing was right: "If it had happened earlier, I might have disappeared." The competition opened doors for performances and a role as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, Constantine worries about being labeled as a "competition" conductor: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I'll be concerned," he says. "But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, who hired me after the competition, are inviting me back. If they don't, your career can fall apart."

**C. WASFI KANI**

Wasfi Kani, founder of Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods in opera. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," says Kani, who began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's business district until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Starting lessons with Sian Edwards was crucial for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my sizeâ€”I had always been taught by much bigger people, which makes a big difference." She appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to consider the singers' personalities."

**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**

"Conducting came as a surprise, but it's fascinating," says Roger Vignoles, 48. It's not a strange move for him, as he started as a resident musician at an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something new for him. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I tried my best to achieve that. People respect my musical ability. I'm benefiting from all my experiences, both in musical style and performing. Now, I'll do whatever people ask to find out what I enjoy."

**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**

In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, then a young assistant, and mentioned him to his agent. Marshall, now 32, soon found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, a challenging start. He even dealt with musicians reading newspapers during the show: "I was firm with them. I always gave a clear beat and got the best result I could. Many musicians don't seem to need much guidance from a conductor. But I'm not afraid to say what I want. If you show worry, it gets worse. I've never formally studied conducting, and no book teaches you how, but people have been kind to me. I'm determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you want to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many options. We asked five families to try out some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**

Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park lacks atmosphere, and the scenery could be better. But the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He was thrilled with the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings at his height! The older children enjoyed the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is perfect, and the staff are friendly and helpful. There is something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**

After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act that kept us excited. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. For younger children, Toy Land is great fun. The children looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small to go on it! The park is well designed, so even waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are great. On one ride, I couldn't sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**

We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park was only open until 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. I'm usually scared, but even I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and then it was over quickly! I didn't go on the Big Leap, but if you're brave, it looked great. If the children were older, they might have found it a bit boring, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**

The park's advertising says there is 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, stands out, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, although Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for a few of them, but she enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome wasn't always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn't have dared tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women's Stories**

**A. Christine Hogan**  
Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business with a yearly turnover of over Â£200,000 and employs four full-time staff. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Having worked with computers before marriage, her husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. Christine was careful with finances, always informing the bank manager if she might overspend. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. The business remains small, with local clients often collecting their work.

**B. Maggy Sasanow**  
Maggy Sasanow designs greeting cards from home. She says, "I enjoy being independent." After studying art at university, she wanted to work in a museum, but living in the countryside meant no such jobs were available. So, she started her own business, creating 50 different greeting cards sold to museums. She works in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is the constant distraction of household chores. Her business grows through word of mouth, without advertising. People send work from London because she is cheaper than other artists. Although she misses exchanging ideas with others, the benefits outweigh the drawbacks.

**C. Delia Turner**  
Delia Turner runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started eight years ago when the business was growing, and her turnover increased from Â£24,000 to Â£80,000 in two years. She managed six full-time curtain-makers but had to let them go due to economic decline, which was difficult as jobs are scarce in the area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband's help and employs women who work from their homes. Delia is ready to lower prices when needed and explore new opportunities.

**D. Tessa Strickland**  
Tessa Strickland manages the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and her love of the country. She enjoys flexible working hours, though 80% of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, requiring calls at odd hours. The challenge is maintaining discipline to stop working. Tessa publishes children's books from various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt lonely, having gained all her professional experience in London.

**E. Meg Rivers**  
Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop with a turnover of Â£250,000 a year, employing six people, some part-time. She started ten years ago at home, focusing on health by making fruit cakes with quality ingredients. As demand grew from friends and relatives, she began sending cakes nationwide. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made, employing a baker, assistant, and professional cake-icer. Meg no longer bakes herself, managing the business side instead. Her biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, as they started with limited funds.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is unique because not only are the sons talented musicians and composers, but their father, John, also makes musical instruments. When John and Hetty Watkins, schoolteachers from South Wales, needed a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, they found it too expensive. John decided to learn how to make one himself. He attended evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making for about three years. After practicing with violins and violas, he successfully made his first cello for Paul. Paul used this cello until recently, as John improved his skills and made another one for him.

John has now retired from teaching to focus on making instruments full-time, crafting up to twelve violins a year. Selling a violin to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo was a significant achievement for him.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano and then moved to the cello, inspired by a cellist in his father's music group. Huw, on the other hand, chose the piano and composition, finding inspiration in Paul's success.

Paul, now 28, achieved great success with his father's cello, winning the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At 20, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, a position he held until last year. He now plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, on loan from the Royal Academy of Music, which he says has a richer sound due to its age.

Paul will soon perform on television with the Rugeri cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto for the series Masterworks. However, he won't be able to watch it as he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival the same night. Huw, now 22, will also be busy, as his String Quartet will premiere in London at the Wigmore Hall that evening. John and Hetty will have to manage their time carefully to follow their sons' musical careers in the coming weeks.

**Looking after the countryside: THE NATIONAL TRUST**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden employed by the Trust to care for the beautiful areas it owns.

According to Gareth Roberts, a National Trust Warden needs common sense. 'You also need to be good with people because you deal with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building firms all the time.' Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience got him the job, even though he didn't have formal training. 'It's helpful that I still farm with my parents and can understand farmers' problems. Also, they can't fool me about anything!' he says.

His farming background helps him handle the physical work of the job, like building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. 'When I was young,' he remembers, 'I used to collect flowers, butterfly larvae, and old birds' nests. I recently thought, where would I find all those things now? It's clear to me that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' faultâ€”they were just following government advice.'

Gareth says that when he started, farmers and conservationists were against each other. Now they talk and understand each other's views. 'We're close to bringing them together,' says Gareth.

Conservation is a big part of Gareth's work, along with allowing public access to the Trust's land, planting trees, and meeting with the Trust's tenant farmers. 'My job is to make sure tasks are completed efficiently and economically. I enjoy seeing projects finished, although I spend about half my time on paperwork.'

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys it, even though he is never really off duty. He especially likes talking to the public, although he admits, 'Some people's attitudes annoy me. They come in, demand everything, and leave as if they own the place. Being nice to them can be frustrating!' But as Gareth says, it all comes down to common sense. So, if you have plenty of that and like outdoor work, you might consider becoming a warden like Garethâ€”but don't expect a job to open up on the Lleyn Peninsula anytime soon!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is leading England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day before next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down, but that's all."

"My whole life now is about being at my best for the Championships," says Kendra. "I'm on a strict schedule to get as fit as possible." These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. "We'll have home support, which is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will have expectations and give more support. People will expect us to start the tournament well."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they'll be exciting to play. They have lots of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra points out, the World Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself to play each day, there's no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different because there's only one chance."

In the fifteen years she has been playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. "You don't train so hard not to win," says Kendra. "But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We're all friendlier after the game."

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "It's essential that we all think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. "As captain, I think it's important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team."

"From the start, my netball career has been carefully planned," she says. "I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening candlelight ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How should parents handle a child with exceptional musical talent? It's not always easy to know the best way to nurture their gift. Some parents might not even notice their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and difficult. While most schools can support children who excel in academic subjects, musically gifted children need special attention that regular schools might not provide, especially if music is not a priority there. These children, along with those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school.

In Britain, there are five specialist music schools, which are relatively new. These schools offer a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen to fully develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend one-third to half of their day on musical activities, such as individual lessons (up to three hours a week on their main and secondary instruments), playing in orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and learning music theory. They also practice for several hours daily in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, though students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students are boarders, meaning they live at the school full-time, which allows them to grow up with peers who share similar goals and interests.

What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; boarding fees range from Â£12,000 to Â£17,000 a year. However, schools try to help parents of exceptionally talented children with scholarships and financial aid. Another concern is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors question the wisdom of admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop 'rounded and well-balanced individuals.'

There is a risk that separating musically gifted children from an early age can cause stress. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to a sense of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and offer support if needed. While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some are concerned about the limited academic program, which is secondary to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, feeling frustrated if their intellectual needs aren't met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide for themselves before considering specialist education. Those who are also academically gifted might thrive in a less specialized environment, such as a school with an excellent music department or by combining regular schooling with musical training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with top teachers and opportunities for orchestral and chamber music experience. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from major cities like London.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden, full of her favorite flowers like tulips and poppies, provides many of her painting subjects. Some plants grow wildly, spreading seeds everywhere. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors and shapes, especially along the flower borders that line the path from east to west. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left plants that Susan liked. She also inherited their gardener, Danny. Susan says, 'It was really his garden. We got along well. At first, he would say, "Oh, it's not worth it" about some plants I wanted, but when I explained I wanted to paint them, he understood.'

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they grow, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. 'I don't set everything up at once,' she explains. 'I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another one, building the painting slowly. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.' Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. 'They all bloom together, and you're so busy,' she says. She is also fascinated by how flowers change as they decay. For example, with tulips, 'you put them in water, leave them for a day, and they form different shapes. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem boring, but they change with twists and turns.'

Susan has always loved plants. 'I studied botany at school and collected wildflowers from the countryside,' she says. 'I wasn't interested in gardening then; I didn't like garden flowers because they looked like fake ones sold in shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they grew in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs.' Now, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they seem at home there. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like an aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of subjects to paint, she finds it hard to work in the garden. She has hired another gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her work, 'you have to get your hands dirty.'

**Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy**

A chalet girl's work is never done, as Sarah Sutherland-Pilch explains to Veronica Lee, while she juggles making beds and cooking delicious meals. This is Sarah's second year working as a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, she works for a company in Val d'IsÃ¨re, France. Her job involves cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses called chalets, which are typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She says being a chalet girl isn't a career, but it's a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week."

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests. "They get everythingâ€”porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants." After the guests finish breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea, which the guests can help themselves to, or cleans the rooms, which she says is "the worst part of the job." By about 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. She skis as much as she can. "On a good day, we can be up there until 4:30 p.m."

Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before starting, but she does not nap. "It's fatal if you do," she says. Dinner, a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and loads the dishwasher. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning." Sometimes she stays and chats with the guests; other times, they prefer to be left alone. "Good guests can make a week brilliantâ€”breakfast this morning was great funâ€”but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well."

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. "We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's, and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening," she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day of the week. "A frightful day," she says, "when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast feeling exhausted." Work starts earlier than usual on Sunday, as breakfast for guests has to be ready by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests leave, Sarah starts cleaning quickly. "We just blitz the placeâ€”clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready." If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests. "They arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are disoriented and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them." Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It's soon time for dinner duty again and maybe a chat with friends, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night," she says.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

**Mandie Currie**, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, but here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job isn't stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking I'd usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested in how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there."

**Alice Cutler**, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, but maybe in Africa."

**Karen Hodson**, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, joined the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, I don't see daylight because of my shifts. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn't include hard work or careful planning. I'm more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my job."

**Charlie Dimmock**, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I might faint, but I was surprised it didn't bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important than nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't exactly pleasant, but it was satisfying."

**Lucy Harvey**, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and I felt differentâ€”people looked up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."

**Sonia McDermott**, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was worried about this swap because I don't exercise. I was amazed at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, you meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see some trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. However, it inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journey Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to return as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast that crosses into Italy. It takes you past some of the most amazing sea views. No matter the weather or time of year, it is always enchanting. Out of the other window, you see some of the best gardens and homes in France. You feel like you're peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The travelers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I've enjoyed many rail journeys over the years, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which runs across the desert in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I owe a lot to one train: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I've worn the color ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after the wedding preparations.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There wasn't a road, so we took the Desert Express. The timetable was unreliableâ€”we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days to depart if he knew people were still on their way. When it appeared, hundreds of people climbed into and onto the carriagesâ€”people even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I've ever seen. It was like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite impressions of trains when they are young, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most filming took place on an old, disused line maintained by volunteers. That's where my passion for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could, and when I returned last year, it was as if time had stood still. Everything was still in place, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Trying to get published? If you're wondering where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has the advice you need. Readers often ask, 'I have written this story/book. Can you tell me who to send it to?' The first thing to know is that you should research your markets and learn about publishers while improving your writing skills. Turning words into something sellable requires knowledge about the 'writing game'. Whatever you write, you need to understand the markets you are targeting. The best way to do this is by reading everything relevant you can find. Use your local library and visit bookshops and newsagents. Reading widely will guide you on what kinds of writing publishers are accepting at any time. This knowledge must be updated as new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. New titles come and go all the time. Publishers are always looking for new talent; as writers, we must give them what they want. At first, you may not be sure what you want to write. Let's say you want to write short love stories. The first thing to do is find out which magazines publish love stories, a limited market these days, and get recent copies. Familiarize yourself with the stories they buy, noting who the readers are. These readers expect different things from their magazine, and the editor focuses on their needs. Writers often send me their stories saying, 'This has been rejected three times - am I wasting my time? Do I stand a chance?' As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone. But it's unlikely the work is ready for publishing; I try to give an honest opinion, but always positively. The problem is most new writers are too eager to send their work out, often before they are ready. If you've only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. That almost never happens. When you hear about 'success', you usually find the person has been in publishing or journalism for years before their success. When you send off your work for the first time, start on more work while waiting for a reply; write ten more stories, even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you'll start to think of yourself as a writer, and your fluency and confidence will grow. Don't throw any of them awayâ€”improve them instead. Also, I advise not showing your work to anyone else, especially in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. See if there's a creative writing course near you. If not, join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writingâ€”every day if possible.'

On the last day of a difficult year, I was at the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. The station was busier than I expected. Usually, it felt airy and clean, but now it was crowded. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and college students sat on the floor with their bags. A well-dressed, grey-haired man was walking around, talking to strangers. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her something. Then he came to a girl near me with long blond hair. I had thought about talking to her myself. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" She replied, "I'm going north, yes." "But to Philadelphia?" he insisted. "No, New York," she said. "Thanks, anyway," he replied and moved on. Now, he had my full attention. I heard him ask an old lady, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" She said, "Wilmington," and he moved on to another couple. I stood up and moved closer, pretending to look at the train platform. I was going to Philadelphia, but he didn't ask me. I understood why; I probably seemed unreliable to him. He glanced at me and then walked to the other end of the waiting area, looking stressed. "Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" She looked up, about thirty-five years old, like a schoolteacher. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." "Could I ask you a favor?" he asked. I stopped a few feet away, pretending to check my watch, though I didn't have one. The woman seemed cautious. The man noticed and said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" My train was being announced, and people started moving toward Gate E. I heard the man explain, "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. She forgot her passport. She called home from the station in Philadelphia, not knowing what to do." The woman listened sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet, waiting to see where this was going. "I told her to stay put, and I would find someone here to take her passport," he continued. It seemed suspicious. Why didn't he go himself if it was so urgent? "Why don't you go yourself?" the woman asked. "I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair," he replied. This seemed like a weak excuse to me. I looked at them. The man held a padded envelope, not a plain one, which would have been more logical. It seemed stapled shut. Be careful, I thought to myself.

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, a famous TV chef.

I believe everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was perfect for what I wanted. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother going to work in a factory and me feeling upset because I was left alone. With that in mind, I thought, 'We want time for family life.' My wife focused on taking care of the children and did all my accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant back then, and we always made sure to have meals together. This has been very beneficial for our children, Gary and Joe. They're both very confident. From a young age, they would come down and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life.

Gary was quite energetic as a child. We had a corner bath, and when he was about seven, he thought he'd jump into it like a swimming pool and knocked himself out. When he was older, he had to work for pocket money. He started with odd jobs, and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had plenty of money at school. He was disciplined. He used to wake up even before me in the morning. If you run a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping out. Gary wasn't very academic, but he excelled in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as good as any of the men working there, and sometimes he was even left in charge. He would produce over a hundred meals, and from then I knew he'd go into catering because he had that talent. So when he came to me and said, 'Dad, I have to do work experience as part of my school course,' I sent him to a friend of mine who has a restaurant.

Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. Who knows what will happen to the cooking if the music becomes successful. My advice to Gary would be: if you try to do two things at once, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can achieve. He understood when I said to him: 'Gary, if you're going to get anywhere in life, you've got to do it by the age of 30. If you haven't done it by then, it's too late.'

Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new studentsâ€”who are usually complete beginnersâ€”were given what's supposed to be a morning's work. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He'd prepared everything. That's my son for you! In the end, he was helping other people out. None of us can believe how successful Gary's TV cookery series has become. I'm extremely proud of him. I've always tried to tell him that if you want something, you've got to work very hard for it because no one gives you anything. He's seen the opportunity he's been given and grabbed it with both hands. You know, you talk to your children as they grow up, and if they only take in ten percent of what you've told them, you've got to be happy with that. The things Gary says, the things he does, I think, well, he must have listened sometimes.

Finding an affordable flat in Dublin was as difficult as finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a flat, that often worked. But for Jo, who had just arrived in Dublin, there were no personal contacts, no one to inform her about a vacant bedsit. So, she stayed in a hostel and searched for a place. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She never questioned why she was going. Everyone at her school assumed she would leave. Who would stay in a small, remote town? That's all she heard for years. Everyone wanted to leave, experience life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family would help them settle. But none from Jo's year were going to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed permanently in the hostel, which was run by nuns, ensuring her safety. Her father hoped the hostel was warm, as they were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. But Jo didn't know they were still thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It offered 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that they would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive. There wasn't a queue because it was more 'Third Girl Wanted' than 'Flat to Let.' The mention of 'own television' made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, clearly a failed applicant, was coming down the stairs. 'Desperate place,' she said to Jo. 'They're both awful. Common as dirt.' 'Oh,' said Jo and continued climbing. 'Hello,' said a girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, "Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear," in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?' Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Jo noted with surprise that Pauline was a punk. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but hadn't talked to one before. 'I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I called about the flat.' Nessa said they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs; one said 'Nessa,' one said 'Pauline,' and the other said 'Other.' 'We'll put your name on it if you stay,' she said kindly.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them at seaside marinas, in movies, and on TV. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on their decline.

Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, understand human emotions, and make us dream of freedom in the wild seas. TV shows like "Flipper" and "Seaquest" have made us love them even more. But these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas today. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000.

You might think such popular animals are protected by law and live in special marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could become a major wildlife disaster. There are forty different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two live far out at sea and are rarely seen. We know little about them. The large grey bottlenoses and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show signs of stress.

Dolphins' complex habits make it hard to know why their numbers are falling. Overfishing, which reduces fish stocks and threatens local fishing industries, also threatens dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are overfished in one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing methods use huge nets that float or are pulled quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show they were caught in these nets.

Waste and other substances in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them, and they accumulate in their bodies. Female dolphins then produce milk rich in pesticides, passing the poison to their young. There is a recorded case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's milk.

Perhaps the most controversial threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels four times more efficiently than in the air. This may disturb dolphins in ways we do not yet understand.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels chaotic. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but it's really good for you. There are many reasons to exercise and very few reasons not to.

Exercise makes your muscles stronger and changes your body shape quickly. It increases muscle power and helps you stand or sit with good posture. Good posture is how you hold your body. Exercise also prevents muscle imbalances that can cause injuries. It improves your heart, lungs, and blood circulation. 

You might have heard these reasons before and feel bored, but here's something new: exercise can help with depression, tiredness, and sleep problems. It also helps control stress and can relieve some medical conditions. 

If these reasons don't convince you, common sense should. Exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise like aerobics, jogging, and weight training. Be careful not to train too hard or with too much weight, as it can cause injuries. Start slowly and consult your doctor if you're unsure.

Good posture is important for improving your body shape. A stiff or sagging body looks unattractive and lacks energy. If you slouch, imagine a helium balloon pulling your head up. This helps you breathe better and makes your body look slimmer. 

Stretching your muscles improves flexibility and helps prevent injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine and should be done slowly and carefully. The best exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home comforts for months? The search for the perfect shot. Among all the creatures in the jungles and plains of East Africa, two of the hardest to find are producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. They are currently in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has experienced six months of almost continuous rain, leading to unexpected problems. Newman explained that they had to buy an expensive tool so that whenever one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their partnership has produced some of TV's best wildlife films, like their well-received film on leopards. Even while this film about Africa's shyest cats was being shown, they were already back in the wild, this time following the equally shy jackal. This is common in television partnerships. Travelling film-makers have been exploring the globe to capture exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke to Newman about their partnership during one of his rare visits to a safari lodge. 'We do have occasional arguments but we tend to get over them quickly,' he says about his colleague. Neither sees themselves as the leader, and he says they get along well because they both view animals similarly. 'When we are on the move, we set up our tents each night. But this time we have a more fixed camp, and since we start at 5 a.m. each morning, we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask.' Their daily diet consists of pre-packed meals heated by whoever is available. 'It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks at a time, so catering can cause some panic,' says Newman. It can be a tough life, but being alone in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals and become part of their lives. Newman recalls filming a family of lions where one lioness would regularly greet their car as part of her routine. Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift', and two years later, they teamed up to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they start, they must submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I developed a good working relationship from the start,' says Newman, 'because we shared the same ideas and vision. We aim to create films rich in atmosphere, capturing the true spirit of the place and animals, and touching people's hearts. I believe evoking an emotional response is better than appealing only to their intellect.'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra leads England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day leading up to next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised about her training location. 'Don't people stare?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she replied. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's it.'

'My whole life is about being at my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. She follows a strict schedule to reach peak fitness. These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. 'We'll have home support, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will expect us to start well.'

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have a lot of talent.' The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra notes, the World Championships will be challenging. 'You have to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, there's only one chance, and you must be ready.'

In her fifteen years at the top level, the sport has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. 'You don't train so hard not to win,' says Kendra. 'But after the final whistle, we become different people. We're all friendlier after the game.'

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. As captain, she believes it's important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. 'I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team.'

'From the start, my netball career has been carefully planned,' she says. She decided some time ago that this competition would be her last as a player. She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she goes into a steel vehicle, about the size of a small car, and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, space is so limited that she can touch the two pilots. They are used to these conditions, which mean they can't stand up or move, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours gathering rock and water samples, and then three hours to return to the surface.

If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can hit a panic button. The outside drops away, leaving a small circular escape vessel that gets released, and it quickly goes to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant journey.

Rachel didn't know how she would react the first time she climbed into the vehicle. It was on the deck of a ship, and she got in with an instructor. He explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were testing her to see how she would react in such a small space. Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. On the ocean floor, there is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effect of a program that would make a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When she isn't at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she loves, but she does it so she can continue her research into the "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It pours out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.

The only time Rachel was frightened was when she first went down with the Americans. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when there was an explosion. There was a loud bang as the shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought, "I'm going to die." They stared at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, they couldn't believe it. The relief was incredibleâ€”they were still alive!

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees those chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. She studied the black smokers for three years for her Ph.D. When she finally saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, how fast or slowly we talk, our volume and tone of voice, and the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I finally graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she recalls. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I always think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. One of her friends, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher's only comment was, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says: "Interviewees who look as if they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should aim to come across in the best possible way." Yet many people ignore the importance of having a professional image.

For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but wasn't even given an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what had happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before I applied again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."

Movement and gestures also influence an interviewer's first impression of a candidate. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian discovered that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from the words we use, 38% from voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and our words send different messages, the listener will trust the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words agree with your body language. Mixed messages will only confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to appear too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job on the spot. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted to the offer with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss sensed how excited I was, he knew I wasn't going to turn him down. Consequently, he offered me a lower salary than I'd hoped for. I'm sure I could have got more had I managed to control my excitement."

Finally, what we say and how we say it will contribute to the success of an interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests that it's a good idea to learn about the company before you go for an interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about areas of company involvement. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will give a positive note and convince others of your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests you have a few questions ready and avoid speaking in long, confused sentences. As she puts it, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City went from being exciting to a grindâ€”no one was having fun anymore. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but then I was made redundant unexpectedly. The payout wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the top 20 hotel restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not stuck in an office anymore, but it's surprising how little has changed: I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. The career counsellor I spoke to was surprised when I said, 'I don't want to go back to where I've been.' Most people in their mid-forties need to return to work quickly for financial reasons. But we married young, and our children didn't need our support. Moving to the north of England, where we knew no one, was a leap into the unknown. We left our friends, but our friendships have survived the distanceâ€”many visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**  
After five years as a company lawyer, Katherine Goodison started her own business in her London flat, making hats for private clients. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more, so I left. People said I'd get bored, but that hasn't happened. The secret is having deadlines. In fashion, there are collections, next year's styles, the seasonâ€”there's always too much to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I do miss socializing with colleagues, though. What I love about this job is being fully responsible for the product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care when working for a company, but when your name is on everything, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but never found the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year instead. During that year, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners about starting up. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That's the best part."

Text: 'Dedicated to their sports Four young sports stars talk about their lives. A Darius (runner) I've always loved sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and athletics. At 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose athletics instead. My proudest moment was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped for sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home in winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun there with great facilities and nightlife. But you must be disciplined. If friends invite me out before training, I have to say no. I wish I didn't, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to reach the next Olympics - that would be amazing. B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so you meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so you have to avoid late-night parties. I don't mind that much, but I love sleeping in, which I often have to skip. It's worth it, though, because without dedication, I might not have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I celebrate with a big night out, and if there's prize money, I go somewhere nice. The sacrifices are worth it because winning the championship got me a TV show about surfing. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now. C Dieter (yacht racer) With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and always celebrate a win in style. Some say we act childishly when out, but we don't seek media attention. Reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come back, hang out with friends, and do normal things. You can't focus on the sport all the time - it's not healthy. I'm known in sailing, but I've only been recognized in public a few times. I'd hate to be a celebrity. I get nice letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to each one. It takes time, but it's worth it. D Tomas (tennis player) It's great to feel the crowd's support when I walk on court. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people crowding around. Still, I enjoy being recognized by fans when I'm out shopping. It has downsides, though. My last girlfriend didn't like the attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up, I think. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in any sport; you must be serious and professional. It doesn't bother me much. I'm happy to focus on my game now and enjoy other things in life after I retire, which comes early in this sport.'

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her children want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't afford all these things and feels guilty if she gives in to their demands, as she believes it's not good for them. However, she also feels bad for always saying no and worries that her children aren't learning how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. Over Â£150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and arguments about health don't seem convincing compared to the appealing ads they see.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertisers and often end up disappointing their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy, so the effect is the same.
