Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse can be stressful for parents. One mother says she discusses food with her children and has taught her son to be critical of ads. They now have fewer conflicts in the supermarket because her children don't ask for things she won't buy.

Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses. Mike, a father of two, says they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they're unhealthy, yet they buy treats for themselves. He finds it hard to be consistent, as his decisions depend on his mood.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering supervised play areas for children. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without their demands could attract more customers.

**Five-star luxury meets modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took nearly two years to convert four large eighteenth-century houses into this luxury hotel. This transformation allowed the installation of the latest technology for both staff and guests. General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but for specific preferences, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system, which cost Â£250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible due to the guest-history feature that records preferences.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests worldwide. At the Merrion, a high-tech system allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the standard 18Â°C. Additionally, the front desk can adjust each room's temperature between 14Â°C and 25Â°C. Business travelers, who are expected to make up 65% of the hotel's clientele, will appreciate the technology in their rooms. Each room includes three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. To keep up with fast-changing technology, extra cables have been installed for future upgrades. Televisions are rented, not bought, so they can be easily replaced with newer models. DVD recorders can also be updated when needed.

Despite all this advanced technology, the hotel aims to make guests feel comfortable and not overwhelmed. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, and welcoming. The hotel also features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. As with all luxury hotels, excellent food is essential. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his business to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He designed a modern kitchen and enjoys better parking facilities. The hotel gains a popular and successful restaurant without financial risks. With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is set to succeed.

Text: 'Where I get my energy Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share their secrets. A. Jeanette Kupfermann Journalist and author: 'I think it's excitement. I need to be doing something challenging. When I'm learning something new, I feel a lot of energy. Anything with rhythm gives me energy, too - right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing. Dance is wonderful, very expressive, and energizing. I think you can feel tired if you're bored or feel life has no purpose. Being effective in the world - even in a small way - gives you energy.' B. Linda Kelsey Magazine editor: 'I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it all - I love being at work, it's not a chore. If you enjoy something, it doesn't make you feel down even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep, so when I get it, I feel great. When I only get six hours of sleep a night, I feel a bit off. I know exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to find the energy to do it! I do a yoga class once a week before work and try to do a workout tape at home. But if I've exercised, my mood improves a lot. I feel very low in the office between 3 and 5 in the afternoon and think it's probably good to eat something then.' C. Annie Nightingale Disc jockey: 'I don't eat healthily to get my energy - I think it's natural enthusiasm and being positive. I really can't stand people with negative attitudes. I'm quite naive - I think we should all enjoy our lives, seize the moment. Enjoyment comes first. You have to achieve things and set goals. I enjoy what I do, and the last two years have been very exciting. In my job, there are lots of lively young people, and you can't help being affected by that. I love rushing around for work, having a busy life. I'm very sociable. I enjoy taking photos but I'm not sure if I'm good at it. I rush to get them developed and can't wait to see them. I've also started writing words for imaginary songs - it's just for fun and a good way to relax my mind when I'm traveling.' D. Floella Benjamin Author and children's TV presenter: 'My energy comes from the things I do and enjoy. I believe in what I'm doing, both at work and at home with my family, and I think being positive about life helps. That's why I love working with kids; they give so much and have a natural resilience. Energy is like a natural chemical, triggered by communicating with others - just try smiling at people and feel the thrill when they smile back. It's much better than feeling sorry for yourself. Although I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, I don't have an exercise plan. The most energetic I get is running around with the kids and playing with them.' E. Deborah Moggach Author and playwright: 'What I love doing more than anything is making a garden out of a wasteland. I did that once. The garden was solid concrete - I broke up all the concrete and added lots of soil. It was better than any workout or tennis. The other thing that gives me energy is knowing someone wants to read what I'm writing - I find it hard to write without an audience. And I like sneaking into a farmer's land or a wood. If I'm caught, I say "Oh, what a wonderful wood, I didn't know it was private," and so on. I like it because it's childlike.' F. Katherine Monblot Therapist: 'I believe you must have an interest in and respect for what you do in life. I like to take risks and I get bored quickly, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don't want to do wears you out. I used to be a member of various committees and resented the demands they made on my time. You only have a certain amount of energy, so direct it into the things that are most important to you.'

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, the upper classes considered skating an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was elegant and reserved. However, at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both graceful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed comes with practice. Your body position is important for balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to center your body weight; this means leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It seems simple, right? As you practice, you can gradually make longer movements.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should learn. Even professional skaters fall. To avoid injury, try to stay relaxed when you fall, which reduces the impact. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you can move confidently on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance, so you can quickly learn basic figures and then move on to turns, jumps, and spins.

If you watch good or professional skaters, you'll notice how relaxed they are and how smoothly they move. To achieve this, you should regularly practice exercises. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should include those for the legs, back, and shoulders, focusing on the ankles and knees. After a long or intense session, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It benefits heart and lung health and strengthens the body. Combined with swimming or jogging, it offers a great program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Triumphs**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can be very emotional. Julia Gregson spoke with three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges in their lives.

**A. Annika Reeder, 15**

Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She dreams of becoming a physiotherapist and competing in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard right now. I don't have time to watch TV, hang out with friends, or do much besides gym and school. I try to take training one day at a time. When I'm extremely tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I just keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."

**B. Annika's Mother**

"Annika showed great potential from a young age. I've seen parents push their kids, and it doesn't work. To perform at Annika's level, you have to want it yourself. People often say we've sacrificed a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who sucked her thumb and hid behind me. Now, she's met people worldwide and gained confidence from her success."

**C. Sarah Stokes**

Sarah started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of itâ€”I love the excitement and fun. Even without my parents, I would do it because I'm determined. I'm glad they are happy when I win, but I'm not doing it for them. My goal this year is to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

**D. Sarah's Mother**

"Sarah's passion for horses started when she first sat on one at age 1. At 5, she would get up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, you have to compete all over England. To save money, we sleep in the horse box's living area. Sarah is well-organized and 100% happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is unbeatable."

**E. Jane McShane, 10**

Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around and don't think too hard. I'm not worried about getting a big head; I don't talk about my success at school. I don't like feeling embarrassed."

**F. Jane's Mother**

"Jane played her first chess game at 5. My father said, 'Let's see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. Of course, I'm pleased when she wins, but if she wanted to quit tomorrow, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to discourage her because she's exceptional. If she has this gift, let her reach her potential."

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point because Chris, at fourteen, was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by another centimetre. Every year, more truly tall people are born. Interestingly, this does not mean we are creating a new super race. Instead, we are returning to our ancient size. We are losing the effects of generations of poor diet, with dramatic results. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived 40,000 years ago.' For most of history, our ancestors got food from many sources: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate 85 different wild plants. Then, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented, with serious consequences. Most green areas have been taken over by farmers, so just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories we eat today. This poor diet has harmed human health and growth. Over the centuries, we have lived on soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought a blessing, was a health disaster, according to some anthropologists. However, agriculture spread because farmed land could support ten times more people than hunter-gathering. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished has only recently been addressed, even by wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets now reflecting the richness of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. It is a positive trend, though not without problems. Heights have risen, but the world has not changed much. A standard bed-length has stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have shrunk, while clothes manufacturers constantly revise their products. The question is: where will it end? We cannot grow forever. We must have some upper limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, it could be as much as 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. However, scientists add a note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller - an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies keep heat better.) Since the climate warmed, we have become thinner and smaller, even when well-fed. As the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink further. In other words, human growth could be offset by global warming.'

**Studio Audiences: What It's Like to Be in One**

Have you ever wondered what it's like to be in the audience when a TV show is being filmed? Cosmo Landesman explored this experience. Studio audiences are a regular part of TV production, yet they remain a mystery to many. When we see them excited on game shows, we often wonder: who are these people?

Studio audiences are sometimes seen as the least prestigious of all live audiences. Some people in the TV industry even look down on them, treating them poorly. I used to think that studio audiences were just people eager for a brief moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience. They come from all walks of life, including different classes, jobs, and income levels. TV shows try to attract various types of people for different programs.

For those of us who enjoy watching TV at home, it can be hard to understand why someone would want to watch a show in a studio. Why go through the trouble of getting tickets, traveling, and sitting for hours in an uncomfortable studio when you can watch the same show at home? One idea is that people hope to appear on TV, even if just for a moment. I didn't believe this until I met Angela, who said she came for the chance to be on TV. Another reason might be curiosity about how TV shows are made. But the most common reason I heard was simply that a friend gave them a ticket.

Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. We imagine sitting tightly packed with strangers, following signs that tell us when to clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, "We always hope a show is good enough not to need these signs."

Is there a real difference between watching a show in a studio and watching it at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," while Charlotte enjoyed feeling part of live TV. "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. Watching him live is different from seeing him on TV at home," she said. Personally, I missed seeing the live actors because my view was blocked. The opening scenes were so far away that I ended up watching them on a studio screen.

Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most people in the audience, it was simply a fun and free night out.

**Favourite Places**

**Bruce**  
I don't like landscapes that are completely wild. I find the human touch important. It's the same when I travel abroad. I am attracted to lovely villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would cycle to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling was a way to escape school. I loved exploring the bleak hilltops, the sheltered valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape familiar yet different, and I still visit today. I used to write about my adventures in my private diary. In a way, that was my first attempt at travel writing, which later became my career.

**Sophia**  
There is a miniature railway from Hythe to Dungeness, run by amateurs. I always travel first class as it doesn't cost much more than the regular fare. The scenery is not spectacular. The train moves across Romney Marsh with its sheep and alongside a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when our miniature world takes a detour through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers see people at random points in their day, making a cup of tea, doing the washing up, unfolding a deckchair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage, looking into other people's homes. It's the ordinariness of the landscape that attracts me. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. That makes me look more closely, to search for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a remote and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and scattered with rocks, so there are not many crowds here. They attract a few brave surfers, but most visitors prefer to reflect on the majesty of the sea. The coast, which faces the Atlantic, is known for shipwrecks. There are coast walks you can combine with trips inland up beautiful damp valleys, full of oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in modest self-catering accommodation with a family who have some property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favourite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a landscape of wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There are not many residents and not many visitors either. It's an unknown corner, empty and remote, and I like the feeling of space. I discovered the area by chance when I was a student, and since then I've made an annual visit, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has changed little since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It makes me sad that he's growing up in an urban environment.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favourite house in Britain. It was about finding pure peace and reconnecting with my English roots and coming home. I grew up in what is now known as Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to cycle around the moors and village backstreets. We had a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's the place of my dreams. It's a magical, secluded, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are a family that loves animals and enjoys being around them. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work, excited because she had found a pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked. I agreed, but only for one night. We had a special tank for temporary animal guests, and one night was enough to admire them and check our natural history book.

I got home late and started cooking when I heard screams from my sons' bedroom: "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed in to find Domino, our cat, with Bianca, a white mouse given to me as a Mother's Day gift, in his mouth. Domino was running around the room, trying to escape with his catch, while the kids waved their arms to stop him. I jumped into the chaos and tripped, landing on the floor. As I considered how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake escaping from its tank.

The room was a mess of cat, mouse, kids, and snake, with the dog barking loudly. I quickly turned off the boiling pot in the kitchen and returned to the chaos. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the mouse, which was unharmed. Interestingly, this mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived to old age.

Feeling confident, I turned my attention to the snake. It was not easy to handle, but I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, trying to calm it. Eventually, the snake relaxed, and I carefully lifted it. I took it to the end of the garden, hoping it would choose to live in the garden shed. When I released its head, expecting it to attack, it instead wrapped around my shoulders like a shawl, seeming comfortable.

We stood there, my four children, the snake, and I, in the evening light. My eldest, DJ, explained, "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't." We gently encouraged the snake to move on, and it slowly climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, summed it up for all of us: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Drop me a line! In our fast world of phones, fax machines, and computers, the old-fashioned art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. Yet, for me, receiving a letter is special in a way that no other form of communication can match. There is the excitement of its arrival, the pleasure of seeing who it is from, and the enjoyment of reading it. Letter writing has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I would write to my mother. My mother also insisted I write my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. It didn't matter how short or untidy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I would write once a week, and so would my mother. Occasionally, my father would write, and it was always a joy to receive his long, amusing letters. Most of the letters from home were about everyday events concerning my parents and their friends. Of course, we also made phone calls, but it is the letters I remember most. There were also letters from my boyfriends. In my youth, I seemed to attract people who had to work or study away, and I could only stay in touch by writing. But instead of harming the relationships, letter writing seemed to improve them. I found that I could often express myself more easily in writing than by talking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are appreciated, but how much better to have a year's supply of news! And it's even better when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. My overseas letters arrive from Mangala in Sri Lanka, from someone I trained with over 20 years ago, and I have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. Then there's the lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn't started talking in a restaurant on the way home from holiday, if my husband hadn't taken her photo, and if I hadn't asked her for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn't replied, we would be poorer for it. As it is, we now have a regular correspondence. I can improve my French (she speaks no English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success, however, came this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been corresponding for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was amazed that a correspondence could last so long. The local press even considered it worth reporting on the front page. I am pleased that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother before me, I insist they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends of their own in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly urge readers not to let letter writing become another 'lost art'. '

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Alpine Rock Art**

Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being gradually destroyed. Scientists and researchers are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they might not survive for future generations. The mountain, once a place for prayer and worship, has 4,000-year-old drawings cut into bare rock. These include pictures of cows with horns, cultivated fields, and various gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, wearing away the rock and the artwork. Some visitors even take parts of the rock home as souvenirs. "When people can't take a good enough photograph, they rub the drawings to get a clearer picture," he said. "The drawings are polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them properly, they simply rub and scrape them to make them look fresher."

Other researchers describe how people arrive with long sticks with sharp ends to scratch their own drawings or even their names into the rocks. But experts disagree on the best way to preserve the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a 'no-go' area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. Otherwise, he says, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research work will be reduced.

Clottes disagrees. "The measure proposed by Henry de Lumley is the most severe, and while it is the most effective, it is also certain to bring about protests from people who live there," he said. "The site was classified as a historic monument years ago by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do as much as possible to save what is there."

David Lavergne, the regional architect, also wants to avoid closing the site. "Henry de Lumley's idea isn't ideal," he said. "Our department feels that the best solution is to let people look at the site, but because the area is very big, it is difficult to prevent visitors from damaging it. I would prefer that everyone was able to look at it, but the main problem is financial. We do not have the funds to employ the necessary number of guards. We may have to consider charging a fee. There seems to be no prospect of government funding."

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who also worked on researching the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reachâ€”tourists can now avoid the three-and-a-half-hour walk by hiring vehiclesâ€”the damage will increase rapidly. She thinks the only solution is to rope off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't go ahead because there is no money," she said. "That is not good enough. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we don't take steps, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for the next generation."

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not the latest sugary breakfast cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't afford all this stuff, and if I give in, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get stressed even before we leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make their own choices. I can't win."

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. More than Â£150 million a year is spent on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things, and arguments about health don't seem convincing compared to the attractive ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with advertisers and having to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But as Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' that's still the effect they want."

A big stress for parents shopping with children is deciding which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads, so they don't ask for things she won't buy. Parents also admit they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of two, says, "We say no to sweets because they're bad for him, but we buy chocolate for ourselves. It's nice to buy treats, and it's normal for children to want them too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on my mood. If I'm feeling good, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering play areas for children. Even if parents spend less because their children aren't with them, the idea of shopping without a child's demands might attract more customers.

**Going up the wall**

In the past, climbers went to mountains. Now, challenging climbs can happen anywhere, indoors or outdoors. The crowd is silent. High above them on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by two fingers, is French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is more famous for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common - The Wall. The possibility of these events is due to new and fast-developing technology.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were many good climbing spots. In winter, they either braved the cold, went walking, or climbed on snow and ice in Scotland. As the sport grew, it became important for top climbers to stay fit. With cliffs unusable for much of the year, they used brick edges or stone buildings to train. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom from not climbing.

Soon, many sports centers started building walls specifically for climbing, using bricks with special edges to grip. Many of these early walls followed the example of Don Robinson, a physical education teacher who, in the mid-1960s, built a climbing wall in a corridor at Leeds University. Robinson had the idea of setting natural rock in concrete blocks, which could be part of a wall. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls across the country in the 1970s, but they had design problems. Walls could only be vertical, while real cliffs have features like overhangs and angled slabs. Another issue was that once built, the walls couldn't be changed, and climbers would get bored with the same holds.

In 1985, a Frenchman, Francois Savigny, created a material that he shaped into forms like those on cliffs. These could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted a new challenge. French manufacturers also started experimenting with panels on a steel framework. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls without major construction, but steel frames could be set up anywhere as free-standing structures. A system of interchangeable fixtures gave climbers endless new holds.

Text: 'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will probably say it's 'risky' very quickly. And acting is indeed a risky career. There are more actors than there are jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some people you thought were your friends might say you're crazy, but others might react differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But it's a personal choice, and only you can be responsible for achieving your dream. There are no easy paths - no exams to pass, and no guarantee that after your training, you will succeed in the profession. It's all about luck and talent. However, there is a need for new faces and talent, and there is always the chance of excitement, glamour, and sometimes big rewards. People often ask me to define talent, which everyone is looking for. I think it's natural skill plus imagination - imagination is the hardest to judge. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing and how you present it. Why do people want to act? It's often hard to explain why you want to act. In theatre, the important thing is the moment of connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is central to all acting and motivates actors. If you ask actors how they succeeded, they might just shrug. They don't know. They know some things about themselves and their techniques, but they take nothing for granted because they know they are only as good as their current job, and their fame might not last. Disappointment is the actor's biggest enemy. Last month you might have been out of work, selling clothes or waitressing. Suddenly you get an audition, but even if you want the job badly, you might not get it. So actors often don't talk about their chances. They find ways to protect themselves from the stress of competing for a role and the possibility of rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. And remember, the possibility of rejection is there from the moment you start auditioning professionally. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. And, in many ways, it's up to you, because if you don't care enough, no one else will care for you.'

**Food for Everyone**

We are excited to share our special selection of top cookbook titles now available.

**A. Delia Smith**

When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from all over the world and show her love for exciting food. She understands what the average cook can do in a regular kitchen. Her book, *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, is a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple yet expert advice on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of excellent recipes. Recently updated, it remains the go-to book for anyone asking, "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"

**B. Raymond Blanc**

Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur, untrained chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His first TV series, *Blanc Mange*, is accompanied by a book of the same name. Raymond aims to make us better cooks by explaining how and why ingredients behave as they do. He believes good cooking is easy when you understand what's happening in the pan. The book includes over 80 impressive recipes and serves as a practical guide, explaining why some dishes fail and introducing basic food chemistry. Raymond loves cooking to entertain, and this book shows he's excellent at it.

**C. Le Cordon Bleu**

Le Cordon Bleu is synonymous with the best in classical French cooking. For over 100 years, this famous cooking school has trained students to achieve perfection. To celebrate its centenary, the *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook* presents 100 of the school's most respected recipes. While the recipes are classics, they remain fresh and have adapted to modern tastes by reducing rich, creamy sauces. The book starts with kitchen basics and continues with sections on Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step images and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have contributed their famous recipes and shared their secrets.

**D. Nigel Slater**

Fast food? Not necessarily bad! Nigel Slater, food editor of *The Observer*, challenges the idea that good food requires long hours in the kitchen. His book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes you can make something tasty in the time it takes to deliver a pizza. This new book offers over 200 enticing recipes from around the world, all ready in 30 minutes. Written in his lively style, Nigel proves that fast food can also be great food. If you're skeptical, try his recipesâ€”they're simply delicious.

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point because Chris, at fourteen, was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by another centimetre. Each year, more very tall people are born. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we are creating a new super race. Instead, we are returning to our ancient size. We are losing the effects of generations of poor diet, with significant results. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived 40,000 years ago.' For most of history, our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate 85 different wild plants. Then, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented, with serious consequences. Most green areas have been taken over by farming, so now just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories we eat today. This poor diet has harmed human health and growth. Over the centuries, we have eaten soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought a blessing, was a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists. However, agriculture spread because farmed land could support ten times more people than hunter-gathering. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets now reflecting the richness of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it has its own problems. Heights have increased, but the world hasn't changed much. A standard bed-length has stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have decreased, while clothing manufacturers constantly update their product ranges. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot grow forever. There must be a natural upper limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, from the University, it could be as much as 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. However, scientists add a note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller - an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies retain heat better.) Since the climate warmed, we have become slightly thinner and smaller, even when well-fed. As the planet continues to warm, we may shrink even more. In other words, human growth could be offset by global warming.'

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but then I was made redundant unexpectedly. The pay-off wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the top 20 hotel restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not stuck in an office anymore, but it's surprising how little has changed: I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. The career counsellor I spoke to was surprised when I said, 'I don't want to go back to where I've been.' Most people in their mid-forties need to return to work quickly for financial reasons. But we married young, and our children didn't need our support. Moving to the north of England was a leap into the unknown. We left our friends, but our friendships have survived the distance, and many visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**

After five years as a company lawyer, Katherine Goodison started her own business in her London flat, making hats for private clients. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more, so I left. Some people thought I'd get bored, but that hasn't happened. The secret is having deadlines. In fashion, there are always collections and seasons, so you need a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I do miss social interactions with colleagues, though. What I love about this job is being fully responsible for the product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the promotional material."

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but never found the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year instead. During that year, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That's the best part."

**Onto a Winner**

Two brothers are discovering that a childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two brothers in their forties with bushy beards, are in their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, remembering their childhood. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing the old game of pichenotte, which they say is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and introduced it to his family. Soon, the family played the game almost every weekend and holiday, and as Dave says, they were 'having the best time ever'. Eventually, the family moved to New Mexico. But they didn't forget Grandpa's pichenotte board, made from old wooden food crates, and continued to play often. Visitors were often intrigued because the game was unknown in southern USA. 

Three years ago, Dave noticed the old pichenotte board was cracked and worn, so he decided to make a new one. It turned out beautifully. A relative saw it and wanted one, then a friend wanted another. Curious about the interest, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. 'People started to watch,' says Dave, 'and say, "No way I'm playing that silly game." Then they'd sit down, and soon you couldn't get them up from the table!' When people asked about the game's origins, Dave researched and found its roots were likely in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' exists. It was adapted into a game called 'squails' in Britain, and British emigrants brought it to Canada a century ago. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec.

Pichenotte, played by two to four people, is a game of skill. Each player gets 12 pieces or 'pucks'. These are 'flicked' across a wheel-like board using the middle or index finger. Flicking a puck into a small hole scores 20 points. Three rings around the hole are worth 15, 10, and 5 points. Eight tiny posts are obstacles. The game usually lasts two minutes. Seeing its popularity at the Santa Fe bar, the Lagasses made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money was exchanged, and the game's popularity grew. Championships began, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly. The brothers decided to make pichenotte their full-time business. They set up a workshop in their garage and started producing boards. Over 450 have been made so far. Made of birchwood and mahogany, each board weighs 12kg and is 1cm thick. Norm explains, 'They're very durable, as they have to stand up to lots of wear.' They sell for $595 each on the brothers' website. There are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, but the brothers hope their garage will one day house a luxury car instead of tools and wood. Until then, they enjoy playing the game they believe will bring them success.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it's hard to believe that just a few years ago, this was a piece of waste ground, flat and covered with brambles. For years, it was seen as useless land. The careful planning and hard work of one man, with constant support from his wife, transformed this land into the masterpiece you see today. Many thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat site into the sculptured landscape you see now. Although bulldozers and digging machines helped, it also required a lot of hard work. Once shaped, about 1,000 tonnes of topsoil were brought in to create the lawns, flower-beds, and rockeries.

In creating the Model Village, hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted. These had to be carefully chosen for the area. Only plants that could handle the salty air near the sea and the strong winter winds could be used. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some came from as far as Canada and New Zealand.

The whole village was designed by Colin Sims, and the models, over 100, were individually made by him over nine years since the village first opened in 1972. The models are made from various materialsâ€”stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plasticsâ€”to withstand all kinds of weather. Initially, Colin needed help from experts to understand how different materials would last in changing weather, but he soon became an expert himself. You will notice that a constant scale has been strictly followed, and even the smallest details on the models have been carefully made. This was achieved through patience and unique construction techniques.

The Model Village has become a very popular attraction, known for its high standard of workmanship and maintenance. The techniques used here have been used in other model villages around England and are even taught in some college courses on modeling. All the model buildings in the village show traditional British architectural styles and are not based on one specific place or structure. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone structure with a brick tower and stone walls, based on the style of manor houses in the West Country. As you walk around the village, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, the latest addition to the village.

We ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch any of the models; a slip can mean hours of repair work for us. Photography is allowed from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome on a short lead. To enhance your enjoyment, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press these to make the models operate. At the end of your visit, we welcome any comments you might have. New models are always being planned, and your ideas can help us create a more varied and interesting display. We also want to know if any models are not up to the standard of the rest of the village. We are continually updating the models and need to know which ones need attention. We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about it.

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the editors' code of practice. Although pop stars sometimes pose for paparazzi, this is not common. Usually, these photos cause great harm to public figures when their private moments appear on the front page. However, very few people use the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization set up to handle such issues. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. Do intimate photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has previously complained about long-lens photos, and since she was in a hotel, where there is a 'reasonable expectation of privacy', she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't take any action. It is scandalous that the PCC did not investigate on its own. It should also look into the recent outrageous story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take the lead on these and other shameful attacks? Initially, this seems like a good idea. It would likely result in many decisions against newspapers, reported by their rivals and broadcast on TV and radio. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as it would no longer be financially viable to wait for unsuspecting celebrities. If the PCC decided to act as a 'police officer', which it technically could, there would be several challenges. How would it decide to start an inquiry? Should it encourage the victim to complain? And if the person still refused, should it continue anyway? Additionally, celebrities and royalty might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. Above all, the role is too large. How could the PCC realistically monitor all of the British press: national, regional, and magazines? Then there is the embarrassment factor. No matter how seriously someone's privacy has been invaded, would they want the further embarrassment of an investigation? Most people likely want to move on with their lives. Some may have other reasons for staying quiet. A worse story might exist that they have kept from the press, and they fear it could become public if they complain. In other words, even the PCC might become the enemy. A British comedian also suffered when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, nor more recently, when his family was photographed during a holiday. He feared that the newspaper, News of the World, would re-run the pictures with a new story about his 'fury', claiming it was just a bit of fun and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Text: 'There is a lot of advice for college graduates starting their first job. In this article, we will talk about moving to a second job. We are not talking about those looking for a second temporary job while searching for a permanent one. Nor are we talking about those leaving a bad job in the first few weeks. Instead, we will focus on those of you taking a real step in your career, choosing a job that matches your goals now that you have some experience, skills, and an idea of where you want to go. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to ask yourself if you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to higher responsibility, or change to a different field. Whatever you decide, choose your second job carefully. Plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow and give you more responsibility. By the way, if you want to travel, now is the time to do it. You can do temporary work when you return, and then get your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again. Juliette Davidson spent her first year after leaving St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a perfect first job because 'OK ... they were very supportive. I learned about office work and improved my word processing skills. However, there was no room for growth. One day I quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.' Juliette now works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. 'In two and a half years I have become more capable and my job has really grown,' she says. 'From the start, my boss wanted to help me develop. My job title is the same as when I started, but my duties have changed. From mostly typing and phone work, I now handle most of the correspondence and budgets. I also deal with various questions, from chairmen of large companies to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda involves me in all her work and gives me specific projects and events to organize.'

Confident people: what's their secret? Confident people might seem like they were born that way, but most will say it's a skill they learned because they needed to. Nina Hathway asks five people how they became confident.

A Jenny: When I left school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At twenty-five, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I didn't think I could do it, but I surprised myself by doing well. Someone there suggested I take a university course. I was very nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew, and I became more outgoing. Working at the school was a turning point in my life.

B Michaela: It started four years ago when my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive and impatient. I thought that's how confident people acted, but I learned otherwise. To be confident, you have to believe in yourself. If work gets too demanding, I don't feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When faced with something difficult, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you lack confidence, so I talk to myself to set aside those fears.

C Lisa: People think I'm very confident, but the calmer I look, the more terrified I am. I had to learn to look confident because it's important in TV. Interviewing people helped me see that most of us get tense in important situations, and we feel calmer when we talk to someone friendly. The best advice I got was from my mother when I worried about wearing the right clothes. She said, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone's too busy worrying about themselves.' I also think you gain confidence by facing things that scare you. I was nervous for my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I would never be that frightened again.

D Barbara: My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but it's something I've built over the years. If you keep going and learn from mistakes, you're more confident next time. I work hard and am popular in the restaurant, but maybe one out of ten people doesn't like me. I don't let that bother me. You have to like yourself for who you are, not try to be what others expect. My company offers training courses, which have built my self-esteem. They also encourage setting manageable goals. It helps to achieve something tangible rather than aiming too high and ending up with nothing.

E Kim: After college, I worked as a secretary and would sit in meetings, not always agreeing but too scared to speak up. Eventually, I found the confidence to make my point. When I first worked in politics, I had never spoken in public and would shake with nerves. I told myself, 'Don't be silly. People do this every day, so you can too.' I found it helpful to jot down notes, like a comfort blanket. I don't think anyone isn't a little nervous about public speaking. The real secret of confidence is telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.'

**Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled as I gave him his torn kite. "You should keep it," he said. "It's a traditionâ€”if the line breaks, finders are keepers. Besides, I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. Each kite was exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat next to them under the shade of the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, looking at Malaysia's biggest kite festival. In the center of the beach were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A row of competitors, holding their kite lines, waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites soared into the sky like rockets. Over 500 men and boys had registered for the competition, which lasts five days each year. Each participant entered four different kite designs, judged on decoration, stability, and flying efficiency. "Flying kites isn't hard," said Adnan, "but making them requires real skill. Visit me at home, and I'll show you how it's done." I accepted his invitation, one of five I received that day. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large room. As night approached, he invited me to return the next day to help rebuild his kite, but my plans didn't allow it. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur into mountains covered with lush rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the road ended at a river. A boat was there to ferry people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my attention. It pointed up a path into the forest and read: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." It would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who managed a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay, trying not to think about insects under my thin mattress. The night was completely dark, filled with various sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was a stunning view of five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind, then lightning hit the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the large butterflies avoided the heavy raindrops. I also worried about my car being swept away (it sometimes happens) and the risk of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But they were very friendly. Kelantan might be famous for its kites, but I remember it more for its kindness.

**What kind of shopper are you?**

Everyone shops, whether they like it or not. But people shop in different ways. Do you know what type of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people ...

**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**

I'm a shopping addictâ€”I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I'm out shopping, and it keeps me happy. I find it hard to ignore sale signs. My boyfriend is just like me, so we often shop together. We're an addicted couple!

**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**

I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he wants. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and rarely tell my husband the real amountâ€”I always say I spent less! The real price always sounds too high.

**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**

I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and only go when I must. When I do, I know what I want and won't settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring and there's always something else I'd rather do.

**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**

I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and get in and out quickly. I do have some mistakes hidden in my wardrobe, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes makes wrong choices!

**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**

I don't enjoy shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy, everything is messy, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I rarely have to shop for clothes because most of my clothes are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish it quickly!

**F. Lisa, 22, actress**

I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out to look around the shops with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I'll buy it.

**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**

I'm a careful shopperâ€”I like going, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and rarely go overboard. Sometimes I shop to cheer myself up, but I often feel worse because I've spent too much!

**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**

I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on a Saturday because it's too busy. I'd say I'm a careful shopper. I always have a good idea of what I want, and I never buy things immediately. I have to check other shops in case I find a better dealâ€”it takes me ages!

**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**

I'm an unwilling shopperâ€”maybe because I work in the city center, the shops have lost their appeal for me. When I have to shop, I'll drag myself out, but I don't try things on because it's too much trouble. Clothes I buy don't always fit, but I don't mind too much. I'd rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of effort shopping!

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE Like any other university, the Open University offers degrees. However, you can continue working while you study. It can also introduce you to a wide range of interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the new experience of gaining knowledge. You will meet many different people. Your qualification might also lead to new career opportunities. You don't attend lectures at the Open University; instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer software. You can choose to attend one class a month at an Open University center if you want. Of course, there are exams to take, just like at any university. If you want to learn more, simply fill out the form below. It could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**

During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about "Surprises." The quiz sheets are free and can be picked up at the Orange Street entrance. Children will be guided to 14 surprising paintings and asked questions about them. The quiz is available during normal gallery hours from 25 March to 9 April.

**New Picture**

The Gallery now has a beautiful still life by the Dutch 18th-century painter Jan van Os. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) of flowers and fruit is painted in light, bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for such paintings to have two dates because the artist waited for different flowers to bloom in their seasons to paint them. This picture was generously donated to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. It is now on display in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**

The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" opened in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery recently acquired works by three Spanish painters from this period: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus of the exhibition. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain during these years - Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition runs until 31 May.

**Lecture News**

The series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will discuss the work of Melendez. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will lecture on Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often "tell a story" through their pictures.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**

The Gallery is pleased to announce that the restaurant now offers an improved and expanded service. With new kitchens, the restaurant provides a wide choice of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**

Free guided tours of the Gallery take place every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest pictures and showcase the entire range of the Gallery's collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning serious cooking. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay Â£280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Class member Bill, aged ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora is twelve, and she's having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby, instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always as tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents interest their children in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

The Outdoor Centre charges a fee for a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. Fees must be paid at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organisation that provides outdoor sports and recreation for everyone. Groups should inform the centre before their visit.

Windsurfing - One-day course
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Beginners can use boards with small sails. Course fee: Â£32.50 (includes all equipment).

One-day adventure course
This is a great opportunity. Try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course introduces outdoor activities to adults in a fun and relaxed way. You donâ€™t need to be very fit or have experience. Just be interested. Course fee: Â£22.50.

Play Park
The Play Park is for children aged two to ten. It is one of the best in the country. It has sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

Group day and residential courses
We offer day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us regularly. There are three large rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked in advance for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

Summer adventure holidays (for ages 8-14)
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We ensure that all children only do activities suitable for their age and abilities. Children must be able to swim 25 metres and be in good health for this programme.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN KEEP GROWING**

Millions of people of all ages enjoy a hobby that is both interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collection and find an interest that can last a lifetime. Starting your collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. Holiday postcards from friends, birthday cards from aunts, and letters from pen pals can all give you stamps from around the world.

Once you start collecting seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You can receive these in three ways: we can send you a complete set of stamps on an envelope addressed to you, send the same stamps in a colorful information pack with interesting facts, or send you the individual stamps to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you could become one too. A two-year membership costs just Â£5, and there is a discount if a group joins together. This is great value for money. When you join, the Club sends you a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This includes 100 stamps to start your collection and an attractive box to keep them in. You also get a helpful 4-page guide to collecting, with more suggestions on how to add to your collection and useful addresses of shops and businesses that sell stamps.

Every two months, you'll receive a copy of the club magazine. It is full of competitions and quizzes and gives you the chance to exchange stamps with members around the world. Why not start an adventure that will give you years of pleasure? You'll spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for unusual ones that are out there waiting to be found.

Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and discover the fun and excitement of stamp collecting. To join, simply complete the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will be sent within 28 days of receiving your application.

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the franc are like units of measurement, such as a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money like we do today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr Green the farmer would trade the corn he grew for Mr Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' to make trading easier. These different currencies eventually started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

**Write a Winning Story!**

You could win Â£1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky winners will receive a cheque for Â£100. We are looking for people who can write great stories. The judges, including Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing, want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like, but here is some advice to help you:

**Write About What You Know**

This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most people who wrote for us followed it. Love, family, and problems with friends were the main topics. However, you need to make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read them. Write about everyday things in a new and surprising way.

**Get Your Facts Right**

Don't describe a town or explain how something works if you are not sure about it. Only write about things you know well.

**Hold the Reader's Attention**

Make the beginning interesting and the ending a surprise. A bad ending is the worst. Develop your story carefully and think of something unusual for the end.

**Think About the Characters**

Make the people in your story come alive for the reader. Use well-chosen words to make them seem real.

Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. Even if you are close to the deadline, we cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, and the story must not have appeared in print or recorded form, like on radio or TV, anywhere in the world. Your Â£5 fee will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist mentioned in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured his daughter received the best education possible. This was unusual because most women at that time had few chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and began teaching mathematics. She quickly became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. Although we have no copies of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented several scientific tools to assist her work. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and anyone connected with it was in danger. One day in March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometres long and goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in the east at Peterborough and ends at Wansford, which is next to the main road. There is a 2-kilometre extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the current western end of the line.

**Fares:**  
- Adult: Â£10.00  
- Child: Â£5.00  
- Family (up to 2 adults and 3 children): Â£25.00  
- Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**

Nene Park offers golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. It's a great place for a family day out. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**

Wansford Station has a unique collection of historic trains from Europe. This includes the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can also see '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower', which were built in Britain. These engines are on display all year, even when the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are open only when the train is running. There is a site entrance fee of Â£2.00 for adults and Â£1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**

Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. For example, it was used in the James Bond movie "Octopussy." Come and see where it was filmed.

**Services for Schools**

From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do while visiting or back in the classroom. An educational pack is available for Â£1.50 plus postage. At other times, school groups can hire the train ('Teddy Bear') with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Bookings should be made one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more pupils. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**

The Railway is a popular place for family events or company visits. It can provide an interesting afternoon or evening out. Special programmes can include a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, etc. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 different types of grasses, and they are found everywhere on Earth. They are the only flowering plants that can live in the cold environments of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands support many kinds of animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals depend on grass in some way. Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This allows large groups of animals to live in one area. Once they have eaten all the grass, new grass starts to grow, providing a fresh meal.

Text: 'The Young Achiever of the Year Kal Kaur Rai has always loved fashion and recently won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards.
