Since she was a child, she has been drawing clothes and designing patterns. She never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make her hobby a career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After graduating, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to go to industry events but couldn't afford the designer clothes she liked, so she started making her own skirts and tops. Her friends loved her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. She found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. Her clothes were very popular, and nothing was returned. This success encouraged her to leave her advertising job, take a Â£20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear label. Kal's parents were not upset about her career change and promised to support her, which made her very happy. Her clothes are now sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns over Â£500,000. Her designs appear in fashion magazines, she creates clothes for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning this award. Her business has grown a lot, and she feels very fortunate. 'What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this.''

Text: 'SUNNINGDALE HOTEL The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has offered excellent service to people from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed at Sunningdale. The hotel is located on a main road leading to the town centre. It is about 20 minutes by bus from the town centre, and buses to many other parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Guests should avoid buses with the blue sign Express on the front because they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 metres away. The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally-heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of all corridors. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos available for guests to use. There are parking spaces in the hotel drive. Daily newspapers are free, and stamps can be bought at the office. Guests staying for long periods must pay for their accommodation weekly in advance, and one week's notice is required for departures. Both short and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are: breakfast 7 am - 9.30 am; lunch 1 pm - 2 pm; dinner 5.30 pm - 7 pm. During the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm for those studying or working late by writing your name on the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices available for breakfast and dinner. No animals or fires (for heating food or the room) are allowed, and guests are asked to respect others' comfort. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. Guests are advised to use taxis to reach the hotel if they arrive by train, as it is some distance from the main railway station.'

Text: 'Tom Cruise Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in cinema history. However, his life hasn't always been easy. As a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends, even though he loved being in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each film. Today, Tom still acts in movies and remains very popular with his thousands of fans worldwide.'

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometres. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and the cat were hungry. He gave her some milk and started asking questions. He called his last customers, but none of them had lost a cat. It was getting late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. Meanwhile, the cat's owner was also trying to find her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbour. Luckily, he remembered the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned.'

Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in northern Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train crosses Australia from the warm north coast through endless desert to the cooler Southern Ocean. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is known for being late. The idea of a rail link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but flooding often made it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, though the food is excellent. The railway was originally for carrying goods, not passengers. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train, instead of by ship, would save time and money. The Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south transcontinental railway. As I waited to board, everyone seemed excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners eager to board. Our first stop was Katherine, where the Ghan waited four hours. Some passengers took a boat trip up the gorge. I left the train at Alice Springs for a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, so we walked around it and watched the sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop here. After Alice Springs, the view from the train is mostly flat land with cattle. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey ended, and although the train might not have met all the promises of the advertisements, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

Climbing to the top of Britain

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is so far north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We planned to climb the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is six hundred metres high and is probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow can be so hard that it feels like walking on ice. Even though some of us were very experienced, we packed all kinds of safety equipment, like lights to attract attention, hard hats, and extra clothing. The weather forecast was perfect, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The path soon became steep, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that I would always train properly before a climb in the future. After 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only a metre and a half wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of metres on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and all the way to the island of Skye, 48 kilometres away. However, we weren't so lucky because a mist had come down. On Ben Nevis, getting back down to camp can be as challenging as going up. You need to read a map properly because a wrong turn could lead to slopes that are too dangerous to go down in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns doing that job. That first time, I only really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we have just moved into our new school building! It's an amazing place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like our old school. However, this new school is one of the first in my country to be very environmentally friendly. It took months to build, so we watched the whole process. It was exciting to see the builders clear the space for it, although it meant losing some lovely open land. The noise from the building machines was very loud, and the builders often had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are huge - much bigger than in our old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town when they need it for meetings. There's also a nursery, a lovely dining room, and big changing rooms that we are excited to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, one of the first things you notice is that there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from us - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed to keep all the heat inside - and the sound too, so if we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we're in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is that the school roof has a tree on top! The builders put it there because it's a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It's so big that it can be seen from miles away! We took some pictures to put on the website.

Even though we are already using the school building, some parts still need to be added. For example, we are putting on a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are so happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now that we are in it!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever thought about joining a book club and buying new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many members already buy books from us this way.

**To join:**

Simply send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:**

As a special offer, you can choose any reduced-price books from our new members' book list, up to a total value of Â£6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you save money on the publishers' prices. Tick the box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift, carefully chosen from our book list by our staff. You can also order a DVD from our list at half the recommended retail price.

**When you've joined:**

As a member, you'll save between 30% and 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, and they will be delivered straight to your door. You will receive a free club magazine once a month, keeping you updated with the latest best-sellers. Each year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. On the Internet, you can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

**Being a member:**

All we ask is that you choose four books during your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want. In each monthly club magazine, our experienced staff select a Club Choice bookâ€”a fiction or reference title they think is worth buying, offered at a special price. If you do not want this book, just indicate this on the form. We will send the book if we do not receive your response.

So, return your application form today, but hurryâ€”offers like this are rare. To apply, simply fill in the enclosed form and return it in the postage-paid envelope provided. Soon, your books will be with you. Please don't send any money now; we will send you the bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. You can then either return the books or send your payment.

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never imagined that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation wasn't great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places and none of us knew the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure exactly what we would do. Half of us spent the morning caving while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out - covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside were my cheque book, address book, and purse, which had about Â£50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn't know what to do: I'm 72 years old, I was far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong, and I explained what had happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what had happened, he said I should keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the telephone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had my handbag and offered to drive over to return it. I got my handbag back, amazingly with all its contents untouched. I want to say how wonderful everyone was who helped me that day and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Text: 'Sharks Sharks are some of the most frightening creatures in our oceans. They are well equipped for hunting underwater because they have excellent vision and can sense movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous for smaller sea creatures that become their prey. Although sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, their bodies are different. For example, unlike other fish, most sharks need to swim constantly to breathe and stay alive, so they rarely sleep. Additionally, if sharks are turned over on their backs, they can stop moving completely. This is a useful technique for researchers who often need to handle sharks. It allows them to learn more about these fascinating creatures.'

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet I'm Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov Ballet School in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I felt nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone gathered around me, asking questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they started speaking English, so we could communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late at night once because I felt lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes in Russia are very hard, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This makes me confident that I can meet the school's high standards. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends. Now that I've settled in, I feel really at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was so cold. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10Â°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy. Right now, we are preparing for a new production, and there's also a competition for young dancers that I'm going to enter. I feel so lucky to be here.'

THE ICEHOTEL

For many years, people visited the Arctic in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. In winter, however, only a few people lived there, enjoying the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, people started to see the cold winter as something positive. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, some foreign guests thought it would be interesting to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and this led to the idea of an ice hotel. Today, it is famous worldwide.

When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As soon as one part is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is complete. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outside using natural winter materials, the completion date can change depending on the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts.

Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5Â°C and -8Â°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Warm clothing like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the cost of staying at the hotel. Guests should also bring sweaters, a scarf, and plenty of wool socks. It is best to wear shoes that are larger than usual to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit, you can buy warm sweaters, wool socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange bus transport from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle, a new furniture shop, had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for Â£45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for Â£30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The shop's regular hours will be 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had said it would stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening. A police officer who was called to the shop said: 'The police knew a big crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The shop filled up quickly, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly until there was room for them inside. Another problem was the long line of cars trying to reach the car park. What surprised me was that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the shop. This blocked the road completely.' One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the shop, said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were very calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. So I'll come back when they reopen, but I won't wait in line again.'

Membership  
The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of Britain's most active arts organizations.

Society Magazines  
We produce several excellent magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine features short stories by some of Britain's top writers and offers many opportunities for new writers to have their work published. Another magazine, Short Story News, includes interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing scene in general. To see articles from recent issues, follow the links on this website.

National Short Story Competition  
We run the National Short Story Competition, the biggest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and short stories on any topic are accepted. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. There is no entry fee for Society members (non-members pay an entry fee of Â£5). The competition runs from April until the end of October each year. The ten best entries will appear in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will receive a publishing contract to produce their own collection of short stories.

Education  
For nearly thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, providing children and teachers with new ideas and building confidence in their writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, started in 1998, open to writers aged 11-18. All winners receive book prizes and are invited to study on a five-day course taught by professional writers.

The Writers' Cafe  
The Writers' Cafe is the social center of the Society. Relaxed and stylish, with freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks, it is the ideal place to look through the Society's magazines. The Cafe also offers monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is located in the heart of London and is open from 11.00 am to 10.00 pm Monday to Friday and 11.00 am to 8.00 pm on Saturday. Society members receive discounts on selected products and events.

Becoming a Member  
We have members worldwide, and anyone aged eighteen or over is welcome to join. If you are interested in joining The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

Free-diving in the Caribbean

Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving, a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on one breath. In 2003, Tanya made history by diving 120 meters deep and returning to the surface without help. She had gone deeper the year before but used a balloon to come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, becoming the first woman to break a man's world record in any sport. Fourteen safety divers watched her dive at different depths. Despite reports of serious accidents with other divers, Tanya believes free-diving is safe if you focus on safety and training.

Most free-divers specialize in one or two types of events, but Tanya's training routine stays the same. She spends two-thirds of her time training on land at the gym, and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees, preferring fast walking instead. When she starts practice dives, she usually travels away from home. She aims to do fourteen dives over four weeks, resting every other day to avoid getting tired, which could ruin her preparation.

When not training, Tanya often appears in public to promote sports products and supports environmental causes by doing research or making films. Growing up on Grand Cayman in the Caribbean, she loved swimming and exploring rock pools. Tanya says her life now is like living her childhood dreams. She is well-known in some countries, so people listen to her about environmental issues. In the future, Tanya, now in her thirties, plans to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and doesn't plan to retire anytime soon.

CARTOON FILMS

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. With new ideas and advanced computer programs, cartoons are becoming exciting again for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, the cinema world thought cartoons were only for children. But soon after, a few directors had some original new ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films where both adults and children could enjoy the fun. However, not every cartoon film was successful. The Black Cauldron, for example, did not do well because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies began to make a lot of money again.

New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first TV role 'I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother always said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I imagined playing her. I took a year off to travel before starting university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to make the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to try for the role. My mother was surprised but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. Filming started a week after university began, so I got permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6.00am to write the essays I missed. I didn't tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I'm so lucky. After university, I want to make acting my career. I'm not from an acting family, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles but haven't received any offers yet. I don't know how I managed everything because I had a busy social life too. When filming ended, I didn't know what to do. I've since acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven't been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends.''

Text: 'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to earn enough money to support my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is an international company growing quickly worldwide. Over the years, I have learned a lot. Much of what I have learned is in this book because I believe our company has valuable ideas about running a successful business without losing our core beliefs. This is not a typical business book, nor is it just about my life. The main idea is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with care, and it can have a positive impact. In business, as in life, I need to have fun, feel a sense of family, and be excited by surprises. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares my ideas with the world and makes them public. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that an exciting thought. I hope you do, too.'

Text: 'A JOURNEY ALONG THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER VOYAGES JULES VERNE offers a 'hotel ship' experience on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, all with outside views and private bathrooms. The ship is air-conditioned and features a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library. Itinerary Day 1 Depart in the early evening from London Heathrow to Oporto. Upon arrival, your guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night. Day 2 Enjoy a morning of sightseeing in Oporto, then return to the ship and depart for Entre-os-Rios. This part of the river journey takes four hours. Day 3 Continue traveling up the river. In the early evening, the ship stops at Peso da Regua, known for port wine production. At dinner, you can taste the local food and drink. Day 4 After breakfast, travel south by bus to the ancient town of Lamego to visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum. The museum, once a palace, has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Return to the ship and sail to Tua. Day 5 Here, the Douro becomes very narrow. Depending on the river's depth, you might continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return journey to Tua is by coach, with much to see along the way. Day 6 In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for one of the best views in the Douro valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take the Douro river valley railway for a scenic ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting. Day 7 Visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch, then head down the river to Oporto. Spend the night on board the Lady Ivy May. Day 8 Arrive in Oporto with time for independent sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.'

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. Honey was very valuable to the ancient Egyptians, who used it as payment. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research suggests that it can help prevent tiredness and improve athletic performance. However, honey is not just food - it can be used for sore throats and is found in many skin and hair-care products.

Norwich, the capital of East Anglia in Britain, has been a place to live for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of England's largest towns. Norwich is known for its religious diversity, with two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself independently.

Today, Norwich is smaller compared to cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second-largest city in England. It continued to grow and became wealthy, known for having as many churches as weeks in the year and as many pubs as days in the year. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. With a growing student population and success as a commercial center, Norwich offers a variety of entertainment options: theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team called 'The Canaries', with green and yellow colors, though the reason for the name is unclear.

A modern shopping center, 'The Castle Mall', is one of the city's attractions. For over two years, the people of Norwich lived with a large hole in the city center as builders worked on the project. Nearly a million tons of earth were moved to create a city center park on the Mall's roof, with water pools and trees. The local people are happy that the old open market remains next to the new development. Both areas are successful, showing that Norwich has combined the best of the old and the new.

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event held every year. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. It started with about a dozen hot-air balloons taking off from a car park in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected at its current location outside the city. What to see The pilots stay in radio contact and light up their balloons' burners at the same time. These are called 'balloon glows' and are great for taking photos. You need to arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am to see these 'glows' as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in all sizes and colors, some shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will love it. In the afternoon, you can take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies offering rides. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a view of the festival from above. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival. The Albuquerque Box This is a local wind pattern that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentler winds at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending. Practical advice Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits to enter the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing. It can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are essential. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, your camera. If you use film, you'll need high-speed film for evening and night pictures.

The Eden Project Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular tourist spots. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this former industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the relationship between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many products we use every day come from plants: wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate, for example. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold the weather is outside, computer-controlled electric heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always damp because of a large waterfall. Another zone recreates the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to build a desert zone soon.

Text: 'No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. Isn't 500 pages of original writing of this quality, for Â£6.99, quite impressive? Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the less well-known writers seem to focus mainly on food. Be cautious with Jane Harris's Those Nails - it's best not to read it right after eating, as it has some very unpleasant scenes that might upset your stomach! There is excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are also pieces from novels-in-progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a bit of non-fiction, featuring a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers, and an extraordinary piece about herself by Ursula Owen. This is an outstanding collection, and I am eager to see what next year's selection will include.'

Text: 'No Title "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "It's the time when you are learning about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, prefers to take students at three and four, although she often makes exceptions for eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old school friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts an hour, once every two weeks. Additionally, each student has one individual lesson a week with her. Parents also need to attend the classes. It is important that the parents show interest in the lessons. From the earliest lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years, and for a long time, there is a big difference between their playing and reading of music. Margaret says that her method is not meant to produce great violinists, and she always suggests that students who perform particularly well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.'

Text: 'Moonshine The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. 'Here Again' follows their previous CD, 'The Waves'. There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now on bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee who left the band last year, and Tom Simpson has joined as the drummer. From the first song, which is a dance tune, it is clear that the band is moving away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later tracks are in the band's usual slow style. These two tracks will surprise many fans, but they could easily become hit singles because they are excellent. Singer Rob Letchford shows his talent by hitting each note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded the songs before he had throat problems, which caused the band to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets need not worry as all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob recovers.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can create perfect music in different styles, from the slow ones we know to the ones that make you want to dance. I felt that the best songs were at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not as good. Despite this, 'Here Again' is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.'

San Francisco San Francisco is located on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, it was discovered from land, not from the sea. In 1849, thousands of people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became wealthy. The richest people made their money by owning banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the former prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting description of everyday life in England between 1660 and 1669. Pepys writes about important events of the time, like disease, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, even about his faults - he often slept during church or looked at the pretty girls. He describes his home life - a quarrel with his wife and how they became friends again, his worry about her illness. Besides books, he liked music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and plenty of fun. Pepys was a busy man who had many important jobs - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work for the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, shoes were not made to be comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely animal skins that people wrapped around their ankles in cold weather. We still use leather today, but other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton are also popular, depending on fashion trends. It was only 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be handmade, but now, although some shoemakers still use traditional skills, most shoes are made by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines allowed the shoe industry to produce many cheaper shoes for more people.'

Text: 'No Title When I hurt my back, I had to stop my running career for a while. I decided to help more women discover running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to give them the confidence to start running. I started a running club for women in my area because I was frustrated with the attitude of many race organizers. They complain about the lack of women in the sport but use this as an excuse not to provide separate changing facilities. I put up posters, and 40 women, both young and old, fit and unfit, joined. They were all interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had really considered running before. When they thought about it, they imagined difficult training. They didn't think about chatting and smiling while running in beautiful places, like by a river. At first, they ran for only a minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They've also learned from other runners about diet and staying fit in general. I wanted to support women's running, and I've enjoyed watching their progress - almost as much as they have.'

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state of the USA. Many people moved there, hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly built and expanded. One of these towns was named Iditarod, meaning 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. During the summer, boats could deliver essential supplies to these towns, but in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making access impossible. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for teams of dogs pulling sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This trail was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a dog team to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers could rest and eat, and feed their dogs. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced steam boats and dog teams as the main transport method. However, the dogs had one last moment of fame in 1925, when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The disease could be treated, but the nearest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were still new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in such cold weather. Also, Carl Eielson, the only pilot skilled enough for the flight, was away. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. The journey covered over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams just six days to complete the trip. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to navigate through the blinding snow, and Togo proved to be a reliable guide. The last part of the journey was completed by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. At one point, Balto refused to go further, saving the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero. Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of that famous 1925 journey. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of JukkasjÃ¤rvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40Â°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit each year to see one of Europe's most unique hotels. In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made entirely of ice. You can even have a wedding there if you wish. The bar is also made of ice, so placing hot drinks on it is not a good idea! The bedrooms are about -4Â°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to stay warm. If needed, suitable outdoor clothing is also available. The hotel is never older than six months because it melts in the summer and is rebuilt each winter. Building the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

Text: 'Maria Mutola In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football in an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. 'We won,' she said. 'At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained.' The story appeared in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who had supported other African athletes, learned about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her playing football outside the club. He immediately noticed she was fast. 'He talked to me about athletics. I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs really hurt.' But Jose visited her parents and convinced them she could succeed and this would help end their poverty. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, she finally accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had refused before because she knew she would miss her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She explains, 'They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot.' Today, Maria still runs, and for most of the year, she lives happily in South Africa with her mother.'

The Skywalk

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. People visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, allowing you to see the beautiful canyon rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of people have visited it. You must wear special shoe covers to prevent scratching the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like you are a bird flying high in the air.

Text: 'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the northwest and extend to areas just a few hundred miles from the center in the south. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are equally impressive. There are many roads through the Rockies, but the best way to experience them is by train. You start in Vancouver, one of Canada's most beautiful large cities. This city is unique because it is located between the ocean and the mountains, allowing residents to ski on slopes just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty passenger trains departed daily from Vancouver on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the journey remains an exciting adventure. You sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, but some of the most stunning scenery is passed during the night.'

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago, when the rulers of China created a large zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In many early zoos, animals were trained to perform for visitors. This no longer happens, as it is now accepted that zoos should allow people to see animals behaving naturally. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos. Supporters of zoos say they give us the chance to learn about the natural world and be close to wild animals, which would not be possible without zoos. On the other hand, some people are against zoos because they think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also argue that in poorly managed zoos, animals live in dirty conditions and eat unsuitable food.'

**JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14**

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions, so the quality of playing was amazing, especially since everyone was so young. Players from each band even made up new tunes right there on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played on stage!

We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to play in it gets acceptedâ€”only about half do. But anyone who is eager to play goes to jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning its language. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country. I've been to a couple and learned a lot.

Adults are often surprised that young people are getting interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for people like me who are serious about music. But I find it exciting because it's both new and old at the same time. You can create your own music, but you also feel you're part of its history, as you're playing on stage like great jazz performers before you.

My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and parents who have supported us all the way. Without them, we'd never get anywhere with our music!

Text: 'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, it doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods, turning streets into rivers. Recently, many winters have been dry, so when it rains, the local people are happy. Marrakesh's parks and gardens don't rely on rain. Instead, they depend on a network of underground channels, dug in the 11th century, that bring water from the mountains all year. Dry places that get water this way are called oases. Further south from Marrakesh is Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels and used to grow food. The Atlas mountains, covered in snow in winter, provide a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis, who is 13 years old, is the youngest child of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined the circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time jobs in a circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus during the summer and return home for the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. "I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving behind our lovely house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." "People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I follow the same books as everyone back at school, and I've got a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." And the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "perhaps Bippo's circus."

Eight-eighteen News Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8-18. We gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to major national and local newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites for publication. The news stories and articles by our members that are accepted can be read or listened to on the Eight-eighteen website. We have three centers across the country where young people can meet other members and join projects, and we plan to open more centers nationwide. Since our agency began in 1994, when we were called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie was one of them. She says: 'I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I was amazed by the opportunities they had. Age wasn't important; they were trusted to do the stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought possible. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, checking articles before they go online.' Get involved at every level When you join Eight-eighteen, you'll receive training and take part in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and over. They train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they gain experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are supported by older staff who accompany them. Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. During the short Antarctic summer, Antarctica Sightseeing Flights takes tourists in a large passenger plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. Flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be moved to another date if we need to change the schedule.

**Questions**

These are answers to the most common questions about Antarctica Sightseeing Flights.

**How long is the flight?**

The flight usually lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the flight, we start seeing the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have lived on research stations in Antarctica give talks about the environment and history, and answer questions. A camera near the pilot, connected to the video system on board, shows you the pilot's view from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, passengers switch to the seat on their second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. While over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to move around the plane so everyone can enjoy the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over interesting spots so both sides of the plane can see the sights well.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 different approved flight routes. Our captain checks the satellite cloud images on the morning of the flight and chooses the route with the clearest views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them clearly. We do not land on Antarctica, mainly for environmental reasons. To see Antarctic wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Yes, you can! All cameras are welcome. We even offer some fun onboard photo opportunities where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning serious cooking. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay Â£280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Class member Bill, aged ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora is twelve, and she's having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby, instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too keen at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always as tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents interest their children in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

Winter Driving

Winter driving is dangerous because it is hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can occur easily. Fog might appear suddenly over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, ready to make you lose control. A car coming towards you might unexpectedly slide across the road. 

Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make a car hard to control. So, when you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive in a way that you wouldn't spill it.

Rule Number Two is to be aware of what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, three times on snow, and even more on ice. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.

Craigie Aitchison

The painter Craigie Aitchison was born in Scotland. He moved to London planning to study law, but instead, he went to art school. There, he found traditional drawing classes difficult, but he continued painting. In his late twenties, he received money from the Italian government to study art, and he became interested in early Italian artists, which is reflected in some of his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian fields and the clear light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. This led him to paint colors thinly, layering them from light to dark, but he says he's never sure what the results will be. He explains, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Like many talented people, Aitchison makes it sound easy. 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I simply notice what you put the colors next to.' Unlike some artists, he never makes drawings before starting a painting, as he feels that if he did, he might get bored and not complete the painting. Instead, Aitchison changes his paintings many times before they are finished. This is why his favorite models are people who don't ask to see their pictures while he's painting them. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he has not felt part of the Scottish painting scene. He says he is not interested in following any tradition, but just paints the way he can. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Text: 'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we were against the idea because of the noise. 'It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time,' Ben argued, 'and it'll keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we agreed. 'All right,' we said, 'but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play.' That was just the start. Because drums are not easy to move, the other members of Ben's band began coming to our home with their guitars and other electric equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house shakes with the sound of their instruments and their teenage singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts practicing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. And I must admit that, although their music may sound a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot judge their musical skill - after all, I didn't expect my parents' generation to like the same music as I did when I was a teenager - but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain - Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

Atlantic College

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a top private school in Wales. This school is special because it gives young people important experiences outside the classroom, along with preparing them for exams. The students, aged 16 to 18, come from all over the world. They study in the morning and in the afternoon, they do useful activities like helping on a farm, assisting people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is its diverse student body. Students come from different social backgrounds and countries. Since the fees are PS20,000 for two years, many students need financial help. Grants are available, and a quarter of the students are British, with many receiving government support to attend.

"I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with and respect others, even those you don't like. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed I argued less with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides an excellent education with methods that truly work.

Text: 'Being an older student At 32, I have just finished my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly and have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I was earning a decent amount of money, but I was bored because the job didn't challenge me. I felt stuck and became more and more unhappy. I envied the students at the local university because they seemed happy and full of hope. I wanted to be part of that. However, now that I'm a student, I find it hard to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a lecturer and ask me questions I can't answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. But I am grateful for this chance to study because I know a qualification is needed for a rewarding job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending weekends with my books rather than going out partying. There are also typical student benefits like long holidays and discounts at theatres and cinemas. I often wonder what I'll do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this age has been a good decision.'

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not enjoy farming. At fifteen, he started working as a mechanic, and in 1893, he built his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. By using strong but light steel, he created affordable cars for ordinary people. In 1908, he introduced the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars a day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Text: 'Dear Sir, I saw your advertisement for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more information. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next course start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course lasts 6 weeks and costs Â£150. If you prefer to start in June, we have another course that lasts 10 weeks and costs Â£200. I hope this answers your questions. Yours, David May '

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before climbing the highest mountain in the world, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is tough. "You must carry everything on your back," she said, "so you can only take what you need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I usually like to be clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!" When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. She suddenly became famous. Now, she has written a book about the trip, and people often ask her to talk about it. She also has a new job on a science programme on television. Rebecca is well known today and has more money, but she still lives in the small flat in south London with her pictures and books about mountains.

Dear Mike,

I'm sorry you couldn't come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and decided to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? It was a great party; the best I've ever had! Many of my friends were there, and they gave me some lovely presents. I'll tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday.

Love,  
Lorenzo

Text: 'CANADA GEESE Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to warmer places. The winters in Canada are so cold that the birds would die if they stayed. Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, 'These young birds won't know what to do in the autumn.' Bill had a small plane and decided to teach the birds to follow him. All summer, he took short trips in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When autumn's cold weather came, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and returned home. This spring, Bill waited for the birds to come back. They didn't arrive, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but couldn't find them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without him!'

Text: 'ESTHER'S STORY When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her Â£500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, but Esther used her aunt's money to start a business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make her own jam. She sold the jam for Â£1 a jar to her friends and soon doubled her aunt's Â£500. At first, her parents didn't want Esther to spend her time making jam; they thought she should study instead. They hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor one day. But Esther didn't listen to them and continued making jam. After a few months, she began selling it at the local market. Then she started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where one of her friends worked. After two years, her business grew very large, and her parents were very happy with her. She made all kinds of food, which she sold to shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she had to hire some people to work for her.'

Text: 'Dear Jacqueline, Would you like to join me at the cinema after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film begins at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? Love, Isabella Dear Isabella, I'm very sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you ask Karen to go with you? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. Love, Jacqueline'

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler run the farm, where they keep cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She owns 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the wool from the sheep to prevent them from getting too warm. 

Five years ago, Jenny decided to make sweaters from the wool and sell them at country markets. Unfortunately, it was summer, and the hot weather meant people were not interested in buying sweaters. So, she decided to make socks instead. The socks became very popular because they were affordable, durable, and easy to wash. This marked the beginning of Jenny's business. Initially, she made the socks at home, but as her customer base grew to thousands, she had to send the wool to a factory. Now, all the socks are produced by machines in the factory.

Jenny's socks come in six colors, five sizes for all ages, and are designed for different activities like walking, sports, and skiing. The busiest time for Jenny is Christmas, as Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In Jenny's office, the walls are covered with letters from satisfied customers from around the world.

28 Long Road Brighton 22nd March

Dear Pat,

I arrived here three weeks ago. I'm studying at a language school in Brighton. The students come from many different countries, and I have made many new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I like our teacher a lot. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon.

Best wishes,  
Maria

Text: 'BURGLARS LOVE THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that house burglaries have increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also mentioned that 67% of burglaries occur when people leave a door or window open. He explained that night-time burglaries are rare because families are usually at home then. However, he said that winter afternoons are ideal for burglars because it is dark, making it easier for them to go unnoticed. Many houses are empty at that time since people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders suggested leaving lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday to deter burglars. He also encouraged neighbors to watch over other houses on the street when people are away and to call the police if they notice anything unusual. 'We can also advise you on how to make your house safe,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This kind of help is free.''

Dear Lynne and Tony,

I'm writing to thank you for the two nights I stayed at your lovely home. It was great to see you again. Here are the photographs of your children that you asked for. They're nice photos, aren't they? I hope you like them. I really love my new camera. I am going to visit my sister in New York next week. I will take many photos there, too. I haven't seen my sister for a long time.

Thanks again.

Love,  
Roy

Text: 'The History of Farming Before farming began, people searched in forests for plants or fruit to eat. This meant they moved constantly to find food. However, around 12,000 years ago in the Middle East, people started to grow their own food. These were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to stay in one place, and their villages gradually expanded. Some villagers could then focus on other tasks, like making clothes, because farmers provided food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming was challenging when the weather was bad, and some people didn't have enough to eat. Today, farmers can produce more food, and it travels thousands of kilometers from where it is grown to our homes.'

Text: 'WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen, went to college, and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she started working for Saudi Arabian Airlines and later joined British Airways as a flight attendant. Four years after that, she got her current job as a manager. This is what she told us about her job: 'My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I teach flight attendants and help them with any issues. I also attend many meetings. My working hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check flight times on my computer and then talk with some of the flight attendants. Sometimes I go on long flights to see how the flight attendants are doing. That's my favorite part of the job, but I also enjoy office work. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I can do is eat something and then go to bed! I don't earn a lot of money, but I'm happy with British Airways and want to stay there and continue to travel.''

Text: 'Dear Maria, It's nice to be back in my country, but I still remember all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my stay was too short. I want to return to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even more. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon. Love, Sophie'

Text: 'Dear Sir, I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8:30 a.m. train to Cambridge on 10th May. It is a large blue bag, and my name is written on the outside. Have you found this bag? Yours faithfully, Mary Johnson Dear Ms. Johnson, I am happy to inform you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can return it to you. The office is open from 9 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. every day. Yours sincerely, J Wilson'

The Weather People are interested in the weather for many reasons, and it is important for people in different jobs. For example, the weather is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers spent a lot of time looking at the sky, animals, and flowers to understand the weather. Now, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even get weather information on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe in old ideas about the weather. They say, for example, that if there is a red sky in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people also think that when cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.

Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small Canadian town. They have been friends and classmates for a long time. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing and swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This isn't because of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's younger brother, Kevin, who had trouble with reading. Kevin learns words better by seeing pictures and hearing information rather than just reading. Frazer wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to develop the game, and now it's ready to use. It's a game with pictures and sounds. For example, when you see the word 'hat', there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their game, and it will soon be available for sale worldwide. Many schools are interested in buying it.

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? Sleeping well is very important. When I visit my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, after a concert, it's hard to sleep because my mind is full of music. Sport is important too. Before my car accident, I spent two and a half hours a day, five days a week, at the sports centre. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well and drink a lot of water because it's healthy. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I don't always manage that. People shouldn't work all the time. I love my job, but I also enjoy other activities. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It's good to relax sometimes. I don't feel tired anymore since the doctor advised me to eat better. Now, I eat lots of vegetables like carrots and spinach every day. But I still enjoy burgers sometimes!'

Bollywood, the film industry in Mumbai, India, produces nearly 1,000 films each year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has created over 29,000 films, making it the largest film industry in the world, even bigger than the USA's. Watching films is the favorite pastime for most Indians, with ten million people going to the cinema daily. Bollywood films often feature romantic love stories, with singing and dancing as key elements. These films are also popular outside India, earning Bollywood over $500 million last year from international sales. Indian actors make more films annually than Hollywood actors, but they earn less money. As a result, most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to produce, while Hollywood films usually cost at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan is an exception; he is considered one of India's greatest actors and has starred in over 140 films during a career spanning almost 40 years.

Bill Bryson was born in the United States, but he has written several travel books about England. He lived in England with his wife and four children for 20 years. For the last three years, they have been living in the United States. His children are now learning about life in the U.S. He believes they will be happier because they have experienced life in two countries. Bryson likes Britain and wants to return, but his daughter, Felicity, will start college in the U.S. soon, so he plans to stay for another four years. Recently, he spent six weeks in England to work on a radio program about the English language and to discuss his new book. Unlike most writers, he doesn't mind traveling around to promote his book.
