He enjoys visiting new places and meeting people. This is very different from his writing life in the U.S. In England, he was driven around in big cars and stayed in expensive hotels, which he enjoyed because he didn't have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to him, and he found it fun.

Text: 'Schnauzer Dogs There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England over 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer arrived more recently. The name Giant is fitting because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair, which needs regular trimming. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers originate from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep, and they are also used by the police because they are very intelligent. A Schnauzer is a good family dog. It is friendly and great with young children.'

Text: 'The Ruwenzori Mountains Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two big towns. 'It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops where we could buy food,' said Mary. 'It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world.' Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.'

Text: 'Dear Keira, Thank you for your letter. I had my first day at my new school today. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms were. She is very nice, and I am going to visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths, and I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time, and I really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I'm a bit scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I must go now because I have to do my homework. Hester'

New books this month

The Long Night  
This is David Reilly's first book. David became a writer after teaching English for several years. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia, working in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick, and Maha has to drive all night to take the baby to the nearest big city. They face many problems on the way and ...

Hard Work  
This exciting story is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. Hard Work is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long, hard hours making tables and chairs, but they do not have much money. Then one day, a man dressed all in black buys the most beautiful table in the shop ...

Hospital or Cinema?  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. Tina is a young Brazilian woman who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine, but one day she meets a man who asks her to go to the USA with him to become a film star ... What will Tina do?

The history of horse racing Horse racing has been an important sport for a long time. It began in Central Asia about 4,500 years ago and was popular in Greek and Roman times. Modern horse racing started when Arab horses came to Europe in the 12th century. Initially, races were long and only between two horses. However, at the start of the 18th century, races became shorter and involved several horses competing. Today, in the USA, more people watch horse racing than any other sport except baseball. It is also very popular in other parts of the world.

World traveler Nick Barlow loves his job. He is a British actor who travels around the world making TV programs. "People welcome me everywhere I go, and when I get home, I remember all the wonderful things that happened in each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but there are still a few trips he would like to make. "I'd love to visit South America and go back to Australia one day," he adds. On each trip, Nick travels with a team. They bring the cameras and other equipment needed to make the program. Nick doesn't pack many personal items, just a few shirts and trousers, but he always makes sure to have some books in his suitcase. Nick's wife, Helen, doesn't mind him traveling for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When he returns, she enjoys listening to all his travel stories. However, sometimes there are problems. When he was in the Malaysian rainforest, Nick heard that his wife was ill in the hospital. "I felt terrible because I couldn't help, but she didn't want me to come home. I was so happy when I heard she was better," he recalls.

Parrots You might have seen these beautiful birds, with their vibrant colors and long tails, in the forest or at the zoo. Parrots are native to countries such as Brazil, Australia, and India. They typically live in large groups, and because they enjoy eating fruit, they can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many different species of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet, which they use for climbing and holding food. The largest parrots can live up to 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are intelligent birds and can be easily taught to talk. Some zoos have parrot shows, where you can watch the birds perform tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a lovely village about fifty kilometres west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr Bonnier's name yet, but he's already quite famous in France. This is because he has written in French magazines about almost all the best restaurants in that country. He's only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend money on lots of clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and it's much more difficult to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he's sure he's done the right thing.'

Text: 'John Pickering In a park in a small town in central England, John Pickering takes care of the grass and flowers. But last week, he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on TV. John, who is thirty-five years old, is currently the top singer in Japan. He visited Japan a few months ago to perform in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on the radio. Many young people called the radio station to request his songs again. John, known as Jon Otis when he sings in Japan, plans to keep his job in the park in England. He is unsure how much money he will make from his music. 'I need to keep my job in the park,' he says. 'I still have bills to pay!' The other gardeners do not know he is famous in Japan. They have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, 'This will not change our life. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!''

Memo To: All staff  
Subject: Holidays  
From: D Brown  
Date: 22.2.02  

I am organizing the holidays for next year. Please let me know when you would like to take your holiday. If possible, could you provide two options for dates? Please give me your response by the end of the month. Thank you.  
D Brown  

---

Memo To: D Brown  
Subject: Holidays  
From: J Green  
Date: 23.2.02  

Could I take two weeks' holiday in July? I would prefer the first two weeks, but if that is not possible, the last two weeks will be fine. Additionally, can I take three extra days in the first week of December?  
John

Text: 'Line dancing Thousands of people in Britain have a new hobby -- line dancing. In almost every town, you can find clubs and classes for this activity. 'Line dancing is easy to learn. If you have two feet and can walk, then you can do it!' says Fiona Lever, a teacher. 'You don't need a partner because you dance in groups. It's a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are both young and old people. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet during the dances!' When did line dancing begin? Most people think it started about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.'

Text: 'The Rhino There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the others live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough and they have very little hair. A rhino's big body stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos at birth. It stays inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live up to 50 years.'

Text: 'THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE Today, there are policemen everywhere, but in 1700, London had no policemen at all. A few old men used to guard the city streets at night, and they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London was starting to grow. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were so many thieves stealing money in the streets that people stayed in their homes as much as possible. In 1750, Henry Fielding began paying a group of people to stop thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had become very large and needed more policemen. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was started with 3000 officers. Most of the men worked on foot, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police are quite well paid, and for the few police officers who still ride horses, the pay is even better than for the others.'

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Are you interested in joining a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest by school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers, a small shop, and you can rent bicycles. The trip costs Â£25. It gets very cold at night, so bring warm clothes and wear sturdy shoes. If you want to join, let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, thousands of people visit Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to join the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come for the biggest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are lively with music and dance from early morning until late at night. You can even watch artists painting on the streets. One of the highlights of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues like halls and cafes. Many tourists come to see new films and plays and listen to music by famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite cheap, and it is often easier to see your favourite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember it can be hard to find a room, so consider booking your hotel now!'

Text: 'ICE-FISHING If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake turns into ice, and thousands of Canadian fishermen go there each weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Then they sit inside to catch fish that swim under the ice. Bob Marvisch has been coming here at this time of year for twenty-five years. 'You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy,' he says. 'First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I have caught three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport and you can meet some nice people here!''

Text: 'From: Greg To: Anna Hi Anna, I'm not having a good week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team was much better than us! Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can't visit us during the holidays because he has a summer job. So, we can't go camping together now. And this morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school! She didn't tell me she needed it. I'm really upset with her. I hope you have some good news! Please write back today if you can. Greg '

Madame Tussaud's

A very famous tourist attraction in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. At this museum, visitors can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures of people and opened a museum for them in Paris. Marie helped her uncle with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was put in prison. While there, she had to make wax copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.

Text: 'BICYCLES Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were costly, and only wealthy individuals could afford them. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we see today. Later, as bicycles became more affordable, many people started buying them. People began using bicycles to commute to work and for leisure. Nowadays, cars are used more than bicycles because they are much faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still prefer cycling to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers, making it hard to find parking.'

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14 Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. It had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went to a large square with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their keepers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant got a paintbrush and started to paint on its own card. Sometimes, the keepers gave the elephants a new brush with paint and took the old one away. Slowly, following their keepers' instructions, the elephants drew pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe what I was seeing! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers held up the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they don't work there anymore, but the smartest of these animals live in special centers where visitors can watch them.'

Text: 'Big Cats There are many different types of big cats. They vary in size and have different appearances and behaviors. Tigers are the largest of the big cats. They can be up to 3.7 meters long from head to tail. Unlike most cats, tigers enjoy water and often lie in it to cool down when it's hot. Lions are unique because they live in large family groups called prides. Several lions work together to hunt for food for the pride. They usually live in open, flat areas where they can see far and easily track other animals. All big cats need excellent eyesight to catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and very strong.'

Dear Mrs. Brian,

I am sorry, but I can't attend your class anymore because I have to return to my country. My sister is getting married next month, and I want to go shopping with her to choose a dress. My parents will prepare a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I am sorry to leave the English class. You are a very good teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me.

Thank you again.

Best wishes,  
Soraya

Love,  
Gloria

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, with adults weighing over 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but their numbers are low. Although ostriches have wings like all birds, they cannot fly. Instead, they use their wings to help them change direction while running. Ostriches can run very fast, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometres per hour, making it hard for predators to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the size of chickens and take around 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can survive for many days without water.'

Victoria Jamieson, from Britain, began snowboarding at the age of 20. Now, at 23, she has won many competitions in this sport. We interviewed her last week at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland and asked why she started snowboarding. She said, "I've always enjoyed all kinds of sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding felt like a natural choice. It doesn't take long to learn, and you can become quite skilled in a few months." 

We asked if she practices a lot. She replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. But I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains. It's so beautiful. But free-riding, which is doing what you want when you're not competing, is the best thing in the world for me."

We also asked what is important when learning to snowboard. She said, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It's also important to have the right clothes so you don't get wet because, at first, you spend a lot of time falling down!"

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed it, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to reach the top. The Marangu path, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. It takes about five days to climb and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the climbers make it to the top. This is often because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it might be hot and wet, but at the top, there is ice and snow, and the temperature can drop below 20 degrees. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothes!

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can move through water at speeds over 10 kilometres per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. Twenty years ago, there were few otters in Great Britain because the rivers were polluted, causing many fish and insects to die, leaving otters with little to eat. Today, the rivers are clean again, providing plenty of food for them.'

Text: 'Dear Deshini, I'm happy to have you as my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there one day. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school you could send me? I'm sending you a few photos of my family. I'll send more next time I write. I hope to hear from you soon. Tom'

Text: '17 Green Street Camden London 29th August 2002 Dear John, Thank you for helping me with my English. You are an excellent teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying medicine. I will stay with him for two weeks and then return home to Greece. I like London a lot. Yesterday, we went to Regents Park by bus. It was very sunny, and we had a great time. Tonight, I am going to watch a film with my brother and some of his friends. I'll write again from Greece. Best wishes, Kostas'

Text: 'Dear David, I will visit your country next month with two friends. We don't know where to stay. Are there any affordable hotels in your town? We would like to stay in the centre. Can you help us? Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the centre are expensive, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you, and she says you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! That will be alright with you, won't it? David'

Text: 'Buildings People have always constructed buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and pop concerts. We use other buildings, like museums, to store beautiful things. Many people collaborate on a building. The architect decides how the building will look and creates drawings to show their ideas. Engineers ensure the building will be strong and safe. Then, the workers carefully construct it. The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with a beautiful roof. However, the building is attractive from every angle, not just from above. The Olympic Stadium in Munich also has a famous roof. This unique building resembles a tent made of glass.'

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and need your help. Can you come shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will turn 80 next month, and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don't have anything to wear. I have grown so much that all my trousers are too short now! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money to spend, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large figure of a man. This figure is called the Cerne Giant because it is near the village of Cerne. Nobody knows exactly when the Cerne Giant was created, but it is believed to be very old. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the figure. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see people from the village dancing around the figure on the hill.'

Gail Rollins is one of the top runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she aims to compete in the 10,000 metresâ€”and possibly the 5,000 metresâ€”at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for finishing second in major competitions. However, she always laughed and smiled, which made people in her hometown admire her. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with an impressive time, the fastest of the year for any British woman runner. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, also used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop competing after injuring his right leg. He can still run a bit and sometimes trains with Gail. However, it's not enjoyable for Mike when Gail overtakes him and he can't keep up. Gail trains hard, doing a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. She always takes a break from running on Sundays. "I am with her all the time," says Mike. "Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

Text: 'Piano players - when they were young Ivan Petrov Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. His mother started teaching him piano when he was six. At ten, he decided he wanted to write music and soon began his first song. Oleg Gagarin Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he started lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly began winning prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years, then returned to Russia. Josef Heptmann Josef's father was German but taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he started playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef always liked music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is too busy now, but one day he would like to write his own music.'

Bill Prince-Smith Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he started writing children's books at 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he writes in his office. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. 'She tells me if she doesn't like something,' says Bill. 'My ten grandchildren don't live nearby, but they also read my stories and say if they are good or bad.' This way, Bill has learned what young children like to read. Bill writes about life in his village and the nearby farms. His fifth book, The Sheepdog, is his favorite. It is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. 'I have always liked animals,' says Bill, 'and dogs are very clever; they learn quickly.' Last year, the book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest computer technology to make it look like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. 'Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film.'

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the pictures are often better than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century. It featured a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards showed pictures of news events from that week, like an accident or a visit from an important person. People liked these because newspapers did not have pictures at that time.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur because they died out about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. The exact reason for their extinction is still unknown. Birds are the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs varied greatly in appearance. There were over 5000 different types. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as large, but it was more powerful. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast due to its long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can kill a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they find food using their noses. There are seven types of bears. The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in Southeast Asia. But not all black bears are actually black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. Everyone loves the black and white panda bear, which is from China. Today, not many pandas live in the forest because it is hard for them to find food.'

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in tropical areas around the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water but can move quickly in water and on land. Crocodiles are often seen in large groups. They eat anything they catch, including fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat large animals or people. There are more than ten different types of crocodiles. All of them have very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth, but new ones grow back quickly. Most crocodiles are about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much larger. Crocodiles can live for many years. The oldest crocodile in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was round, had no roof, and people got cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to watch the plays of William Shakespeare. All the actors at that time were men. Visitors ate, talked to their friends, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place near the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Dear Jeff,

I'm having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is so warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different here: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home!

See you at the end of September.

Sue
